1. Johnny Depp (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000136/?ref_=ls_t_1)
Actor
Producer
Director
Pirates of the Caribbean: The Curse of the Black Pearl (2003) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0325980/?ref_=ls_knf_1)
John Christopher "Johnny" Depp II was born on June 9, 1963 in Owensboro, Kentucky, to Betty Sue Palmer (née Wells), a waitress, and John Christopher Depp, a civil engineer. He was raised in Florida. He dropped out of school when he was 15, and fronted a series of music-garage bands, including one named 'The Kids'. When he married
Lori A. Depp (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0220129/?ls)
, he took a job as a ballpoint-pen salesman to support himself and his wife. A visit to Los Angeles, California, with his wife, however, happened to be a blessing in disguise, when he met up with actor
Nicolas Cage (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000115/?ls)
, who advised him to turn to acting, which culminated in Depp's film debut in the low-budget horror film,
A Nightmare on Elm Street (1984) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0087800/?ls)
, where he played a teenager who falls prey to dream-stalking demon Freddy Krueger.
In 1987 he shot to stardom when he replaced
Jeff Yagher (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0944891/?ls)
in the role of undercover cop Tommy Hanson in the popular TV series
21 Jump Street (1987) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0092312/?ls)
. In 1990, after numerous roles in teen-oriented films, his first of a handful of great collaborations with director
Tim Burton (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000318/?ls)
came about when Depp played the title role in
Edward Scissorhands (1990) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0099487/?ls)
. Following the film's success, Depp carved a niche for himself as a serious, somewhat dark, idiosyncratic performer, consistently selecting roles that surprised critics and audiences alike. He continued to gain critical acclaim and increasing popularity by appearing in many features before re-joining with Burton in the lead role of
Ed Wood (1994) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0109707/?ls)
. In 1997 he played an undercover FBI agent in the fact-based film
Donnie Brasco (1997) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0119008/?ls)
, opposite
Al Pacino (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000199/?ls)
; in 1998 he appeared in
Fear and Loathing in Las Vegas (1998) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0120669/?ls)
, directed by
Terry Gilliam (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000416/?ls)
; and then, in 1999, he appeared in the sci-fi/horror film
The Astronaut's Wife (1999) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0138304/?ls)
. The same year he teamed up again with Burton in
Sleepy Hollow (1999) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0162661/?ls)
, brilliantly portraying Ichabod Crane.
Depp has played many characters in his career, including another fact-based one, Insp. Fred Abberline in
From Hell (2001) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0120681/?ls)
. He stole the show from screen greats such as
Antonio Banderas (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000104/?ls)
in the finale to
Robert Rodriguez (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001675/?ls)
's "mariachi" trilogy,
Once Upon a Time in Mexico (2003) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0285823/?ls)
. In that same year he starred in the marvelous family blockbuster
Pirates of the Caribbean: The Curse of the Black Pearl (2003) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0325980/?ls)
, playing a character that only the likes of Depp could pull off: the charming, conniving and roguish Capt. Jack Sparrow. The film's enormous success has opened several doors for his career and included an Oscar nomination. He appeared as the central character in the
Stephen King (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000175/?ls)
-based movie,
Secret Window (2004) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0363988/?ls)
; as the kind-hearted novelist James Barrie in the factually-based
Finding Neverland (2004) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0308644/?ls)
, where he co-starred with
Kate Winslet (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000701/?ls)
; and Rochester in the British film,
The Libertine (2004) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0375920/?ls)
. Depp collaborated again with Burton in a screen adaptation of
Roald Dahl (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001094/?ls)
's novel,
Charlie and the Chocolate Factory (2005) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0367594/?ls)
, and later in
Alice in Wonderland (2010) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1014759/?ls)
and
Dark Shadows (2012) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1077368/?ls)
.
Off-screen, Depp has dated several female celebrities, and has been engaged to
Sherilyn Fenn (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000145/?ls)
,
Jennifer Grey (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000426/?ls)
,
Winona Ryder (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000213/?ls)
and
Kate Moss (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0609017/?ls)
. He was married to Lori Anne Allison in 1983, but divorced her in 1985. Depp has two children with his former long-time partner, French singer/actress
Vanessa Paradis (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0660854/?ls)
: Lily-Rose Melody, born in 1999 and John Christopher "Jack" III, born in 2002. He married actress/producer
Amber Heard (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm1720028/?ls)
in 2015, divorcing a few years later.
[No Text] (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000216/?ref_=ls_i_2)
2. Arnold Schwarzenegger (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000216/?ref_=ls_t_2)
Actor
Producer
Writer
Terminator 2: Judgment Day (1991) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0103064/?ref_=ls_knf_2)
With an almost unpronounceable surname and a thick Austrian accent, who
would have ever believed that a brash, quick talking bodybuilder from a
small European village would become one of Hollywood's biggest stars,
marry into the prestigious Kennedy family, amass a fortune via shrewd
investments and one day be the Governor of California!?
The amazing story of megastar Arnold Schwarzenegger is a true "rags to
riches" tale of a penniless immigrant making it in the land of
opportunity, the United States of America. Arnold Alois Schwarzenegger was born July 30, 1947, in the town of Thal, Styria, Austria, to
Aurelia Schwarzenegger (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm9134375/?ls)
(born Jadrny) and Gustav
Schwarzenegger, the local police chief. From a young age, he took a
keen interest in physical fitness and bodybuilding, going on to compete
in several minor contests in Europe. However, it was when he emigrated
to the United States in 1968 at the tender age of 21 that his star
began to rise.
Up until the early 1970s, bodybuilding had been viewed as a rather
oddball sport, or even a mis-understood "freak show" by the general
public, however two entrepreneurial Canadian brothers
Ben Weider (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm2366221/?ls)
and
Joe Weider (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0917755/?ls)
set about broadening the appeal of
"pumping iron" and getting the sport respect, and what better poster
boy could they have to lead the charge, then the incredible "Austrian
Oak", Arnold Schwarzenegger. Over roughly the next decade, beginning in
1970, Schwarzenegger dominated the sport of competitive bodybuilding
winning five Mr. Universe titles and seven Mr. Olympia titles and, with
it, he made himself a major sports icon, he generated a new
international audience for bodybuilding, gym memberships worldwide
swelled by the tens of thousands and the Weider sports business empire
flourished beyond belief and reached out to all corners of the globe.
However, Schwarzenegger's horizons were bigger than just the landscape
of bodybuilding and he debuted on screen as "Arnold Strong" in the low
budget
Hercules in New York (1970) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0065832/?ls)
,
then director
Bob Rafelson (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0706182/?ls)
cast Arnold in
Stay Hungry (1976) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0075268/?ls)
alongside
Jeff Bridges (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000313/?ls)
and
Sally Field (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000398/?ls)
, for which Arnold won a Golden
Globe Award for "Best Acting Debut in a Motion Picture". The
mesmerizing
Pumping Iron (1977) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0076578/?ls)
covering the 1975 Mr Olympia contest in South Africa has since gone on
to become one of the key sports documentaries of the 20th century, plus
Arnold landed other acting roles in the comedy
The Villain (1979) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0080097/?ls)
opposite
Kirk Douglas (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000018/?ls)
, and he portrayed
Mickey Hargitay (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0362927/?ls)
in the well- received TV
movie
The Jayne Mansfield Story (1980) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0080947/?ls)
.
What Arnold really needed was a super hero / warrior style role in a
lavish production that utilized his chiseled physique, and gave him
room to show off his growing acting talents and quirky humor.
Conan the Barbarian (1982) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0082198/?ls)
was just that role. Inspired by the
Robert E. Howard (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0397574/?ls)
short stories of the
"Hyborean Age" and directed by gung ho director
John Milius (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0587518/?ls)
, and with a largely unknown
cast, save
Max von Sydow (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001884/?ls)
and
James Earl Jones (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000469/?ls)
, "Conan" was a smash
hit worldwide and an inferior, although still enjoyable sequel titled
Conan the Destroyer (1984) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0087078/?ls)
quickly followed. If "Conan" was the kick start to Arnold's movie
career, then his next role was to put the pedal to the floor and
accelerate his star status into overdrive. Director
James Cameron (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000116/?ls)
had until that time
only previously directed one earlier feature film titled
Piranha II: The Spawning (1982) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0082910/?ls)
, which stank of rotten fish from start to finish. However, Cameron had penned a fast paced, science fiction themed film script that called for
an actor to play an unstoppable, ruthless predator -
The Terminator (1984) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0088247/?ls)
. Made on a
relatively modest budget, the high voltage action / science fiction
thriller
The Terminator (1984) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0088247/?ls)
was
incredibly successful worldwide, and began one of the most profitable
film franchises in history. The dead pan phrase "I'll be back" quickly
became part of popular culture across the globe. Schwarzenegger was in
vogue with action movie fans, and the next few years were to see Arnold
reap box office gold in roles portraying tough, no-nonsense individuals
who used their fists, guns and witty one-liners to get the job done.
The testosterone laden
Commando (1985) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0088944/?ls)
,
Raw Deal (1986) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0091828/?ls)
,
Predator (1987) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0093773/?ls)
,
The Running Man (1987) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0093894/?ls)
and
Red Heat (1988) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0095963/?ls)
were all box office hits
and Arnold could seemingly could no wrong when it came to picking
winning scripts. The tongue-in-cheek comedy
Twins (1988) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0096320/?ls)
with co-star
Danny DeVito (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000362/?ls)
was a smash and won Arnold new
fans who saw a more comedic side to the muscle- bound actor once
described by Australian author / TV host
Clive James (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0416380/?ls)
as "a condom stuffed with
walnuts". The spectacular
Total Recall (1990) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0100802/?ls)
and "feel good"
Kindergarten Cop (1990) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0099938/?ls)
were
both solid box office performers for Arnold, plus he was about to
return to familiar territory with director
James Cameron (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000116/?ls)
in
Terminator 2: Judgment Day (1991) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0103064/?ls)
.
The second time around for the futuristic robot, the production budget
had grown from the initial film's $6.5 million to an alleged $100
million for the sequel, and it clearly showed as the stunning sequel
bristled with amazing special effects, bone-crunching chases & stunt
sequences, plus state of the art computer-generated imagery.
Terminator 2: Judgment Day (1991) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0103064/?ls)
was arguably the zenith of Arnold's film career to date and he was
voted "International Star of the Decade" by the National Association of
Theatre Owners.
Remarkably, his next film
Last Action Hero (1993) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0107362/?ls)
brought
Arnold back to Earth with a hard thud as the self-satirizing, but
confusing plot line of a young boy entering into a mythical Hollywood
action film confused movie fans even more and they stayed away in
droves making the film an initial financial disaster. Arnold turned
back to good friend, director
James Cameron (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000116/?ls)
and the chemistry
was definitely still there as the "James Bond" style spy thriller
True Lies (1994) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0111503/?ls)
co-starring
Jamie Lee Curtis (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000130/?ls)
and
Tom Arnold (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000792/?ls)
was the surprise hit of
1994! Following the broad audience appeal of
True Lies (1994) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0111503/?ls)
, Schwarzenegger
decided to lean towards more family-themed entertainment with
Junior (1994) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0110216/?ls)
and
Jingle All the Way (1996) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0116705/?ls)
, but
he still found time to satisfy his hard-core fan base with
Eraser (1996) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0116213/?ls)
, as the chilling "Mr.
Freeze" in
Batman & Robin (1997) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0118688/?ls)
and battling dark forces in the supernatural action of
End of Days (1999) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0146675/?ls)
. The science
fiction / conspiracy tale
The 6th Day (2000) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0216216/?ls)
played to only
mediocre fan interest, and
Collateral Damage (2002) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0233469/?ls)
had
its theatrical release held over for nearly a year after the tragic
events of Sept 11th 2001, but it still only received a lukewarm
reception.
It was time again to resurrect Arnold's most successful franchise and,
in 2003, Schwarzenegger pulled on the biker leathers for the third time
for
Terminator 3: Rise of the Machines (2003) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0181852/?ls)
.
Unfortunately, directorial duties passed from
James Cameron (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000116/?ls)
to
Jonathan Mostow (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0609236/?ls)
and the deletion of the
character of "Sarah Connor" aka
Linda Hamilton (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000157/?ls)
and a change in
the actor playing "John Connor" -
Nick Stahl (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001763/?ls)
took over from
Edward Furlong (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000411/?ls)
- making
the third entry in the "Terminator" series the weakest to date.
Schwarzenegger married TV journalist
Maria Shriver (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0005425/?ls)
in April, 1986 and the
couple have four children.
In October of 2003 Schwarzenegger, running as a Republican, was elected
Governor of California in a special recall election of then governor
Gray Davis (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0204665/?ls)
. The "Governator," as Schwarzenegger came to be called, held
the office until 2011. Upon leaving the Governor's mansion it was
revealed that he had fathered a child with the family's live-in maid
and Shriver filed for divorce.
Schwarzenegger contributed cameo roles to
The Rundown (2003) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0327850/?ls)
,
Around the World in 80 Days (2004) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0327437/?ls)
and
The Kid & I (2005) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0416891/?ls)
. Recently, he
starred in
The Expendables 2 (2012) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1764651/?ls)
,
The Last Stand (2013) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1549920/?ls)
,
Escape Plan (2013) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1211956/?ls)
,
The Expendables 3 (2014) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2333784/?ls)
, and
Terminator Genisys (2015) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1340138/?ls)
.
[No Text] (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000120/?ref_=ls_i_3)
3. Jim Carrey (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000120/?ref_=ls_t_3)
Actor
Writer
Producer
Ace Ventura: Pet Detective (1994) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0109040/?ref_=ls_knf_3)
Jim Carrey, Canadian-born and a U.S. citizen since 2004, is
an actor and producer famous for his rubbery body movements and
flexible facial expressions. The two-time Golden Globe-winner rose to
fame as a cast member of the Fox sketch comedy
In Living Color (1990) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0098830/?ls)
but
leading roles in
Ace Ventura: Pet Detective (1994) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0109040/?ls)
,
Dumb and Dumber (1994) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0109686/?ls)
and
The Mask (1994) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0110475/?ls)
established him as a
bankable comedy actor.
James Eugene Carrey was born on January 17, 1962 in Newmarket, Ontario, Canada, and is the youngest of four children of Kathleen (Oram), a homemaker,
and Percy Carrey, an accountant and jazz musician. The family surname
was originally "Carré", and he has French-Canadian, Scottish, and Irish
ancestry. Carrey was an incurable extrovert from day one. As a child,
he performed constantly, for anyone who would watch, and even mailed
his résumé to
The Carol Burnett Show (1967) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0061240/?ls)
at age 10. In junior high, he was granted a few precious minutes at the
end of each school day to do stand-up routines for his classmates
(provided, of course, that he kept a lid on it the rest of the day).
Carrey's early adolescence took a turn for the tragic, however, when
the family was forced to relocate from their cozy town of Newmarket to
Scarborough (a Toronto suburb). They all took security and janitorial
jobs in the Titan Wheels factory, Jim working 8-hour shifts after
school let out (not surprisingly, his grades and morale both suffered).
When they finally deserted the factory, the family lived out of a
Volkswagen camper van until they could return to Toronto.
Carrey made his stand-up debut in Toronto after his parents and
siblings got back on their feet. He made his (reportedly awful)
professional stand-up debut at Yuk-Yuk's, one of the many local clubs
that would serve as his training ground in the years to come. He
dropped out of high school, worked on his celebrity impersonations
(among them
Michael Landon (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001446/?ls)
and
James Stewart (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000071/?ls)
), and in 1979 worked
up the nerve to move to Los Angeles. He finessed his way into a regular
gig at The Comedy Store, where he impressed
Rodney Dangerfield (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001098/?ls)
so much that the
veteran comic signed him as an opening act for an entire season. During
this period Carrey met and married waitress Melissa Womer, with whom he
had a daughter (Jane). The couple would later go through a very messy
divorce, freeing Carrey up for a brief second marriage to actress
Lauren Holly (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000452/?ls)
. Wary of falling into the
lounge act lifestyle, Carrey began to look around for other performance
outlets. He landed a part as a novice cartoonist in the short-lived
sitcom
The Duck Factory (1984) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0086702/?ls)
;
while the show fell flat, the experience gave Carrey the confidence to
pursue acting more vigorously.
Carrey also worked on breaking into film around this time. He scored
the male lead in the ill-received
Lauren Hutton (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001381/?ls)
vehicle
Once Bitten (1985) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0089730/?ls)
, and had a
supporting role in
Peggy Sue Got Married (1986) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0091738/?ls)
,
before making a modest splash with his appearance as the alien Wiploc
in
Earth Girls Are Easy (1988) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0097257/?ls)
.
Impressed with Carrey's lunacy, fellow extraterrestrial
Damon Wayans (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001834/?ls)
made a call to his brother,
Keenen Ivory Wayans (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0005540/?ls)
, who was in the
process of putting together the sketch comedy show
In Living Color (1990) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0098830/?ls)
.
Carrey joined the cast and quickly made a name for himself with
outrageous acts (one of his most popular characters, psychotic Fire
Marshall Bill, was attacked by watchdog groups for dispensing ill-
advised safety tips).
Following his time on
In Living Color (1990) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0098830/?ls)
,
Carrey's transformation from TV goofball to marquee headliner happened
within the course of a single year. He opened 1994 with a starring turn
in
Ace Ventura: Pet Detective (1994) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0109040/?ls)
,
a film that cashed in on his extremely physical brand of humor (the
character's trademark was talking out his derrière). Next up was the
manic superhero movie
The Mask (1994) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0110475/?ls)
,
which had audiences wondering just how far Carrey's features could
stretch.
Finally, in December 1994, he hit theaters as a loveable dolt in the
Farrelly brothers'
Dumb and Dumber (1994) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0109686/?ls)
(his first
multi-million dollar payday). Now a box-office staple, Carrey brought
his manic antics onto the set of
Batman Forever (1995) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0112462/?ls)
, replacing
Robin Williams (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000245/?ls)
as The Riddler. He
also filmed the follow-up to his breakthrough,
Ace Ventura: When Nature Calls (1995) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0112281/?ls)
,
and inked a deal with Sony to star in
The Cable Guy (1996) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0115798/?ls)
(replacing
Chris Farley (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000394/?ls)
) for a cool $20
million--at the time, that was the biggest up-front sum that had been
offered to any comic actor. The movie turned out to be a
disappointment, both critically and financially, but Carrey bounced
back the next year with the energetic hit
Liar Liar (1997) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0119528/?ls)
. Worried that his
comic shtick would soon wear thin, Carrey decided to change course.
In 1998, he traded in the megabucks and silly grins to star in
Peter Weir (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001837/?ls)
's
The Truman Show (1998) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0120382/?ls)
playing a
naive salesman who discovers that his entire life is the subject of a
TV show, Carrey demonstrated an uncharacteristic sincerity that took
moviegoers by surprise. He won a Golden Globe for the performance, and
fans anticipated an Oscar nomination as well--when it didn't
materialize, Carrey lashed out at Academy members for their
narrow-minded selection process. Perhaps inspired by the snub, Carrey
threw himself into his next role with abandon. After edging out a
handful of other hopefuls (including
Edward Norton (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001570/?ls)
) to play eccentric
funnyman
Andy Kaufman (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001412/?ls)
in
Man on the Moon (1999) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0125664/?ls)
, Carrey
disappeared into the role, living as Kaufman -- and his blustery
alter-ego Tony Clifton -- for months (Carrey even owned Kaufman's bongo
drums, which he'd used during his audition for director
Milos Forman (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001232/?ls)
). His sometimes uncanny
impersonation was rewarded with another Golden Globe, but once again
the Academy kept quiet.
An indignant Carrey next reprised his bankable mania for the Farrelly
brothers in
Me, Myself & Irene (2000) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0183505/?ls)
,
playing a state trooper whose Jekyll and Hyde personalities both fall
in love with the same woman
(
Renée Zellweger (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000250/?ls)
). Carrey's real-life
persona wound up falling for her too--a few months after the film
wrapped, the pair announced they were officially a couple. By then,
Carrey had already slipped into a furry green suit to play the stingy
antihero of
Ron Howard (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000165/?ls)
's
How the Grinch Stole Christmas (2000) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0170016/?ls)
.
Although Carrey maintains a foothold in the comedy world with films
such as
Bruce Almighty (2003) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0315327/?ls)
and
Mr. Popper's Penguins (2011) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1396218/?ls)
,
he is also capable of turning in nuanced dramatic performances, as
demonstrated in films like
Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind (2004) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0338013/?ls)
and the drama/comedy
Yes Man (2008) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1068680/?ls)
. In
2013, he costars with
Steve Carell (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0136797/?ls)
in
The Incredible Burt Wonderstone (2013) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0790628/?ls)
.
Carrey has one child with his first wife,
Melissa Carrey (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0140314/?ls)
, whom he divorced in 1995.
He married actress
Lauren Holly (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000452/?ls)
in 1996,
but they split less than a year later.
[No Text] (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000138/?ref_=ls_i_4)
4. Leonardo DiCaprio (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000138/?ref_=ls_t_4)
Producer
Actor
Writer
Inception (2010) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1375666/?ref_=ls_knf_4)
Few actors in the world have had a career quite as diverse as Leonardo DiCaprio's. DiCaprio has gone from relatively humble beginnings, as a supporting cast member of the sitcom
Growing Pains (1985) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0088527/?ls)
and low budget horror movies, such as
Critters 3 (1991) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0101627/?ls)
, to a major teenage heartthrob in the 1990s, as the hunky lead actor in movies such as
Romeo + Juliet (1996) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0117509/?ls)
and
Titanic (1997) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0120338/?ls)
, to then become a leading man in Hollywood blockbusters, made by internationally renowned directors such as
Martin Scorsese (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000217/?ls)
and
Christopher Nolan (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0634240/?ls)
.
Leonardo Wilhelm DiCaprio was born in Los Angeles, California, the only child of
Irmelin DiCaprio (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm2638069/?ls)
(née Indenbirken) and former comic book artist
George DiCaprio (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm1096247/?ls)
. His father is of Italian and German descent, and his mother, who is German-born, is of German, Ukrainian and Russian ancestry. His middle name, "Wilhelm", was his maternal grandfather's first name. Leonardo's father had achieved minor status as an artist and distributor of cult comic book titles, and was even depicted in several issues of American Splendor, the cult semi-autobiographical comic book series by the late 'Harvey Pekar', a friend of George's. Leonardo's performance skills became obvious to his parents early on, and after signing him up with a talent agent who wanted Leonardo to perform under the stage name "Lenny Williams", DiCaprio began appearing on a number of television commercials and educational programs.
DiCaprio began attracting the attention of producers, who cast him in small roles in a number of television series, such as
Roseanne (1988) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0094540/?ls)
and
The New Lassie (1989) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0096661/?ls)
, but it wasn't until 1991 that DiCaprio made his film debut in
Critters 3 (1991) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0101627/?ls)
, a low-budget horror movie. While
Critters 3 (1991) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0101627/?ls)
did little to help showcase DiCaprio's acting abilities, it did help him develop his show-reel, and attract the attention of the people behind the hit sitcom
Growing Pains (1985) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0088527/?ls)
, in which Leonardo was cast in the "Cousin Oliver" role of a young homeless boy who moves in with the Seavers. While DiCaprio's stint on
Growing Pains (1985) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0088527/?ls)
was very short, as the sitcom was axed the year after he joined, it helped bring DiCaprio into the public's attention and, after the sitcom ended, DiCaprio began auditioning for roles in which he would get the chance to prove his acting chops.
Leonardo took up a diverse range of roles in the early 1990s, including a mentally challenged youth in
What's Eating Gilbert Grape (1993) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0108550/?ls)
, a young gunslinger in
The Quick and the Dead (1995) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0114214/?ls)
and a drug addict in one of his most challenging roles to date, Jim Carroll in
The Basketball Diaries (1995) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0112461/?ls)
, a role which the late
River Phoenix (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000203/?ls)
originally expressed interest in. While these diverse roles helped establish Leonardo's reputation as an actor, it wasn't until his role as Romeo Montague in
Baz Luhrmann (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0525303/?ls)
's
Romeo + Juliet (1996) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0117509/?ls)
that Leonardo became a household name, a true movie star. The following year, DiCaprio starred in another movie about doomed lovers,
Titanic (1997) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0120338/?ls)
, which went on to beat all box office records held before then, as, at the time,
Titanic (1997) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0120338/?ls)
became the highest grossing movie of all time, and cemented DiCaprio's reputation as a teen heartthrob. Following his work on
Titanic (1997) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0120338/?ls)
, DiCaprio kept a low profile for a number of years, with roles in
The Man in the Iron Mask (1998) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0120744/?ls)
and the low-budget
The Beach (2000) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0163978/?ls)
being some of his few notable roles during this period.
In 2002, he burst back into screens throughout the world with leading roles in
Catch Me If You Can (2002) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0264464/?ls)
and
Gangs of New York (2002) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0217505/?ls)
, his first of many collaborations with director
Martin Scorsese (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000217/?ls)
. With a current salary of $20 million a movie, DiCaprio is now one of the biggest movie stars in the world. However, he has not limited his professional career to just acting in movies, as DiCaprio is a committed environmentalist, who is actively involved in many environmental causes, and his commitment to this issue led to his involvement in The 11th Hour, a documentary movie about the state of the natural environment. As someone who has gone from small roles in television commercials to one of the most respected actors in the world, DiCaprio has had one of the most diverse careers in cinema. DiCaprio continued to defy conventions about the types of roles he would accept, and with his career now seeing him leading all-star casts in action thrillers such as
The Departed (2006) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0407887/?ls)
,
Shutter Island (2010) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1130884/?ls)
and
Christopher Nolan (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0634240/?ls)
's
Inception (2010) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1375666/?ls)
, DiCaprio continues to wow audiences by refusing to conform to any cliché about actors.
In 2012, he played a mustache twirling villain in
Django Unchained (2012) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1853728/?ls)
, and then tragic literary character Jay Gatsby in
The Great Gatsby (2013) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1343092/?ls)
and Jordan Belfort in
The Wolf of Wall Street (2013) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0993846/?ls)
.
DiCaprio is passionate about environmental and humanitarian causes, having donated $1,000,000 to earthquake relief efforts in 2010, the same year he contributed $1,000,000 to the Wildlife Conservation Society.
[No Text] (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000129/?ref_=ls_i_5)
5. Tom Cruise (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000129/?ref_=ls_t_5)
Actor
Producer
Director
Top Gun (1986) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0092099/?ref_=ls_knf_5)
In 1976, if you had told fourteen-year-old Franciscan seminary student Thomas Cruise Mapother IV that one day in the not too distant future he would be Tom Cruise, one of the top 100 movie stars of all time, he would have probably grinned and told you that his ambition was to join the priesthood. Nonetheless, this sensitive, deeply religious youngster who was born in 1962 in Syracuse, New York, was destined to become one of the highest paid and most sought after actors in screen history.
Tom is the only son (among four children) of nomadic parents, Mary Lee (Pfeiffer), a special education teacher, and Thomas Cruise Mapother III, an electrical engineer. His parents were both from Louisville, Kentucky, and he has German, Irish, and English ancestry. Young Tom spent his boyhood always on the move, and by the time he was 14 he had attended 15 different schools in the U.S. and Canada. He finally settled in Glen Ridge, New Jersey with his mother and her new husband. While in high school, Tom wanted to become a priest but pretty soon he developed an interest in acting and abandoned his plans of becoming a priest, dropped out of school, and at age 18 headed for New York and a possible acting career. The next 15 years of his life are the stuff of legends. He made his film debut with a small part in
Endless Love (1981) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0082329/?ls)
and from the outset exhibited an undeniable box office appeal to both male and female audiences.
With handsome movie star looks and a charismatic smile, within 5 years Tom Cruise was starring in some of the top-grossing films of the 1980s including
Top Gun (1986) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0092099/?ls)
;
The Color of Money (1986) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0090863/?ls)
,
Rain Man (1988) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0095953/?ls)
and
Born on the Fourth of July (1989) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0096969/?ls)
. By the 1990s he was one of the highest-paid actors in the world earning an average 15 million dollars a picture in such blockbuster hits as
Interview with the Vampire (1994) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0110148/?ls)
,
Mission: Impossible (1996) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0117060/?ls)
and
Jerry Maguire (1996) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0116695/?ls)
, for which he received an Academy Award Nomination for best actor. Tom Cruise's biggest franchise, Mission Impossible, has also earned a total of 3 billion dollars worldwide. Tom Cruise has also shown lots of interest in producing, with his biggest producer credits being the Mission Impossible franchise.
In 1990 he renounced his devout Catholic beliefs and embraced The Church of Scientology claiming that Scientology teachings had cured him of the dyslexia that had plagued him all of his life. A kind and thoughtful man well known for his compassion and generosity, Tom Cruise is one of the best liked members of the movie community. He was married to actress
Nicole Kidman (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000173/?ls)
until 2001. Thomas Cruise Mapother IV has indeed come a long way from the lonely wanderings of his youth to become one of the biggest movie stars ever.
[No Text] (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000375/?ref_=ls_i_6)
6. Robert Downey Jr. (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000375/?ref_=ls_t_6)
Actor
Producer
Writer
Iron Man (2008) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0371746/?ref_=ls_knf_6)
Robert Downey Jr. has evolved into one of the most respected actors in Hollywood. With an amazing list of credits to his name, he has managed to stay new and fresh even after over four decades in the business.
Downey was born April 4, 1965 in Manhattan, New York, the son of writer, director and filmographer
Robert Downey Sr. (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0002049/?ls)
and actress
Elsie Downey (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0235991/?ls)
(née Elsie Ann Ford). Robert's father is of half Lithuanian Jewish, one quarter Hungarian Jewish, and one quarter Irish, descent, while Robert's mother was of English, Scottish, German, and Swiss-German ancestry. Robert and his sister,
Allyson Downey (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0235969/?ls)
, were immersed in film and the performing arts from a very young age, leading Downey Jr. to study at the Stagedoor Manor Performing Arts Training Center in upstate New York, before moving to California with his father following his parents' 1978 divorce. In 1982, he dropped out of Santa Monica High School to pursue acting full time. Downey Sr., himself a drug addict, exposed his son to drugs at a very early age, and Downey Jr. would go on to struggle with abuse for decades.
Downey Jr. made his debut as an actor at the age of five in the film
Pound (1970) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0066234/?ls)
, written and directed by his father,
Robert Downey Sr. (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0002049/?ls)
. He built his film repertoire throughout the 1980s and 1990s with roles in
Tuff Turf (1985) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0090213/?ls)
,
Weird Science (1985) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0090305/?ls)
,
True Believer (1989) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0098524/?ls)
, and
Wonder Boys (2000) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0185014/?ls)
among many others. In 1992, Downey received an Academy Award nomination and won the BAFTA (British Academy Award) for Best Actor for his performance in the title role of
Chaplin (1992) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0103939/?ls)
.
In
Robert Altman (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000265/?ls)
's
Short Cuts (1993) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0108122/?ls)
, he appeared as an aspiring film make-up artist whose best friend commits murder. In
Oliver Stone (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000231/?ls)
's
Natural Born Killers (1994) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0110632/?ls)
, with
Woody Harrelson (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000437/?ls)
and
Juliette Lewis (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000496/?ls)
, Downey starred as a tabloid TV journalist who exploits a murderous couple's killing spree to boost his ratings. For the comedy
Heart and Souls (1993) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0107091/?ls)
, Downey starred as a young man with a special relationship with four ghosts. In 1995, Downey starred in
Restoration (1995) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0114272/?ls)
, with
Hugh Grant (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000424/?ls)
,
Meg Ryan (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000212/?ls)
and
Ian McKellen (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0005212/?ls)
, directed by
Michael Hoffman (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001355/?ls)
. Also that year, he starred in
Richard III (1995) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0114279/?ls)
, in which he appears opposite his
Restoration (1995) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0114272/?ls)
co-star McKellen.
In 1997, Downey was seen in
Robert Altman (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000265/?ls)
's
The Gingerbread Man (1998) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0119196/?ls)
, alongside
Kenneth Branagh (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000110/?ls)
,
Daryl Hannah (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000435/?ls)
and
Embeth Davidtz (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001110/?ls)
; in
One Night Stand (1997) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0119832/?ls)
, directed by
Mike Figgis (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001214/?ls)
and starring
Wesley Snipes (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000648/?ls)
and
Nastassja Kinski (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000176/?ls)
; and in
Hugo Pool (1997) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0119327/?ls)
, directed by his father,
Robert Downey Sr. (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0002049/?ls)
and starring
Sean Penn (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000576/?ls)
and
Patrick Dempsey (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001131/?ls)
. In September of 1999, Downey appeared in
Black & White (1999) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0165643/?ls)
, written and directed by
James Toback (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0864812/?ls)
, along with
Ben Stiller (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001774/?ls)
,
Elijah Wood (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000704/?ls)
,
Gaby Hoffmann (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000451/?ls)
,
Brooke Shields (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000222/?ls)
and
Claudia Schiffer (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000629/?ls)
. In January of 1999, he starred with
Annette Bening (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000906/?ls)
and
Aidan Quinn (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001644/?ls)
in
In Dreams (1999) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0120710/?ls)
, directed by
Neil Jordan (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001403/?ls)
.
In 2000, Downey co-starred with
Michael Douglas (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000140/?ls)
and
Tobey Maguire (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001497/?ls)
in
Wonder Boys (2000) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0185014/?ls)
, directed by
Curtis Hanson (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000436/?ls)
. In this dramatic comedy, Downey played the role of a bisexual literary agent. In 2001, Downey made his prime-time television debut when he joined the cast of the Fox-TV series
Ally McBeal (1997) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0118254/?ls)
as attorney "Larry Paul". For this role, he won the Golden Globe Award for Best Performance by an Actor in a Supporting Role in a Series, Mini-Series or Motion Picture Made for Television, as well as the Screen Actors Guild Award for Outstanding Performance by a Male in a Comedy Series. In addition, Downey was nominated for an Emmy for Outstanding Supporting Actor in a Comedy Series.
The actor's drug-related problems escalated from 1996 to 2001, leading to arrests, rehab visits and incarcerations, and he was eventually fired from
Ally McBeal (1997) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0118254/?ls)
. Emerging clean and sober in 2003, Downey Jr. began to rebuild his career.
He marked his debut into music with his debut album, titled "The Futurist", on the Sony Classics Label on November 23rd, 2004. The album's eight original songs, that Downey wrote, and his two musical numbers debuting as cover songs revealed his sultry singing voice and his musical talents. Downey displayed his versatility in two different films in October 2003: the musical/drama
The Singing Detective (2003) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0314676/?ls)
, a remake of the BBC hit of the same name, and the thriller
Gothika (2003) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0348836/?ls)
starring
Halle Berry (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000932/?ls)
and
Penélope Cruz (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0004851/?ls)
. Downey starred in powerful yet humbling roles inspired by real-life accounts of some of history's most precious kept secrets, including
Richard Linklater (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000500/?ls)
's
A Scanner Darkly (2006) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0405296/?ls)
in 2006 co-starring
Keanu Reeves (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000206/?ls)
,
Winona Ryder (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000213/?ls)
and
Woody Harrelson (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000437/?ls)
, and
Fur: An Imaginary Portrait of Diane Arbus (2006) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0422295/?ls)
co-starring
Nicole Kidman (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000173/?ls)
, a film inspired by the life of Diane Arbus, the revered photographer whose images captured attention in the early 1960s. These roles exhibited Downey's momentum from the previous year of 2005, in which he starred in the Academy Award®-nominated feature film
Good Night, and Good Luck. (2005) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0433383/?ls)
, directed by
George Clooney (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000123/?ls)
and in
Shane Black (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000948/?ls)
's action comedy
Kiss Kiss Bang Bang (2005) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0373469/?ls)
co-starring
Val Kilmer (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000174/?ls)
. In 2007, he co-starred in
David Fincher (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000399/?ls)
's suspenseful
Zodiac (2007) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0443706/?ls)
, alongside
Jake Gyllenhaal (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0350453/?ls)
and
Mark Ruffalo (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0749263/?ls)
, about the notorious serial killer who haunted San Francisco during the 1970s.
In May 2008, Downey achieved critical acclaim and worldwide box office success for his starring role in
Iron Man (2008) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0371746/?ls)
,
Jon Favreau (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0269463/?ls)
's big-screen rendering of the Marvel comic book superhero. The film co-starred
Gwyneth Paltrow (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000569/?ls)
,
Jeff Bridges (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000313/?ls)
and
Terrence Howard (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0005024/?ls)
. In August of 2008, Downey starred with
Ben Stiller (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001774/?ls)
and
Jack Black (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0085312/?ls)
in the comedy
Tropic Thunder (2008) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0942385/?ls)
, and went on to receive an Academy Award®-nomination for Best Supporting Actor for his, Kirk Lazarus.
In December 2009, Downey starred in the action-adventure
Sherlock Holmes (2009) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0988045/?ls)
. The film, directed by
Guy Ritchie (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0005363/?ls)
, co-starred
Jude Law (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000179/?ls)
and
Rachel McAdams (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm1046097/?ls)
and earned Downey a Golden Globe for Best Performance by an Actor in a Motion Picture - Comedy or Musical in January of 2010. In early Summer 2010, Downey re-teamed with director
Jon Favreau (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0269463/?ls)
and reprised his role as "Tony Stark/Iron Man" in the hugely successful sequel to the original film,
Iron Man 2 (2010) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1228705/?ls)
, starring
Gwyneth Paltrow (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000569/?ls)
,
Scarlett Johansson (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0424060/?ls)
,
Samuel L. Jackson (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000168/?ls)
and
Mickey Rourke (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000620/?ls)
.
Downey next starred in
Due Date (2010) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1231583/?ls)
, a comedy directed by
Todd Phillips (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0680846/?ls)
, in which he plays the role of an expectant father on a road trip racing to get back in time for the birth of his first child.
Due Date (2010) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1231583/?ls)
, starring
The Hangover (2009) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1119646/?ls)
's
Zach Galifianakis (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0302108/?ls)
, was released in November 2010.
Downey was honored by Time Magazine's "Time 100" in 2008, an annual list of the 100 most influential people in the world. His laurels include two Academy Award nominations, three Golden Globe wins, numerous other award nominations and wins, and tremendous popular and commercial success, particularly in his roles as Sherlock Holmes and Tony Stark (the latter of which he has so far played in
Iron Man (2008) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0371746/?ls)
,
Iron Man 2 (2010) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1228705/?ls)
,
The Avengers (2012) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0848228/?ls)
,
Iron Man 3 (2013) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1300854/?ls)
, and
Avengers: Age of Ultron (2015) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2395427/?ls)
. For three consecutive years, from 2012 to 2015, Downey has topped the Forbes list of Hollywood's highest-paid actors, making an estimated $80 million in earnings between June 2014 and June 2015.
In 2005, Downey Jr. married
Susan Downey (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm1206265/?ls)
, with whom he has two children. Downey also has another son,
Indio Falconer Downey (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm2003789/?ls)
, born 1993, from his first marriage to
Deborah Falconer (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0265999/?ls)
, from whom he was officially divorced in 2004.
Robert has jump-started the Team Downey Production Company with wife
Susan Downey (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm1206265/?ls)
.

7. Emma Watson (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0914612/?ref_=ls_t_7)
Actress
Director
Producer
The Perks of Being a Wallflower (2012) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1659337/?ref_=ls_knf_7)
Emma Charlotte Duerre Watson was born in Paris, France, to British parents, Jacqueline Luesby and Chris Watson, both lawyers. She moved to Oxfordshire when she was five, where she attended the Dragon School. The same year, she was diagnosed with ADHD and was put on Ritalin as she struggled to sit still. From the age of six, Emma knew that she wanted to be an actress and, for a number of years, she trained at the Oxford branch of Stagecoach Theatre Arts, a part-time theatre school where she studied singing, dancing and acting. By the age of ten, she had performed and taken the lead in various Stagecoach productions and school plays.
In 1999, casting began for Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone (2001), the film adaptation of British author J.K. Rowling's bestselling novel. Casting agents found Emma through her Oxford theatre teacher. After eight consistent auditions, producer David Heyman told Emma and fellow applicants,
Daniel Radcliffe (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0705356/?ls)
and
Rupert Grint (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0342488/?ls)
, that they had been cast for the roles of the three leads, Hermione Granger, Harry Potter and Ron Weasley. The release of
Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone (2001) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0241527/?ls)
was Emma's cinematic screen debut. The film broke records for opening-day sales and opening-weekend takings and was the highest-grossing film of 2001. Critics praised the film and the performances of the three leading young actors. The highly distributed British newspaper, 'The Daily Telegraph', called her performance "admirable". Later, Emma was nominated for five awards for her performance in the film, winning the Young Artist Award for Leading Young Actress in a Feature Film.
After the release of the first film of the highly successful franchise, Emma became one of the most well-known actresses in the world. She continued to play the role of Hermione Granger for nearly ten years, in all of the following Harry Potter films: Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone (2001),
Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (2002) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0295297/?ls)
,
Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (2004) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0304141/?ls)
,
Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (2005) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0330373/?ls)
,
Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (2007) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0373889/?ls)
,
Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (2009) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0417741/?ls)
,
Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 1 (2010) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0926084/?ls)
, and
Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 2 (2011) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1201607/?ls)
. Emma acquired two Critics' Choice Award nominations from the Broadcast Film Critics Association for her work in Harry Potter And The Prisoner Of Azkaban and Harry Potter And The Goblet Of Fire. The completion of the seventh and eight movies saw Emma receive nominations in 2011 for a Nickelodeon Kids' Choice Award, and for Best Actress at the Jameson Empire Awards. The Harry Potter franchise won the BAFTA for Outstanding British Contribution to Cinema in February 2011.
2011 saw Emma in Simon Curtis's
My Week with Marilyn (2011) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1655420/?ls)
, alongside a stellar cast of Oscar nominees including Michelle Williams as Marilyn Monroe and Kenneth Branagh as Sir Laurence Olivier, in addition to Eddie Redmayne, Dame Judi Dench, Dougray Scott, Zoe Wanamaker, Toby Jones and Dominic Cooper. Chronicling a week in
Marilyn Monroe (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000054/?ls)
's life, the film featured Emma in the supporting role of Lucy, a costume assistant to Colin Clark (Redmayne). The film was released by The Weinstein Company and was nominated for a Golden Globe for Best Motion Picture - Comedy or Musical. In 2012 Emma was seen in Stephen Chbosky's adaptation of his coming-of-age novel
The Perks of Being a Wallflower (2012) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1659337/?ls)
, starring opposite
Logan Lerman (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0503567/?ls)
and
Ezra Miller (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm3009232/?ls)
. This independent drama centered around Charlie (Lerman), an introverted freshman who is taken under the wings of two seniors (Watson and Miller) who welcome him to the real world. The film premiered at the 2012 Toronto International Film Festival and received rave reviews. The film won the People's Choice Award for Favourite Dramatic Movie and Emma also picked up the People's Choice Award for Favourite Dramatic Movie Actress. Emma was awarded a second time for this role with the Best Supporting Actress Award at the San Diego Film Critics Society Awards where the film also won the Best Ensemble Performance Award.
In summer 2013, Emma starred in
Sofia Coppola (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001068/?ls)
's American satirical black comedy crime film,
The Bling Ring (2013) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2132285/?ls)
, opposite
Katie Chang (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm4583512/?ls)
and
Israel Broussard (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm3441152/?ls)
. The film took inspiration from real events and followed a group of teenagers who, obsessed with fashion and fame, burgled the homes of celebrities in Los Angeles. The film opened the Un Certain Regard section of the 2013 Cannes Film Festival. Emma also appeared in a cameo role as herself in Seth Rogen's apocalypse comedy This Is The End (2013). The film tells the story about what happens to some of Hollywood's best loved celebrities when the apocalypse strikes during a party at James Franco's house.
In 2014, Emma was seen in Darren Aronofsky's
Noah (2014) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1959490/?ls)
, opposite
Russell Crowe (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000128/?ls)
,
Jennifer Connelly (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000124/?ls)
,
Ray Winstone (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0935653/?ls)
,
Douglas Booth (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm3150488/?ls)
,
Logan Lerman (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0503567/?ls)
, and
Anthony Hopkins (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000164/?ls)
. The film told the epic, biblical tale of Noah and the ark. Emma plays the role of Ila, a young woman who develops a close relationship with Noah's son, Shem (Booth). Noah made an outstanding $300m since its release in March. In 2015, Emma starred in
Regression (2015) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt3319920/?ls)
, written and directed by Alejandro Amenábar and Occultum Luciferus. Also headlined by Oscar-nominated Ethan Hawke, and set in Minnesota in 1990, Regression tells the story of Detective Bruce Kenner (Hawke), who investigates the case of young Angela, played by Emma, who accuses her father of sexual abuse.
In 2012, Emma was honored with the Calvin Klein Emerging Star Award at the ELLE Women in Hollywood Awards. In 2013, Emma was awarded the Trailblazer Award at the MTV Movie Awards in April and was honored with the GQ Woman of the Year Award at the GQ Awards in September. Further to her acting career, Emma is a Goodwill Ambassador for the UN, promoting gender equality and the empowerment of women. Emma graduated from Brown University in May 2014.
In 2017, Emma starred in the live-action Disney fantasy
Beauty and the Beast (2017) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2771200/?ls)
, one of the biggest movies of all time in the U.S., and the dramatic thriller
The Circle (2017) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt4287320/?ls)
.

8. Daniel Radcliffe (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0705356/?ref_=ls_t_8)
Actor
Producer
Soundtrack
Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 2 (2011) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1201607/?ref_=ls_knf_8)
Daniel Jacob Radcliffe was born on July 23, 1989 in Fulham, London, England, to casting agent
Marcia Gresham (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0340339/?ls)
(née Jacobson) and literary agent
Alan Radcliffe (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0705353/?ls)
. His father is from a
Northern Irish Protestant background, while his mother was born in
South Africa, to a Jewish family (from Lithuania, Poland, Russia, and
Germany). Daniel began performing in small school productions as a
young boy. Soon enough, he landed a role in
David Copperfield (1999) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0167872/?ls)
,
as the young David Copperfield. A couple of years later, he landed a
role as Mark Pendel in
The Tailor of Panama (2001) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0236784/?ls)
,
the son of Harry and Louisa Pendel
(
Geoffrey Rush (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001691/?ls)
and
Jamie Lee Curtis (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000130/?ls)
). Curtis had
indeed pointed out to Daniel's mother that he could be Harry Potter
himself. Soon afterwards, Daniel was cast as Harry Potter by director,
Chris Columbus (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001060/?ls)
in the film that hit
theaters in November 16, 2001,
Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone (2001) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0241527/?ls)
.
He was recognized worldwide after this film was released. Pleasing
audiences and critics everywhere, filming on its sequel,
Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (2002) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0295297/?ls)
,
commenced shortly afterwards. He appeared again as Harry in
Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (2004) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0304141/?ls)
directed by
Alfonso Cuarón (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0190859/?ls)
, and then
appeared in
Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (2005) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0330373/?ls)
directed by
Mike Newell (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001565/?ls)
. Shortly
afterwards, he finished filming
December Boys (2007) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0465436/?ls)
in Adelaide,
Australia, Kangaroo Island, and Geelong, Australia which began on the
14 November 2005 and ended sometime in December. On January 27,
2006, he attended the South Bank Awards Show to present the award for
"Breakthrough Artist of the Year" to
Billie Piper (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0684877/?ls)
. Daniel reprised his famous
character once again for the next installment of the Harry Potter
series,
Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (2007) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0373889/?ls)
.
In February 2007, he took on his first stage role in the West End play
Equus, to worldwide praise from fans and critics alike. Also that year,
he starred in the television movie
My Boy Jack (2007) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0851430/?ls)
, which
aired on 11 November 2007 in the UK.
After voicing a character in an episode of the animated television series The Simpsons in late 2010, Radcliffe debuted as J. Pierrepont Finch in the 2011 Broadway revival How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying, a role previously held by Broadway veterans Robert Morse and Matthew Broderick. Other cast members included John Larroquette, Rose Hemingway and Mary Faber. Both the actor and production received good reviews, with USA Today commenting: "Radcliffe ultimately succeeds not by overshadowing his fellow cast members, but by working in conscientious harmony with them - and having a blast in the process." Radcliffe's performance in the show earned him Drama Desk Award, Drama League Award and Outer Critics Circle Award nominations. The production itself later received nine Tony Award nominations. Radcliffe left the show on 1 January 2012. His first post-Harry Potter project was the 2012 horror film The Woman in Black, adapted from the 1983 novel by Susan Hill. The film was released on 3 February 2012 in the United States and Canada, and was released on 10 February in the UK. Radcliffe portrays a man sent to deal with the legal matters of a mysterious woman who has just died, and soon after he begins to experience strange events from the ghost of a woman dressed in black. He has said he was "incredibly excited" to be part of the film and described the script as "beautifully written".
In 2013, he portrayed American poet Allen Ginsberg in the thriller drama
Kill Your Darlings (2013) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1311071/?ls)
, directed by John Krokidas. He also starred in an Irish-Canadian romantic comedy film The F Word directed by Michael Dowseand written by Elan Mastai, based on TJ Dawe and Michael Rinaldi's play Toothpaste and Cigars and then he starred in an American dark fantasy horror film directed by Alexandre Aja Horns. Both of the films premiered at the 38th Toronto International Film Festival. Radcliffe also performed at the Noël Coward Theatre in the stage play revival of Martin McDonagh's dark comedy The Cripple of Inishmaan as the lead, Billy Claven, for which he won the WhatsOnStage Award for Best Actor in a Play. In 2015, Radcliffe starred as Igor in a science fiction horror film
Victor Frankenstein (2015) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1976009/?ls)
, directed by Paul McGuigan and written by Max Landis, which was based on contemporary adaptations of Mary Shelley's 1818 novel Frankenstein. In 2016, he appeared as a wealthy villain in the mystery/action film
Now You See Me 2 (2016) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt3110958/?ls)
, and as an oftentimes mobile corpse in the indie fantasy
Swiss Army Man (2016) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt4034354/?ls)
.
Now being one of the world's most recognizable people, Daniel leads a
somewhat normal life. He has made friends working on the Harry Potter
films, which include his co-stars
Rupert Grint (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0342488/?ls)
and
Emma Watson (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0914612/?ls)
.

9. Chris Evans (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0262635/?ref_=ls_t_9)
Actor
Producer
Director
The Avengers (2012) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0848228/?ref_=ls_knf_9)
Christopher Robert Evans is an American actor, film producer, and director. Evans began his acting career in typical fashion: performing in school productions and community theatre.
He was born in Boston, Massachusetts, the son of Lisa (Capuano), who worked at the Concord Youth Theatre, and G. Robert Evans III, a dentist. His uncle is former U.S. Representative
Mike Capuano (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm4576629/?ls)
. Chris's father is of half German and half Welsh/English/Scottish ancestry, while Chris's mother is of half Italian and half Irish descent. He has an older sister,
Carly Evans (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm2869049/?ls)
, and two younger siblings, a brother named
Scott Evans (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm3268924/?ls)
, who is also an actor, and a sister named
Shana Evans (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm4974640/?ls)
. The family moved to suburban Sudbury when he was 11 years-old. Bitten by the acting bug in the first grade because his older sister, Carly, started performing, Evans followed suit and began appearing in school plays. While at Lincoln-Sudbury Regional High School, his drama teacher cited his performance as "Leontes" in "The Winter's Tale" as exemplary of his skill. After more plays and regional theatre, he moved to New York and attended the
Lee Strasberg (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0833448/?ls)
Theatre Institute.
On the advice of friends, he landed an internship at a casting office and befriended a couple of the agents he regularly communicated with - one of whom later took him on as a client. The screen - not the stage - then became his focus; Evans soon began auditioning for feature films and television series. Evans made one of his first appearances on
The Fugitive (2000) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0247097/?ls)
(CBS, 2000-2001), a remake of the 1960s series and feature film starring
Harrison Ford (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000148/?ls)
. In the episode "Guilt", Evans played the son of a small-town sheriff who tries to exact revenge after Dr. Richard Kimble - incognito as a liquor store owner - refuses to sell him and his friends alcohol. After small roles in
Cherry Falls (1999) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0175526/?ls)
and
The Newcomers (2000) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0221431/?ls)
- two unknown low-budget features - Evans appeared in
Boston Public (2000) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0247081/?ls)
(Fox, 2000-2004) as a murder suspect. He then appeared in his first major feature,
Not Another Teen Movie (2001) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0277371/?ls)
, a spoof on teen comedies wherein he played a jock who makes a bet that he can turn an unpopular and unkempt girl (
Chyler Leigh (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0500200/?ls)
) into prom queen.
After filming a couple of television pilots he was confident would be successful -
Just Married (2003) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0305711/?ls)
and
Eastwick (2002) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0362585/?ls)
- he appeared in another listless teen comedy,
The Perfect Score (2004) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0314498/?ls)
, playing an average, ho-hum student who takes part in a plot to steal the SAT test. Hijinks naturally ensue. Then, Evans broke through to the Big Time, grabbing the lead in the kidnapping thriller,
Cellular (2004) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0337921/?ls)
, a suspenseful B movie with a cheesy gimmick - a random wrong number on his cell phone forces him into a high-stakes race to save an unknown woman's life. Despite an unassuming performance from Evans and
Kim Basinger (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000107/?ls)
as the damsel in distress,
Cellular (2004) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0337921/?ls)
failed to break any box office records or please a wide majority of critics. Evans then prepared himself for super stardom when he signed on to play Johnny Storm in
Fantastic Four (2005) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0120667/?ls)
, 20th Century Fox's long-awaited adaptation of the Marvel comic. Although the film was wildly uneven and disappointing, Evans nearly stole the show with his energetic, unfettered performance. In that year itself, Chris was noticed by critics and made it into magazine and Internet countdowns, scoring himself a third position of the hot body countdown from Gay.com and #18 on E! Television's 2006 101 Sexiest Celebrity Bodies.
The year 2007 also proved to be one successful year for Chris, as he had two movies released around the world that same year, starting with the second installment of the Marvel franchise Fantastic Four. Chris received positive reviews for his performance.
The Nanny Diaries (2007) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0489237/?ls)
, where Evans played Harvard Hottie, showed his sensitive. The year 2008 saw Chris Evans' part of the movie
Street Kings (2008) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0421073/?ls)
, playing the character Detective Paul Diskant. The movie is about police officers trying to cover up their wrongdoings and audiences got to see a serious side of Chris. In the same year, Chris also worked on the movie
The Loss of a Teardrop Diamond (2008) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0896031/?ls)
.

10. Brad Pitt (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000093/?ref_=ls_t_10)
Producer
Actor
Executive
Fight Club (1999) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0137523/?ref_=ls_knf_10)
William Bradley "Brad" Pitt was born on December 18, 1963 in Shawnee, Oklahoma and raised in Springfield, Missouri, the son of Jane Etta (Hillhouse), a school counselor, and William Alvin "Bill" Pitt, a truck company manager. At Kickapoo High School, he was involved in sports, debating, student government and school musicals. Pitt attended the University of Missouri, where he majored in journalism with a focus on advertising. He occasionally acted in fraternity shows. He left college two credits short of graduating to move to California. Before he became successful at acting, Pitt supported himself by driving strippers in limos, moving refrigerators and dressing as a giant chicken while working for El Pollo Loco.
Pitt's earliest credited roles were in television, starting on the daytime soap opera
Another World (1964) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0057731/?ls)
before appearing in the recurring role of Randy on the legendary prime time soap opera
Dallas (1978) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0077000/?ls)
. Following a string of guest appearances on various television series through the 1980s, Pitt gained widespread attention with a small part in
Thelma & Louise (1991) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0103074/?ls)
, in which he played a sexy criminal who romanced and conned
Geena Davis (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000133/?ls)
. This led to starring roles in badly received films such as
Johnny Suede (1991) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0104567/?ls)
&
Cool World (1992) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0104009/?ls)
.
But Pitt's career hit an upswing with his casting in
A River Runs Through It (1992) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0105265/?ls)
, which cemented his status as an multi-layered actor as opposed to just a pretty face. Pitt's subsequent projects were as quirky and varied in tone as his performances, ranging from his unforgettably comic cameo as stoner roommate Floyd in
True Romance (1993) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0108399/?ls)
to romantic roles in such visually lavish films as
Interview with the Vampire (1994) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0110148/?ls)
and
Legends of the Fall (1994) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0110322/?ls)
, to an emotionally tortured detective in the horror-thriller
Se7en (1995) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0114369/?ls)
. His portrayal of frenetic oddball Jeffrey Goines in
12 Monkeys (1995) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0114746/?ls)
won him a Globe for Best Performance by an Actor in a Supporting Role.
Pitt's portrayal of Achilles in the big-budget period drama
Troy (2004) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0332452/?ls)
helped establish his appeal as an action star and was closely followed by a co-starring role in the stylish spy-versus-spy flick
Mr. & Mrs. Smith (2005) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0356910/?ls)
. It was on the set of Mr. & Mrs. Smith that Pitt, who married
Jennifer Aniston (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000098/?ls)
in a highly publicized ceremony in 2000, met
Angelina Jolie (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001401/?ls)
. Pitt left Aniston for Jolie in 2005, a break-up that continues to fuel tabloid stories years after its occurrence.
He continues to wildly vary his film choices, appearing in everything from high-concept popcorn flicks such as
Megamind (2010) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1001526/?ls)
to adventurous critic-bait like
Inglourious Basterds (2009) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0361748/?ls)
and
The Tree of Life (2011) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0478304/?ls)
. He has received two Best Actor Oscar nominations, for
The Curious Case of Benjamin Button (2008) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0421715/?ls)
and
Moneyball (2011) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1210166/?ls)
. In 2014, he starred in the war film
Fury (2014) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2713180/?ls)
, opposite
Shia LaBeouf (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0479471/?ls)
,
Logan Lerman (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0503567/?ls)
,
Jon Bernthal (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm1256532/?ls)
, and
Michael Peña (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0671567/?ls)
.
Pitt and Jolie later separated. They have six children, three adopted and three biological.

11. Charles Chaplin (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000122/?ref_=ls_t_11)
Writer
Actor
Director
The Great Dictator (1940) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0032553/?ref_=ls_knf_11)
Considered to be one of the most pivotal stars of the early days of Hollywood, Charlie Chaplin lived an interesting life both in his films and behind the camera. He is most recognized as an icon of the silent film era, often associated with his popular character, the Little Tramp; the man with the toothbrush mustache, bowler hat, bamboo cane, and a funny walk.
Charles Spencer Chaplin was born in Walworth, London, England on April 16, 1889, to Hannah Harriet Pedlingham (Hill) and Charles Chaplin, both music hall performers, who were married on June 22, 1885. After Charles Sr. separated from Hannah to perform in New York City, Hannah then tried to resurrect her stage career. Unfortunately, her singing voice had a tendency to break at unexpected moments. When this happened, the stage manager spotted young Charlie standing in the wings and led him on stage, where five-year-old Charlie began to sing a popular tune. Charlie and his half-brother,
Syd Chaplin (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0152260/?ls)
spent their lives in and out of charity homes and workhouses between their mother's bouts of insanity. Hannah was committed to Cane Hill Asylum in May 1903 and lived there until 1921, when Chaplin moved her to California.
Chaplin began his official acting career at the age of eight, touring with the Eight Lancashire Lads. At age 18, he began touring with
Fred Karno (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0439833/?ls)
's vaudeville troupe, joining them on the troupe's 1910 United States tour. He traveled west to California in December 1913 and signed on with Keystone Studios' popular comedy director
Mack Sennett (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0784407/?ls)
, who had seen Chaplin perform on stage in New York. Charlie soon wrote his brother Syd, asking him to become his manager. While at Keystone, Chaplin appeared in and directed 35 films, starring as the Little Tramp in nearly all.
In November 1914, he left Keystone and signed on at Essanay, where he made 15 films. In 1916, he signed on at Mutual and made 12 films. In June 1917, Chaplin signed up with First National Studios, after which he built Chaplin Studios. In 1919, he and
Douglas Fairbanks (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001196/?ls)
,
Mary Pickford (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0681933/?ls)
and
D.W. Griffith (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000428/?ls)
formed United Artists (UA).
Chaplin's life and career was full of scandal and controversy. His first big scandal was during World War I, at which time his loyalty to England, his home country, was questioned. He had never applied for American citizenship, but claimed that he was a "paying visitor" to the United States. Many British citizens called Chaplin a coward and a slacker. This and other career eccentricities sparked suspicion with FBI chief
J. Edgar Hoover (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0393890/?ls)
and the House Un-American Activities Committee (HUAC), who believed that he was injecting Communist propaganda into his films. Chaplin's later film
The Great Dictator (1940) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0032553/?ls)
, which was his first "talkie", also created a stir. In the film, Chaplin plays a humorous caricature of
Adolf Hitler (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0386944/?ls)
. Some thought the film was poorly done and in bad taste. However, the film grossed over $5 million and earned five Academy Award Nominations.
Another scandal occurred when Chaplin briefly dated 22 year-old Joan Barry. However, Chaplin's relationship with Barry came to an end in 1942, after a series of harassing actions from her. In May 1943, Barry returned to inform Chaplin that she was pregnant and filed a paternity suit, claiming that the unborn child was his. During the 1944 trial, blood tests proved that Chaplin was not the father, but at the time, blood tests were inadmissible evidence, and he was ordered to pay $75 a week until the child turned 21.
Chaplin also was scrutinized for his support in aiding the Russian struggle against the invading Nazis during World War II, and the United States government questioned his moral and political views, suspecting him of having Communist ties. For this reason, HUAC subpoenaed him in 1947. However, HUAC finally decided that it was no longer necessary for him to appear for testimony. Conversely, when Chaplin and his family traveled to London for the premier of
Limelight (1952) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0044837/?ls)
, he was denied re-entry to the United States. In reality, the government had almost no evidence to prove that he was a threat to national security. Instead, he and his wife decided to settle in Switzerland.
Chaplin was married four times and had a total of 11 children. In 1918, he married
Mildred Harris (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0365121/?ls)
and they had a son together, Norman Spencer Chaplin, who lived only three days. Chaplin and Harris divorced in 1920. He married
Lita Grey (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0340614/?ls)
in 1924, who had two sons,
Charles Chaplin Jr. (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0152224/?ls)
and
Sydney Chaplin (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0152261/?ls)
. They were divorced in 1927. In 1936, Chaplin married
Paulette Goddard (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0002104/?ls)
, and his final marriage was to Oona O'Neill (
Oona Chaplin (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0152253/?ls)
), daughter of playwright
Eugene O'Neill (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0642156/?ls)
in 1943. Oona gave birth to eight children:
Geraldine Chaplin (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001036/?ls)
,
Michael Chaplin (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0152249/?ls)
,
Josephine Chaplin (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0152245/?ls)
,
Victoria Chaplin (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0152265/?ls)
, Eugene Chaplin, Jane Chaplin, Annette-Emilie Chaplin, and
Christopher Chaplin (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0152237/?ls)
.
In contrast to many of his boisterous characters, Chaplin was a quiet man who kept to himself a great deal. He also had an "un-millionaire" way of living. Even after he had accumulated millions, he continued to live in shabby accommodations. In 1921, Chaplin was decorated by the French government for his outstanding work as a filmmaker and was elevated to the rank of Officer of the Legion of Honor in 1952. In 1972, he was honored with an Academy Award for his "incalculable effect in making motion pictures the art form of the century". He was appointed Knight Commander of the Order of the British Empire in the 1975 New Year's Honours List. No formal reason for the honour was listed. The citation simply reads "Charles Spencer Chaplin, Film Actor and Producer".
Chaplin's other works included musical scores that he composed for many of his films. He also authored two autobiographical books, "My Autobiography" (1964) and its companion volume, "My Life in Pictures" (1974).
Chaplin died at age 88 of natural causes on December 25, 1977 at his home in Vevey, Switzerland. His funeral was a small and private Anglican ceremony according to his wishes. In 1978, Chaplin's corpse was stolen from its grave and was not recovered for three months; he was re-buried in a vault surrounded by cement.
Six of Chaplin's films have been selected for preservation in the National Film Registry by the United States Library of Congress: The Immigrant (1917),
The Kid (1921) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0012349/?ls)
,
The Gold Rush (1925) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0015864/?ls)
,
City Lights (1931) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0021749/?ls)
,
Modern Times (1936) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0027977/?ls)
, and
The Great Dictator (1940) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0032553/?ls)
.
Charlie Chaplin is considered one of the greatest filmmakers in the history of American cinema, whose movies were and still are popular throughout the world and have even gained notoriety as time progresses. His films show, through the Little Tramp's positive outlook on life in a world full of chaos, that the human spirit has and always will remain the same.
