12. Morgan Freeman (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000151/?ref_=ls_t_12)
Actor
Producer
Director
Se7en (1995) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0114369/?ref_=ls_knf_12)
With an authoritative voice and calm demeanor, this ever popular
American actor has grown into one of the most respected figures in
modern US cinema. Morgan was born on June 1, 1937 in Memphis, Tennessee,
to Mayme Edna (Revere), a teacher, and Morgan Porterfield Freeman, a
barber. The young Freeman attended Los Angeles City College before
serving several years in the US Air Force as a mechanic between 1955
and 1959. His first dramatic arts exposure was on the stage including
appearing in an all-African American production of the exuberant
musical Hello, Dolly!.
Throughout the 1970s, he continued his work on stage, winning Drama
Desk and Clarence Derwent Awards and receiving a Tony Award nomination
for his performance in The Mighty Gents in 1978. In 1980, he won two
Obie Awards, for his portrayal of Shakespearean anti-hero Coriolanus at
the New York Shakespeare Festival and for his work in Mother Courage
and Her Children. Freeman won another Obie in 1984 for his performance
as The Messenger in the acclaimed Brooklyn Academy of Music production
of
Lee Breuer (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0108031/?ls)
's The Gospel at Colonus and, in
1985, won the Drama-Logue Award for the same role. In 1987, Freeman
created the role of Hoke Coleburn in
Alfred Uhry (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0880261/?ls)
's Pulitzer Prize-winning play
Driving Miss Daisy, which brought him his fourth Obie Award. In 1990,
Freeman starred as Petruchio in the New York Shakespeare Festival's The
Taming of the Shrew, opposite
Tracey Ullman (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001808/?ls)
. Returning to the Broadway
stage in 2008, Freeman starred with
Frances McDormand (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000531/?ls)
and
Peter Gallagher (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001251/?ls)
in
Clifford Odets (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0644048/?ls)
' drama The Country Girl,
directed by
Mike Nichols (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001566/?ls)
.
Freeman first appeared on TV screens as several characters including
"Easy Reader", "Mel Mounds" and "Count Dracula" on the Children's
Television Workshop (now Sesame Workshop) show
The Electric Company (1971) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0066651/?ls)
.
He then moved into feature film with another children's adventure,
Who Says I Can't Ride a Rainbow! (1971) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0067982/?ls)
.
Next, there was a small role in the thriller
Blade (1973) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0069797/?ls)
; then he played Casca in
Julius Caesar (1979) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0079379/?ls)
and
the title role in
Coriolanus (1979) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0078999/?ls)
. Regular
work was coming in for the talented Freeman and he appeared in the
prison dramas
Attica (1980) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0080392/?ls)
and
Brubaker (1980) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0080474/?ls)
,
Eyewitness (1981) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0082353/?ls)
, and portrayed the
final 24 hours of slain Malcolm X in
Death of a Prophet (1981) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0179757/?ls)
.
For most of the 1980s, Freeman continued to contribute decent enough
performances in films that fluctuated in their quality. However, he
really stood out, scoring an Oscar nomination as a merciless hoodlum in
Street Smart (1987) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0094056/?ls)
and, then, he
dazzled audiences and pulled a second Oscar nomination in the film
version of
Driving Miss Daisy (1989) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0097239/?ls)
opposite
Jessica Tandy (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001788/?ls)
. The same year,
Freeman teamed up with youthful
Matthew Broderick (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000111/?ls)
and fiery
Denzel Washington (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000243/?ls)
in the epic Civil
War drama
Glory (1989) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0097441/?ls)
about freed slaves
being recruited to form the first all-African American fighting
brigade.
His star continued to rise, and the 1990s kicked off strongly with
roles in
The Bonfire of the Vanities (1990) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0099165/?ls)
,
Robin Hood: Prince of Thieves (1991) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0102798/?ls)
,
and
The Power of One (1992) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0105159/?ls)
.
Freeman's next role was as gunman Ned Logan, wooed out of retirement by
friend William Munny to avenge several prostitutes in the wild west
town of Big Whiskey in
Clint Eastwood (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000142/?ls)
's de-mythologized
western
Unforgiven (1992) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0105695/?ls)
. The film
was a sh and scored an acting Oscar for
Gene Hackman (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000432/?ls)
, a directing Oscar for
Eastwood, and the Oscar for best picture. In 1993, Freeman made his
directorial debut on
Bopha! (1993) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0106464/?ls)
and
soon after formed his production company, Revelations Entertainment.
More strong scripts came in, and Freeman was back behind bars depicting
a knowledgeable inmate (and obtaining his third Oscar nomination),
befriending falsely accused banker
Tim Robbins (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000209/?ls)
in
The Shawshank Redemption (1994) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0111161/?ls)
.
He was then back out hunting a religious serial killer in
Se7en (1995) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0114369/?ls)
, starred alongside
Keanu Reeves (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000206/?ls)
in
Chain Reaction (1996) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0115857/?ls)
, and was
pursuing another serial murderer in
Kiss the Girls (1997) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0119468/?ls)
.
Further praise followed for his role in the slave tale of
Amistad (1997) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0118607/?ls)
, he was a worried US
President facing Armageddon from above in
Deep Impact (1998) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0120647/?ls)
, appeared in
Neil LaBute (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001438/?ls)
's black comedy
Nurse Betty (2000) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0171580/?ls)
, and reprised his
role as Alex Cross in
Along Came a Spider (2001) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0164334/?ls)
.
Now highly popular, he was much in demand with cinema audiences, and he
co-starred in the terrorist drama
The Sum of All Fears (2002) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0164184/?ls)
,
was a military officer in the
Stephen King (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000175/?ls)
-inspired
Dreamcatcher (2003) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0285531/?ls)
, gave divine
guidance as God to
Jim Carrey (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000120/?ls)
in
Bruce Almighty (2003) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0315327/?ls)
, and played
a minor role in the comedy
The Big Bounce (2004) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0315824/?ls)
.
2005 was a huge year for Freeman. First, he he teamed up with good
friend
Clint Eastwood (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000142/?ls)
to appear
in the drama,
Million Dollar Baby (2004) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0405159/?ls)
.
Freeman's on-screen performance is simply world-class as ex-prize
fighter Eddie "Scrap Iron" Dupris, who works in a run-down boxing gym
alongside grizzled trainer Frankie Dunn, as the two work together to
hone the skills of never-say-die female boxer
Hilary Swank (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0005476/?ls)
. Freeman received his fourth
Oscar nomination and, finally, impressed the Academy's judges enough to
win the Best Supporting Actor Oscar for his performance. He also
narrated
Steven Spielberg (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000229/?ls)
's
War of the Worlds (2005) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0407304/?ls)
and
appeared in
Batman Begins (2005) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0372784/?ls)
as
Lucius Fox, a valuable ally of
Christian Bale (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000288/?ls)
's Bruce Wayne/Batman for
director
Christopher Nolan (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0634240/?ls)
.
Freeman would reprise his role in the two sequels of the
record-breaking, genre-redefining trilogy.
Roles in tentpoles and indies followed; highlights include his role as
a crime boss in
Lucky Number Slevin (2006) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0425210/?ls)
, a
second go-round as God in
Evan Almighty (2007) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0413099/?ls)
with
Steve Carell (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0136797/?ls)
taking over for
Jim Carrey (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000120/?ls)
, and a supporting role in
Ben Affleck (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000255/?ls)
's directorial debut,
Gone Baby Gone (2007) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0452623/?ls)
. He
co-starred with
Jack Nicholson (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000197/?ls)
in
the breakout hit
The Bucket List (2007) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0825232/?ls)
in 2007,
and followed that up with another box-office success,
Wanted (2008) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0493464/?ls)
, then segued into the second
Batman film,
The Dark Knight (2008) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0468569/?ls)
.
In 2009, he reunited with Eastwood to star in the director's true-life
drama
Invictus (2009) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1057500/?ls)
, on which Freeman
also served as an executive producer. For his portrayal of
Nelson Mandela (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0541691/?ls)
in the film, Freeman
garnered Oscar, Golden Globe and Critics' Choice Award nominations, and
won the National Board of Review Award for Best Actor.
Recently, Freeman appeared in
Red (2010) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1245526/?ls)
, a
surprise box-office hit; he narrated the
Conan the Barbarian (2011) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0816462/?ls)
remake, starred in
Rob Reiner (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001661/?ls)
's
The Magic of Belle Isle (2012) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1839654/?ls)
;
and capped the Batman trilogy with
The Dark Knight Rises (2012) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1345836/?ls)
.
Freeman has several films upcoming, including the thriller
Now You See Me (2013) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1670345/?ls)
, under
the direction of
Louis Leterrier (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0504642/?ls)
, and
the science fiction actioner
Oblivion (2013) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1483013/?ls)
, in which he stars
with
Tom Cruise (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000129/?ls)
.

13. Tom Hanks (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000158/?ref_=ls_t_13)
Producer
Actor
Writer
Cast Away (2000) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0162222/?ref_=ls_knf_13)
Thomas Jeffrey Hanks was born in Concord, California, to Janet Marylyn (Frager), a hospital worker, and Amos Mefford Hanks, an itinerant cook. His mother's family, originally surnamed "Fraga", was entirely Portuguese, while his father was of mostly English ancestry. Tom grew up in what he has called a "fractured" family. He moved around a great deal after his parents' divorce, living with a succession of step-families. No problems, no alcoholism - just a confused childhood. He has no acting experience in college and credits the fact that he could not get cast in a college play with actually starting his career. He went downtown, and auditioned for a community theater play, was invited by the director of that play to go to Cleveland, and there his acting career started.
Ron Howard (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000165/?ls)
was working on
Splash (1984) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0088161/?ls)
, a fantasy-comedy about a mermaid who falls in love with a business executive. Howard considered Hanks for the role of the main character's wisecracking brother, which eventually went to
John Candy (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001006/?ls)
. Instead, Hanks landed the lead role and the film went on to become a surprise box office success, grossing more than $69 million. After several flops and a moderate success with the comedy
Dragnet (1987) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0092925/?ls)
, Hanks' stature in the film industry rose. The broad success with the fantasy-comedy
Big (1988) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0094737/?ls)
established him as a major Hollywood talent, both as a box office draw and within the film industry as an actor. For his performance in the film, Hanks earned his first Academy Award nomination as Best Actor.
Hanks climbed back to the top again with his portrayal of a washed-up baseball legend turned manager in
A League of Their Own (1992) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0104694/?ls)
. Hanks has stated that his acting in earlier roles was not great, but that he subsequently improved. In an interview with Vanity Fair, Hanks noted his "modern era of movie making ... because enough self-discovery has gone on ... My work has become less pretentiously fake and over the top". This "modern era" began for Hanks, first with
Sleepless in Seattle (1993) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0108160/?ls)
and then with
Philadelphia (1993) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0107818/?ls)
. The former was a blockbuster success about a widower who finds true love over the radio airwaves. Richard Schickel of Time magazine called his performance "charming", and most critics agreed that Hanks' portrayal ensured him a place among the premier romantic-comedy stars of his generation.
In Philadelphia, he played a gay lawyer with AIDS who sues his firm for discrimination. Hanks lost 35 pounds and thinned his hair in order to appear sickly for the role. In a review for People, Leah Rozen stated, "Above all, credit for Philadelphia's success belongs to Hanks, who makes sure that he plays a character, not a saint. He is flat-out terrific, giving a deeply felt, carefully nuanced performance that deserves an Oscar." Hanks won the 1993 Academy Award for Best Actor for his role in Philadelphia. During his acceptance speech, he revealed that his high school drama teacher Rawley Farnsworth and former classmate John Gilkerson, two people with whom he was close, were gay.
Hanks followed Philadelphia with the blockbuster
Forrest Gump (1994) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0109830/?ls)
which grossed a worldwide total of over $600 million at the box office. Hanks remarked: "When I read the script for Gump, I saw it as one of those kind of grand, hopeful movies that the audience can go to and feel ... some hope for their lot and their position in life ... I got that from the movies a hundred million times when I was a kid. I still do." Hanks won his second Best Actor Academy Award for his role in Forrest Gump, becoming only the second actor to have accomplished the feat of winning consecutive Best Actor Oscars.
Hanks' next role - astronaut and commander Jim Lovell, in the docudrama
Apollo 13 (1995) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0112384/?ls)
- reunited him with Ron Howard. Critics generally applauded the film and the performances of the entire cast, which included actors Kevin Bacon, Bill Paxton, Gary Sinise, Ed Harris, and Kathleen Quinlan. The movie also earned nine Academy Award nominations, winning two. Later that year, Hanks starred in Disney/Pixar's computer-animated film
Toy Story (1995) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0114709/?ls)
, as the voice of Sheriff Woody. A year later, he made his directing debut with the musical comedy
That Thing You Do! (1996) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0117887/?ls)
about the rise and fall of a 1960s pop group, also playing the role of a music producer.
As of 2022, Hanks is 66-years-old. He has never retired from acting, and has remained active in the film industry for more than four decades.

14. Hugh Jackman (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0413168/?ref_=ls_t_14)
Actor
Producer
Executive
Les Misérables (2012) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1707386/?ref_=ls_knf_14)
Hugh Michael Jackman is an Australian actor, singer, multi-instrumentalist, dancer and producer. Jackman has won international recognition for his roles in major films, notably as superhero, period, and romance characters. He is best known for his long-running role as Wolverine in the X-Men film series, as well as for his lead roles in the romantic-comedy fantasy Kate & Leopold (2001), the action-horror film Van Helsing (2004), the drama The Prestige and The Fountain (2006), the epic historical romantic drama Australia (2008), the film version of Les Misérables (2012), and the thriller Prisoners (2013). His work in Les Misérables earned him his first Academy Award nomination for Best Actor and his first Golden Globe Award for Best Actor - Motion Picture Musical or Comedy in 2013. In Broadway theatre, Jackman won a Tony Award for his role in The Boy from Oz. A four-time host of the Tony Awards themselves, he won an Emmy Award for one of these appearances. Jackman also hosted the 81st Academy Awards on 22 February 2009.
Jackman was born in Sydney, New South Wales, to Grace McNeil (Greenwood) and Christopher John Jackman, an accountant. He is the youngest of five children. His parents, both English, moved to Australia shortly before his birth. He also has Greek (from a great-grandfather) and Scottish (from a grandmother) ancestry.
Jackman has a communications degree with a journalism major from the University of Technology Sydney. After graduating, he pursued drama at the Western Australian Academy of Performing Arts, immediately after which he was offered a starring role in the ABC-TV prison drama
Correlli (1995) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0111927/?ls)
, opposite his future wife
Deborra-Lee Furness (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0299028/?ls)
. Several TV guest roles followed, as an actor and variety compere. An accomplished singer, Jackman has starred as Gaston in the Australian production of "Beauty and the Beast." He appeared as Joe Gillis in the Australian production of "Sunset Boulevard." In 1998, he was cast as Curly in the Royal National Theatre's production of
Trevor Nunn (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0638080/?ls)
's Oklahoma. Jackman has made two feature films, the second of which,
Erskineville Kings (1999) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0212936/?ls)
, garnered him an Australian Film Institute nomination for Best Actor in 1999. Recently, he won the part of Logan/Wolverine in the
Bryan Singer (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001741/?ls)
- directed comic-book movie
X-Men (2000) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0120903/?ls)
. In his spare time, Jackman plays piano, golf, and guitar, and likes to windsurf.

15. Matt Damon (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000354/?ref_=ls_t_15)
Producer
Actor
Writer
Good Will Hunting (1997) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0119217/?ref_=ls_knf_15)
Matthew Paige Damon was born on October 8, 1970, in Boston, Massachusetts, to
Kent Damon (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm1497320/?ls)
, a stockbroker, realtor and tax preparer, and
Nancy Carlsson-Paige (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm1497472/?ls)
, an early childhood education professor at Lesley University. Matt has an older brother, Kyle, a sculptor. His father was of English and Scottish descent, and his mother is of Finnish and Swedish ancestry. The family lived in Newton until his parents divorced in 1973, when Damon and his brother moved with his mother to Cambridge. He grew up in a stable community, and was raised near actor
Ben Affleck (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000255/?ls)
.
Damon attended Cambridge Rindge and Latin School and he performed in a number of theater productions during his time there. He attended Harvard University as an English major. While in Harvard, he kept on skipping classes to pursue acting projects, which included the TNT original film,
Rising Son (1990) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0100497/?ls)
, and prep-school drama,
School Ties (1992) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0105327/?ls)
. It was until his film,
Geronimo: An American Legend (1993) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0107004/?ls)
, was expected to be a big success that he decided to drop out of university completely. Arriving in Hollywood, Matt managed to get his first break with a part in the romantic comedy,
Mystic Pizza (1988) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0095690/?ls)
. However, the film did not do too well and his film career failed to take off. Not letting failure discourage him from acting, he went for another audition, and managed to get a starring role in
School Ties (1992) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0105327/?ls)
. Up next for Matt was a role as a soldier who had problems with drug-addiction in the movie,
Courage Under Fire (1996) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0115956/?ls)
. Matt had, in fact, lost forty pounds for his role which resulted in health problems.
The following year, he garnered accolades for
Good Will Hunting (1997) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0119217/?ls)
, a screenplay he had originally written for an English class at Harvard University.
Good Will Hunting (1997) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0119217/?ls)
was nominated for 9 Academy Awards, one of which, Matt won for Best Original Screenplay along with
Ben Affleck (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000255/?ls)
. In the year 1998, Matt played the title role in
Steven Spielberg (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000229/?ls)
's film,
Saving Private Ryan (1998) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0120815/?ls)
, which was one of the most acclaimed films in that year. Matt had the opportunity of working with
Tom Hanks (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000158/?ls)
and
Vin Diesel (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0004874/?ls)
while filming that movie. That same year, he starred as an earnest law student and reformed poker player in
Rounders (1998) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0128442/?ls)
, starring opposite
Edward Norton (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001570/?ls)
and
John Malkovich (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000518/?ls)
. The next year, Matt rejoined his childhood friend,
Ben Affleck (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000255/?ls)
and fellow comedian,
Chris Rock (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001674/?ls)
, in the comedy
Dogma (1999) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0120655/?ls)
.
Towards the end of 1999, Matt played "Tom Ripley", a working-class young man who tastes the good life and will do anything to live it. Both
Jude Law (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000179/?ls)
and
Gwyneth Paltrow (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000569/?ls)
also starred in the movie.
The Talented Mr. Ripley (1999) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0134119/?ls)
earned mixed reviews from critics, but even so, Matt earned praise for his performance. Matt lent his voice to the animated movie,
Titan A.E. (2000) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0120913/?ls)
in the year 2000, which also earned mixed reviews from the public. He also starred in two other movies,
All the Pretty Horses (2000) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0149624/?ls)
and the golf comedy-drama,
The Legend of Bagger Vance (2000) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0146984/?ls)
, starring alongside
Will Smith (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000226/?ls)
. In the year 2003, he signed on to star in
The Informant! (2009) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1130080/?ls)
by
Steven Soderbergh (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001752/?ls)
and the Farrelly Brothers'
Stuck on You (2003) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0338466/?ls)
. He also starred in
Gerry (2002) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0302674/?ls)
, a film he co-wrote with his friends,
Gus Van Sant (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001814/?ls)
and
Casey Affleck (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000729/?ls)
. One of Matt's most recognizable work to date is his role in the "Bourne" movie franchise. He plays an amnesiac assassin, "Jason Bourne", in
The Bourne Identity (2002) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0258463/?ls)
,
The Bourne Supremacy (2004) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0372183/?ls)
and
The Bourne Ultimatum (2007) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0440963/?ls)
. Another praised role is that as "Linus Caldwell" in the "Ocean's" movie franchise. He had the opportunity to star opposite
George Clooney (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000123/?ls)
,
Brad Pitt (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000093/?ls)
,
Julia Roberts (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000210/?ls)
and
Don Cheadle (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000332/?ls)
in
Ocean's Eleven (2001) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0240772/?ls)
. The successful crime comedy-drama eventually had two other sequels,
Ocean's Twelve (2004) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0349903/?ls)
and
Ocean's Thirteen (2007) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0496806/?ls)
. Among other highly acclaimed movies that Matt has been a part of are
Terry Gilliam (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000416/?ls)
's
The Brothers Grimm (2005) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0355295/?ls)
,
George Clooney (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000123/?ls)
's
Syriana (2005) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0365737/?ls)
,
Martin Scorsese (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000217/?ls)
's
The Departed (2006) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0407887/?ls)
and
Robert De Niro (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000134/?ls)
's
The Good Shepherd (2006) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0343737/?ls)
.
In his personal life, Matt is now happily married to Argentine-born
Luciana Damon (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm3180094/?ls)
, whom he met in Miami, where she was working as a bartender. They married in a private civil ceremony on December 9, 2005, at the Manhattan Marriage Bureau. The couple have four daughters Alexia, Luciana's daughter from a previous relationship, as well as Isabella, Gia and Stella. Matt is a big fan of the Boston Red Sox and he tries to attend their games whenever possible. He has also formed great friendships with his Ocean's co-stars,
George Clooney (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000123/?ls)
and
Brad Pitt (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000093/?ls)
, whom he works on charity projects with. He and actor
Ben Affleck (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000255/?ls)
have remained lifelong friends and collaborators.

16. Sylvester Stallone (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000230/?ref_=ls_t_16)
Actor
Producer
Writer
Rocky (1976) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0075148/?ref_=ls_knf_16)
Sylvester Stallone is an athletically built, dark-haired American actor/screenwriter/director/producer, the movie fans worldwide have been flocking to see Stallone's films for over 40 years, making "Sly" one of Hollywood's biggest-ever box office draws.
Sylvester Stallone was born on July 6, 1946, in New York's gritty
Hell's Kitchen, to
Jackie Stallone (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0821736/?ls)
(née
Labofish), an astrologer, and
Frank Stallone (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm2200613/?ls)
, a beautician
and hairdresser. His father was an Italian immigrant, and his mother's
heritage is half French (from Brittany) and half German. The
young Stallone attended the American College of Switzerland and
The University of Miami, eventually obtaining a B.A. degree. Initially, he
struggled in small parts in films such as the soft-core
The Party at Kitty and Stud's (1970) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0065904/?ls)
,
the thriller
Klute (1971) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0067309/?ls)
and the comedy
Bananas (1971) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0066808/?ls)
. He got a crucial career
break alongside fellow young actor
Henry Winkler (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001857/?ls)
, sharing lead billing in the
effectively written teen gang film
The Lords of Flatbush (1974) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0071772/?ls)
.
Further film and television roles followed, most of them in uninspiring
productions except for the opportunity to play a megalomaniac,
bloodthirsty race driver named "Machine Gun Joe Viterbo" in the
Roger Corman (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000339/?ls)
-produced
Death Race 2000 (1975) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0072856/?ls)
. However,
Stallone was also keen to be recognized as a screenwriter, not just an
actor, and, inspired by the 1975 Muhammad Ali-Chuck Wepner fight in
Cleveland, Stallone wrote a film script about a nobody fighter given
the "million to one opportunity" to challenge for the heavyweight
title.
Rocky (1976) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0075148/?ls)
became the stuff of
cinematic legends, scoring ten Academy Award nominations, winning the
Best Picture Award of 1976 and triggering one of the most financially
successful movie series in history! Whilst full credit is wholly
deserved by Stallone, he was duly supported by tremendous acting from
fellow cast members
Talia Shire (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001735/?ls)
,
Burgess Meredith (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0580565/?ls)
and
Burt Young (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0949350/?ls)
, and director
John G. Avildsen (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000814/?ls)
gave the film an
emotive, earthy appeal from start to finish. Stallone had truly arrived
on his terms, and offers poured in from various studios eager to secure
Hollywood's hottest new star.
Stallone followed
Rocky (1976) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0075148/?ls)
with
F.I.S.T. (1978) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0077531/?ls)
, loosely based on the life
of Teamsters boss "Jimmy Hoffa", and
Paradise Alley (1978) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0078056/?ls)
before
pulling on the boxing gloves again to resurrect Rocky Balboa in the
sequel
Rocky II (1979) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0079817/?ls)
. The second
outing for the "Italian Stallion" wasn't as powerful or successful as
the first "Rocky", however, it still produced strong box office.
Subsequent films
Nighthawks (1981) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0082817/?ls)
and
Victory (1981) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0083284/?ls)
failed to ignite with
audiences, so Stallone was once again lured back to familiar territory
with
Rocky III (1982) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0084602/?ls)
and a fearsome
opponent in "Clubber Lang" played by muscular ex-bodyguard
Mr. T (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001558/?ls)
. The third "Rocky" installment far
outperformed the first sequel in box office takings, but Stallone
retired his prizefighter for a couple of years as another
series was about to commence for the busy actor.
The character of Green Beret "John Rambo" was the creation of
Canadian-born writer
David Morrell (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0606251/?ls)
, and his novel was
adapted to the screen with Stallone in the lead role in
First Blood (1982) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0083944/?ls)
, also starring
Richard Crenna (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001077/?ls)
and
Brian Dennehy (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001133/?ls)
. The movie was a surprise
hit that polarized audiences because of its commentary about the
Vietnam war, which was still relatively fresh in the American public's
psyche. Political viewpoints aside, the film was a worldwide smash, and
a sequel soon followed with
Rambo: First Blood Part II (1985) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0089880/?ls)
,
which drew even stronger criticism from several quarters owing to the
film's plot line about American MIAs allegedly being held in Vietnam.
But they say there is no such thing as bad publicity, and "John
Rambo's" second adventure was a major money spinner for Stallone and
cemented him as one of the top male stars of the 1980s. Riding a wave
of amazing popularity, Stallone called on old sparring partner Rocky
Balboa to climb back into the ring to defend American pride against a
Soviet threat in the form of a towering Russian boxer named "Ivan
Drago" played by curt
Dolph Lundgren (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000185/?ls)
in
Rocky IV (1985) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0089927/?ls)
. The fourth outing was
somewhat controversial with "Rocky" fans, as violence levels seemed
excessive compared to previous "Rocky" films, especially with the
savage beating suffered by Apollo Creed, played by
Carl Weathers (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001835/?ls)
, at the hands of the
unstoppable "Siberian Express".
Stallone continued forward with a slew of macho character-themed films
that met with a mixed reception from his fans.
Cobra (1986) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0090859/?ls)
was a clumsy mess,
Over the Top (1987) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0093692/?ls)
was equally
mediocre,
Rambo III (1988) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0095956/?ls)
saw Rambo
take on the Russians in Afghanistan, and cop buddy film
Tango & Cash (1989) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0098439/?ls)
just did not
quite hit the mark, although it did feature a top-notch cast and there
was chemistry between Stallone and co-star
Kurt Russell (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000621/?ls)
.
Philadelphia's favorite mythical boxer moved out of the shadows for his
fifth screen outing in
Rocky V (1990) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0100507/?ls)
tackling Tommy "Machine" Gunn played by real-life heavyweight fighter
Tommy Morrison (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0607338/?ls)
, the great-nephew
of screen legend
John Wayne (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000078/?ls)
. Sly
quickly followed with the lukewarm comedy
Oscar (1991) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0102603/?ls)
, the painfully unfunny
Stop! Or My Mom Will Shoot (1992) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0105477/?ls)
,
the futuristic action film
Demolition Man (1993) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0106697/?ls)
, and the
comic book-inspired
Judge Dredd (1995) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0113492/?ls)
. Interestingly,
Stallone then took a departure from the gung-ho steely characters he
had been portraying to stack on a few extra pounds and tackle a more
dramatically challenging role in the intriguing
Cop Land (1997) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0118887/?ls)
, also starring
Robert De Niro (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000134/?ls)
and
Ray Liotta (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000501/?ls)
. It isn't a classic of the genre,
but
Cop Land (1997) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0118887/?ls)
certainly surprised
many critics with Stallone's understated performance. Stallone then
lent his vocal talents to the animated adventure story
Antz (1998) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0120587/?ls)
, reprised the role made famous
by
Michael Caine (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000323/?ls)
in a terrible
remake of
Get Carter (2000) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0208988/?ls)
, climbed
back into a race car for
Driven (2001) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0132245/?ls)
,
and guest-starred as the "Toymaker" in the third chapter of the
immensely popular "Spy Kids" film series,
Spy Kids 3: Game Over (2003) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0338459/?ls)
.
Showing that age had not wearied his two most popular series,
Stallone has most recently brought back never-say-die boxer Rocky
Balboa to star in, well, what else but
Rocky Balboa (2006) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0479143/?ls)
, and Vietnam
veteran
Rambo (2008) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0462499/?ls)
will reappear after a
20-year hiatus to once again right wrongs in the jungles of Thailand.
Love him or loathe him, Sylvester Stallone has built an enviable and
highly respected career in Hollywood, plus, he has considerably
influenced modern popular culture through several of his iconic film
characters.
