17. Will Smith (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000226/?ref_=ls_t_17)
Producer
Actor
Writer
The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air (1995–1996) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0098800/?ref_=ls_knf_17)
Willard Carroll "Will" Smith II (born September 25, 1968) is an American actor, comedian, producer, rapper, and songwriter. He has enjoyed success in television, film, and music. In April 2007, Newsweek called him "the most powerful actor in Hollywood". Smith has been nominated for five Golden Globe Awards, two Academy Awards, and has won four Grammy Awards.
In the late 1980s, Smith achieved modest fame as a rapper under the name The Fresh Prince. In 1990, his popularity increased dramatically when he starred in the popular television series The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air. The show ran for six seasons (1990-96) on NBC and has been syndicated consistently on various networks since then. After the series ended, Smith moved from television to film, and ultimately starred in numerous blockbuster films. He is the only actor to have eight consecutive films gross over $100 million in the domestic box office, eleven consecutive films gross over $150 million internationally, and eight consecutive films in which he starred open at the number one spot in the domestic box office tally.
Smith is ranked as the most bankable star worldwide by Forbes. As of 2014, 17 of the 21 films in which he has had leading roles have accumulated worldwide gross earnings of over $100 million each, five taking in over $500 million each in global box office receipts. As of 2014, his films have grossed $6.6 billion at the global box office. He has received Best Actor Oscar nominations for Ali and The Pursuit of Happyness.
Smith was born in West Philadelphia, the son of Caroline (Bright), a Philadelphia school board administrator, and Willard Carroll Smith, Sr., a refrigeration engineer. He grew up in West Philadelphia's Wynnefield neighborhood, and was raised Baptist. He has three siblings, sister Pamela, who is four years older, and twins Harry and Ellen, who are three years younger. Smith attended Our Lady of Lourdes, a private Catholic elementary school in Philadelphia. His parents separated when he was 13, but did not actually divorce until around 2000.
Smith attended Overbrook High School. Though widely reported, it is untrue that Smith turned down a scholarship to attend the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT); he never applied to college because he "wanted to rap." Smith says he was admitted to a "pre-engineering [summer] program" at MIT for high school students, but he did not attend. According to Smith, "My mother, who worked for the School Board of Philadelphia, had a friend who was the admissions officer at MIT. I had pretty high SAT scores and they needed black kids, so I probably could have gotten in. But I had no intention of going to college."
Smith started as the MC of the hip-hop duo DJ Jazzy Jeff & The Fresh Prince, with his childhood friend Jeffrey "DJ Jazzy Jeff" Townes as producer, as well as Ready Rock C (Clarence Holmes) as the human beat box. The trio was known for performing humorous, radio-friendly songs, most notably "Parents Just Don't Understand" and "Summertime". They gained critical acclaim and won the first Grammy awarded in the Rap category (1988).
Smith spent money freely around 1988 and 1989 and underpaid his income taxes. The Internal Revenue Service eventually assessed a $2.8 million tax debt against Smith, took many of his possessions, and garnished his income. Smith was nearly bankrupt in 1990, when the NBC television network signed him to a contract and built a sitcom, The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air, around him.
The show was successful and began his acting career. Smith set for himself the goal of becoming "the biggest movie star in the world", studying box office successes' common characteristics.
Smith's first major roles were in the drama Six Degrees of Separation (1993) and the action film Bad Boys (1995) in which he starred opposite Martin Lawrence.
In 1996, Smith starred as part of an ensemble cast in Roland Emmerich's Independence Day. The film was a massive blockbuster, becoming the second highest grossing film in history at the time and establishing Smith as a prime box office draw. He later struck gold again in the summer of 1997 alongside Tommy Lee Jones in the summer hit Men in Black playing Agent J. In 1998, Smith starred with Gene Hackman in Enemy of the State.
He turned down the role of Neo in The Matrix in favor of Wild Wild West (1999). Despite the disappointment of Wild Wild West, Smith has said that he harbors no regrets about his decision, asserting that Keanu Reeves's performance as Neo was superior to what Smith himself would have achieved, although in interviews subsequent to the release of Wild Wild West he stated that he "made a mistake on Wild Wild West. That could have been better."
In 2005, Smith was entered into the Guinness Book of World Records for attending three premieres in a 24-hour time span.
He has planned to star in a feature film remake of the television series It Takes a Thief.
On December 10, 2007, Smith was honored at Grauman's Chinese Theatre on Hollywood Boulevard. Smith left an imprint of his hands and feet outside the world-renowned theater in front of many fans. Later that month, Smith starred in the film I Am Legend, released December 14, 2007. Despite marginally positive reviews, its opening was the largest ever for a film released in the United States during December. Smith himself has said that he considers the film to be "aggressively unique". A reviewer said that the film's commercial success "cemented [Smith's] standing as the number one box office draw in Hollywood." On December 1, 2008, TV Guide reported that Smith was selected as one of America's top ten most fascinating people of 2008 for a Barbara Walters ABC special that aired on December 4, 2008.
In 2008 Smith was reported to be developing a film entitled The Last Pharaoh, in which he would be starring as Taharqa. It was in 2008 that Smith starred in the superhero movie Hancock.
Men in Black III opened on May 25, 2012 with Smith again reprising his role as Agent J. This was his first major starring role in four years.
On August 19, 2011, it was announced that Smith had returned to the studio with producer La Mar Edwards to work on his fifth studio album. Edwards has worked with artists such as T.I., Chris Brown, and Game. Smith's most recent studio album, Lost and Found, was released in 2005.
Smith and his son Jaden played father and son in two productions: the 2006 biographical drama The Pursuit of Happyness, and the science fiction film After Earth, which was released on May 31, 2013.
Smith starred opposite Margot Robbie in the romance drama Focus. He played Nicky Spurgeon, a veteran con artist who takes a young, attractive woman under his wing. Focus was released on February 27, 2015. Smith was set to star in the Sci-Fic thriller Brilliance, an adaptation of Marcus Sakey's novel of the same name scripted by Jurassic Park writer David Koepp. But he left the project.
Smith played Dr. Bennet Omalu of the Brain Injury Research Institute in the sports-drama Concussion, who became the first person to discover chronic traumatic encephalopathy (CTE) in a football player's brain. CTE is a degenerative disease caused by severe trauma to the head that can be discovered only after death. Smith's involvement is mostly due to his last-minute exit from the Sci-Fi thriller-drama Brilliance. Concussion was directed by Peter Landesman and-bead filmed in Pittsburgh, according to the Pittsburgh Tribune-Review. It received $14.4 million in film tax credits from Pennsylvania. Principal photography started on October 27, 2014. Actress Gugu Mbatha-Raw played his wife. Omalu served as a consultant.
As of November 2015, Smith is set to star in the independent drama Collateral Beauty, which will be directed by David Frankel. Smith will play a New York advertising executive who succumbs to an deep depression after a personal tragedy.
Nobel Peace Prize Concert December 11, 2009, in Oslo, Norway: Smith with wife Jada and children Jaden and Willow
Smith married Sheree Zampino in 1992. They had one son, Trey Smith, born on November 11, 1992, and divorced in 1995. Trey appeared in his father's music video for the 1998 single "Just the Two of Us". He also acted in two episodes of the sitcom All of Us, and has appeared on The Oprah Winfrey Show and on the David Blaine: Real or Magic TV special.
Smith married actress Jada Koren Pinkett in 1997. Together they have two children: Jaden Christopher Syre Smith (born 1998), his co-star in The Pursuit of Happyness and After Earth, and Willow Camille Reign Smith (born 2000), who appeared as his daughter in I Am Legend. Smith and his brother Harry own Treyball Development Inc., a Beverly Hills-based company named after Trey. Smith and his family reside in Los Angeles, California.
Smith was consistently listed in Fortune Magazine's "Richest 40" list of the forty wealthiest Americans under the age of 40.
[No Text] (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000142/?ref_=ls_i_18)
18. Clint Eastwood (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000142/?ref_=ls_t_18)
Actor
Producer
Director
Million Dollar Baby (2004) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0405159/?ref_=ls_knf_18)
Clinton Eastwood Jr. was born May 31, 1930 in San Francisco, to Clinton Eastwood Sr., a bond salesman and later manufacturing executive for Georgia-Pacific Corporation, and
Ruth Wood (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm2503495/?ls)
(née Margret Ruth Runner), a housewife turned IBM clerk. He grew up in nearby Piedmont. At school Clint took interest in music and mechanics, but was an otherwise bored student; this resulted in being held back a grade. In 1949, the year he graduated from high school, his parents and younger sister Jeanne moved to Seattle. Clint spent a couple years in the Pacific Northwest himself, operating log broncs in Springfield, Oregon, with summer gigs life-guarding in Renton, Washington. Returning to California in 1951, he did a two-year stint at Fort Ord Military Reservation and later enrolled at L.A. City College, but dropped out to pursue acting.
During the mid-1950s he landed uncredited bit parts in such Z movies as
Revenge of the Creature (1955) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0048554/?ls)
and
Tarantula (1955) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0048696/?ls)
while digging swimming pools and driving a garbage truck to supplement his income. In 1958, he landed his first consequential acting role in the long-running TV show
Rawhide (1959) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0052504/?ls)
with
Eric Fleming (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0281661/?ls)
. Although only a secondary player the first seven seasons, he was promoted to series star when Fleming departed--both literally and figuratively--in its final year, along the way becoming a recognizable face to television viewers around the country.
Eastwood's big-screen breakthrough came as The Man with No Name in
Sergio Leone (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001466/?ls)
's trilogy of excellent spaghetti westerns:
A Fistful of Dollars (1964) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0058461/?ls)
,
For a Few Dollars More (1965) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0059578/?ls)
, and
The Good, the Bad and the Ugly (1966) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0060196/?ls)
. The movies were shown exclusively in Italy during their respective copyright years with
Enrico Maria Salerno (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0758066/?ls)
providing the voice of Eastwood's character, finally getting American distribution in 1967-68. As the last film racked up respectable grosses, Eastwood, 37, rose from a barely registering actor to sought-after commodity in just a matter of months. Again a success was the late-blooming star's first U.S.-made western,
Hang 'Em High (1968) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0061747/?ls)
. He followed that up with the lead role in
Coogan's Bluff (1968) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0062824/?ls)
(the loose inspiration for the TV series
McCloud (1970) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0065317/?ls)
), before playing second fiddle to
Richard Burton (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000009/?ls)
in the World War II epic
Where Eagles Dare (1968) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0065207/?ls)
and
Lee Marvin (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001511/?ls)
in the bizarre musical
Paint Your Wagon (1969) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0064782/?ls)
. In
Two Mules for Sister Sara (1970) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0065134/?ls)
and
Kelly's Heroes (1970) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0065938/?ls)
, Eastwood leaned in an experimental direction by combining tough-guy action with offbeat humor.
1971 proved to be his busiest year in film. He starred as a sleazy Union soldier in
The Beguiled (1971) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0066819/?ls)
to critical acclaim, and made his directorial debut with the classic erotic thriller
Play Misty for Me (1971) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0067588/?ls)
. His role as the hard edge police inspector in
Dirty Harry (1971) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0066999/?ls)
, meanwhile, boosted him to cultural icon status and helped popularize the loose-cannon cop genre. Eastwood put out a steady stream of entertaining movies thereafter: the westerns
Joe Kidd (1972) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0068768/?ls)
,
High Plains Drifter (1973) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0068699/?ls)
and
The Outlaw Josey Wales (1976) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0075029/?ls)
(his first of six onscreen collaborations with then live-in love
Sondra Locke (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0516800/?ls)
), the Dirty Harry sequels
Magnum Force (1973) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0070355/?ls)
and
The Enforcer (1976) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0074483/?ls)
, the action-packed road adventures
Thunderbolt and Lightfoot (1974) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0072288/?ls)
and
The Gauntlet (1977) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0076070/?ls)
, and the prison film
Escape from Alcatraz (1979) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0079116/?ls)
. He branched out into the comedy genre in 1978 with
Every Which Way But Loose (1978) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0077523/?ls)
, which became the biggest hit of his career up to that time; taking inflation into account, it still is. In short,
The Eiger Sanction (1975) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0072926/?ls)
notwithstanding, the 1970s were nonstop success for Eastwood.
Eastwood kicked off the 1980s with
Any Which Way You Can (1980) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0080377/?ls)
, the blockbuster sequel to Every Which Way but Loose. The fourth Dirty Harry film,
Sudden Impact (1983) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0086383/?ls)
, was the highest-grossing film of the franchise and spawned his trademark catchphrase: "Make my day." He also starred in
Bronco Billy (1980) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0080472/?ls)
,
Firefox (1982) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0083943/?ls)
,
Tightrope (1984) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0088272/?ls)
,
City Heat (1984) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0087062/?ls)
,
Pale Rider (1985) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0089767/?ls)
and
Heartbreak Ridge (1986) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0091187/?ls)
, all of which were solid hits, with
Honkytonk Man (1982) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0084088/?ls)
being his only commercial failure of the period. In 1988, he did his fifth and final Dirty Harry movie,
The Dead Pool (1988) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0094963/?ls)
. Although it was a success overall, it did not have the box office punch the previous films had. About this time, with outright bombs like
Pink Cadillac (1989) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0098097/?ls)
and
The Rookie (1990) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0100514/?ls)
, it seemed Eastwood's star was declining as it never had before. He then started taking on low-key projects, directing
Bird (1988) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0094747/?ls)
, a biopic of
Charlie Parker (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0662127/?ls)
that earned him a Golden Globe, and starring in and directing
White Hunter Black Heart (1990) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0100928/?ls)
, an uneven, loose biopic of
John Huston (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001379/?ls)
(both films had a limited release).
Eastwood bounced back big time with his dark western
Unforgiven (1992) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0105695/?ls)
, which garnered the then 62-year-old his first ever Academy Award nomination (Best Actor), and an Oscar win for Best Director. Churning out a quick follow-up hit, he took on the secret service in
In the Line of Fire (1993) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0107206/?ls)
, then accepted second billing for the first time since 1970 in the interesting but poorly received
A Perfect World (1993) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0107808/?ls)
with
Kevin Costner (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000126/?ls)
. Next was a love story,
The Bridges of Madison County (1995) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0112579/?ls)
, where Eastwood surprised audiences with a sensitive performance alongside none other than
Meryl Streep (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000658/?ls)
. But it soon became apparent he was going backwards after his brief revival. Subsequent films were credible, but nothing really stuck out.
Absolute Power (1997) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0118548/?ls)
and
Space Cowboys (2000) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0186566/?ls)
did well enough, while
True Crime (1999) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0139668/?ls)
and
Blood Work (2002) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0309377/?ls)
were received badly, as was
Midnight in the Garden of Good and Evil (1997) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0119668/?ls)
, which he directed but didn't appear in.
Eastwood surprised again in the mid-2000s, returning to the top of the A-list with
Million Dollar Baby (2004) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0405159/?ls)
. Also starring
Hilary Swank (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0005476/?ls)
and
Morgan Freeman (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000151/?ls)
, the hugely successful drama won four Academy Awards, including Best Picture and Best Director for Eastwood. He scored his second Best Actor nomination, too. His next starring vehicle,
Gran Torino (2008) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1205489/?ls)
, earned almost $30 million in its opening weekend and was his highest grosser unadjusted for inflation. 2012 saw him in a rare lighthearted movie,
Trouble with the Curve (2012) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2083383/?ls)
, as well as a reality show,
Mrs. Eastwood & Company (2012) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2305717/?ls)
.
Between acting jobs, he chalked up an impressive list of credits behind the camera. He directed
Mystic River (2003) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0327056/?ls)
(in which
Sean Penn (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000576/?ls)
and
Tim Robbins (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000209/?ls)
gave Oscar-winning performances),
Flags of Our Fathers (2006) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0418689/?ls)
,
Letters from Iwo Jima (2006) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0498380/?ls)
(nominated for the Best Picture Oscar),
Changeling (2008) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0824747/?ls)
(a vehicle for
Angelina Jolie (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001401/?ls)
),
Invictus (2009) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1057500/?ls)
(again with Freeman),
Hereafter (2010) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1212419/?ls)
,
J. Edgar (2011) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1616195/?ls)
,
Jersey Boys (2014) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1742044/?ls)
,
American Sniper (2014) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2179136/?ls)
(2014's top box office champ),
Sully (2016) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt3263904/?ls)
(starring
Tom Hanks (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000158/?ls)
as hero pilot
Chesley Sullenberger (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm3314810/?ls)
) and
The 15:17 to Paris (2018) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt6802308/?ls)
. Back on screens after a considerable absence, he played an unlikely drug courier in
The Mule (2018) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt7959026/?ls)
, which reached the top of the box office with a nine-figure gross, then directed
Richard Jewell (2019) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt3513548/?ls)
. At age 91, Eastwood made history as the oldest actor to star above the title in a movie with the release of
Cry Macho (2021) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1924245/?ls)
.
Away from the limelight, Eastwood has led an aberrant existence and is described by biographer
Patrick McGilligan (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0569292/?ls)
as a cunning manipulator of the media. His convoluted slew of partners and children are now somewhat factually acknowledged, but for the first three decades of his celebrity, his personal life was kept top secret, and several of his families were left out of the official narrative. The actor refuses to disclose his exact number of offspring even to this day. He had a longtime relationship with similarly abstruse co-star Locke (who died aged 74 in 2018, though for her entire public life she masqueraded about being younger), and has fathered at least eight children by at least six different women in an unending string of liaisons, many of which overlapped. He has been married only twice, however, with a mere three of his progeny coming from those unions.
His known children are:
Laurie Murray (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm15158933/?ls)
(b. 1954), whose mother is unidentified;
Kimber Eastwood (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0247761/?ls)
(b. 1964) with stuntwoman
Roxanne Tunis (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0876651/?ls)
;
Kyle Eastwood (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0247762/?ls)
(b. 1968) and
Alison Eastwood (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0002055/?ls)
(b. 1972) with his first ex-wife,
Margaret Neville Johnson (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm1527881/?ls)
;
Scott Eastwood (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm2207222/?ls)
(b. 1986) and
Kathryn Eastwood (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm1828228/?ls)
(b. 1988) with stewardess Jacelyn Reeves;
Francesca Eastwood (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0247754/?ls)
(b. 1993) with actress
Frances Fisher (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0004920/?ls)
; and
Morgan Eastwood (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm1765859/?ls)
(b. 1996) with his second ex-wife,
Dina Eastwood (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0247753/?ls)
. The entire time that he lived with Locke she was legally married to sculptor
Gordon Anderson (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0026770/?ls)
.
Eastwood has real estate holdings in Bel-Air, La Quinta, Carmel-by-the-Sea, Cassel (in remote northern California), Idaho's Sun Valley and Kihei, Hawaii.
[No Text] (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000139/?ref_=ls_i_19)
19. Cameron Diaz (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000139/?ref_=ls_t_19)
Actress
Producer
Soundtrack
Charlie's Angels (2000) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0160127/?ref_=ls_knf_19)
A tall, strikingly attractive blue-eyed natural blonde, Cameron Diaz was born in 1972 in San Diego, the daughter of a Cuban-American father and an Anglo-German mother. Self described as "adventurous, independent and a tough kid," Cameron left home at 16 and for the next 5 years lived in such varied locales as Japan, Australia, Mexico, Morocco, and Paris. Returning to California at the age of 21, she was working as a model when she auditioned for a big part in
The Mask (1994) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0110475/?ls)
. To her amazement and despite having no previous acting experience, she was cast as the female lead in the film opposite
Jim Carrey (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000120/?ls)
. Over the next 3 years, she honed her acting skills in such low budget independent films as
The Last Supper (1995) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0113613/?ls)
;
Feeling Minnesota (1996) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0116289/?ls)
; and
Head Above Water (1996) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0116502/?ls)
. She returned to main stream films in
My Best Friend's Wedding (1997) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0119738/?ls)
, in which she held her own against veteran actress
Julia Roberts (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000210/?ls)
. She earned full fledged star status in 1998 for her performance in the box office smash
There's Something About Mary (1998) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0129387/?ls)
. With her name near the top on virtually every list of Hollyood's sexiest actresses, and firmly established as one of filmdom's hottest properties and most sought after actresses,
Cameron Diaz (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000139/?ls)
appears to possess everything necessary to become one of the super stars of the new century.
[No Text] (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000123/?ref_=ls_i_20)
20. George Clooney (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000123/?ref_=ls_t_20)
Actor
Producer
Director
The Ides of March (2011) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1124035/?ref_=ls_knf_20)
George Timothy Clooney was born on May 6, 1961, in Lexington, Kentucky, to
Nina Clooney (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm6460343/?ls)
(née Nina Bruce Warren), a beauty pageant queen, and
Nick Clooney (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0167040/?ls)
, a former anchorman and television host (who was also the brother of singer
Rosemary Clooney (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0167041/?ls)
). He has Irish, English, and German ancestry. Clooney spent most of his youth in Ohio and Kentucky, and graduated from Augusta High School. He was very active in sports such as basketball and baseball, and tried out for the Cincinnati Reds, but was not offered a contract.
After his cousin,
Miguel Ferrer (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001208/?ls)
, got him a small role in a feature film, Clooney began to pursue acting. His first major role was on the sitcom
E/R (1984) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0086704/?ls)
as Ace. More roles soon followed, including George Burnett, the handsome handyman on
The Facts of Life (1979) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0078610/?ls)
; Booker Brooks, a supervisor on
Roseanne (1988) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0094540/?ls)
; and Detective James Falconer on
Sisters (1991) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0101199/?ls)
. Clooney had his breakthrough when he was cast as Dr. Doug Ross on the award-winning drama series
ER (1994) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0108757/?ls)
, opposite
Anthony Edwards (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000381/?ls)
,
Noah Wyle (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001864/?ls)
and
Julianna Margulies (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000523/?ls)
.
While filming "ER" (1994), Clooney starred in a number of high profile film roles, such as
Robert Rodriguez (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001675/?ls)
's
From Dusk Till Dawn (1996) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0116367/?ls)
, and
One Fine Day (1996) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0117247/?ls)
, opposite
Michelle Pfeiffer (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000201/?ls)
. In 1997, Clooney took on the role of Batman in
Joel Schumacher (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001708/?ls)
's
Batman & Robin (1997) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0118688/?ls)
. The film was a moderate success in the box office, but was slammed by critics, notably for the nipple-laden Batsuit. Clooney went on to star in
Steven Soderbergh (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001752/?ls)
's
Out of Sight (1998) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0120780/?ls)
,
Terrence Malick (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000517/?ls)
's
The Thin Red Line (1998) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0120863/?ls)
, and
David O. Russell (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0751102/?ls)
's
Three Kings (1999) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0120188/?ls)
.
In 1999, Clooney left "ER" (1994) (though he would return for the season finale) and appeared in a number of films, including
O Brother, Where Art Thou? (2000) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0190590/?ls)
,
The Perfect Storm (2000) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0177971/?ls)
and
Ocean's Eleven (2001) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0240772/?ls)
. Collaborating once again with
Steven Soderbergh (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001752/?ls)
, Ocean's Eleven (2001) received critical acclaim, earned more than $450 million at the box office, and spawned two sequels:
Ocean's Twelve (2004) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0349903/?ls)
and
Ocean's Thirteen (2007) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0496806/?ls)
.
In 2002, Clooney made his directorial debut with
Confessions of a Dangerous Mind (2002) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0270288/?ls)
, an adaptation of TV producer
Chuck Barris (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0057567/?ls)
' autobiography. This was the first film under the banner of Section Eight Productions, a production company he founded with
Steven Soderbergh (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001752/?ls)
. The company also produced many acclaimed films, including
Far from Heaven (2002) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0297884/?ls)
,
Syriana (2005) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0365737/?ls)
,
A Scanner Darkly (2006) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0405296/?ls)
and
Good Night, and Good Luck. (2005) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0433383/?ls)
. Clooney won his first Oscar for Best Supporting Actor in Syriana (2005), and was nominated for Best Director and Best Original Screenplay for Good Night, and Good Luck. (2005).
In 2006, Section Eight Productions was shut down so that Soderbergh could concentrate on directing, and Clooney founded a new production company, Smokehouse Productions, with his friend and longtime business partner,
Grant Heslov (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0381416/?ls)
.
Clooney went on to produce and star in
Michael Clayton (2007) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0465538/?ls)
(which earned him an Oscar nomination for Best Actor), directed and starred in
Leatherheads (2008) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0379865/?ls)
, and took leading roles in
Burn After Reading (2008) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0887883/?ls)
,
The Men Who Stare at Goats (2009) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1234548/?ls)
,
Fantastic Mr. Fox (2009) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0432283/?ls)
, and
Jason Reitman (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0718646/?ls)
's
Up in the Air (2009) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1193138/?ls)
. Clooney received critical acclaim for his performance in Up in the Air (2009) and was nominated for several awards, including a Golden Globe Award and Academy Award. He didn't win that year, but took home both Best Actor awards (as well as countless nominations) for his role as a father who finds out his wife was unfaithful as she lays in a coma in
Alexander Payne (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0668247/?ls)
's
The Descendants (2011) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1033575/?ls)
. Through his career, Clooney has been heralded for his political activism and humanitarian work. He has served as one of the United Nations Messengers of Peace since 2008, has been an advocate for the Darfur conflict, and organized the Hope for Haiti telethon, to raise money for the victims of the 2010 earthquake. In March 2012, Clooney was arrested for civil disobedience while protesting at the Sudanese embassy in Washington, D.C.
Clooney was married to actress
Talia Balsam (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0051104/?ls)
, from 1989 until 1993. After their divorce, he swore he would never marry again.
Michelle Pfeiffer (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000201/?ls)
and
Nicole Kidman (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000173/?ls)
bet him $10,000 that he would have children by the age of 40, and sent him a check shortly after his birthday. Clooney returned the funds and bet double or nothing he wouldn't have children by the age of 50. Although he has remained a consummate bachelor, Clooney has had many highly publicized relationships, including with former WWE wrestler
Stacy Keibler (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0445001/?ls)
. In 2014, he married lawyer and activist
Amal Clooney (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm5007802/?ls)
, with whom he has two children, twins.
[No Text] (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000229/?ref_=ls_i_21)
21. Steven Spielberg (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000229/?ref_=ls_t_21)
Producer
Writer
Director
Schindler's List (1993) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0108052/?ref_=ls_knf_21)
One of the most influential personalities in the history of cinema, Steven Spielberg is Hollywood's best known
director and one of the wealthiest filmmakers in the world. He has an extraordinary number of commercially successful and critically acclaimed credits to his name, either as a director, producer or writer since launching the summer blockbuster with
Jaws (1975) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0073195/?ls)
, and he has done more to define popular film-making since the mid-1970s than anyone else.
Steven Allan Spielberg was born in 1946 in Cincinnati, Ohio, to Leah Frances (Posner), a concert pianist and restaurateur, and
Arnold Spielberg (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0818577/?ls)
, an electrical engineer who worked in computer development. His parents were both born to Russian Jewish immigrant families. Steven spent his younger years in Haddon Township, New Jersey, Phoenix, Arizona, and later Saratoga, California. He went to California State University Long Beach, but dropped
out to pursue his entertainment career.
Among his
early directing efforts were Battle Squad (1961), which combined World
War II footage with footage of an airplane on the ground that he makes
you believe is moving. He also directed
Escape to Nowhere (1961) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0054857/?ls)
, which
featured children as World War Two soldiers, including his sister
Anne Spielberg (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0818576/?ls)
, and
The Last Gun (1959) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0052991/?ls)
, a western.
All of these were short films. The next couple of years, Spielberg
directed a couple of movies that would portend his future career in
movies. In 1964, he directed
Firelight (1964) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0059181/?ls)
, a movie about aliens
invading a small town. In 1967, he directed
Slipstream (1967) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0249968/?ls)
, which was
unfinished. However, in 1968, he directed
Amblin' (1968) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0064010/?ls)
, which featured the desert
prominently, and not the first of his movies in which the desert would
feature. Amblin' also became the name of his production
company, which turned out such classics as
E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial (1982) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0083866/?ls)
.
Spielberg had a unique and classic early directing project,
Duel (1971) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0067023/?ls)
, with
Dennis Weaver (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0915840/?ls)
. In the early 1970s,
Spielberg was working on TV, directing among others such series as
Rod Serling (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0785245/?ls)
's
Night Gallery (1969) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0065327/?ls)
,
Marcus Welby, M.D. (1969) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0063927/?ls)
and
Murder by the Book (1971) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0066932/?ls)
.
All of his work in television and short films, as well as his directing
projects, were just a hint of the wellspring of talent that would
dazzle audiences all over the world.
Spielberg's first major directorial effort was
The Sugarland Express (1974) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0072226/?ls)
,
with
Goldie Hawn (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000443/?ls)
, a film that marked him as
a rising star. It was his next effort, however, that made him an
international superstar among directors:
Jaws (1975) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0073195/?ls)
. This classic shark attack tale
started the tradition of the summer blockbuster or, at least, he was
credited with starting the tradition. His next film was the classic
Close Encounters of the Third Kind (1977) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0075860/?ls)
,
a unique and original UFO story that remains a classic. In 1978,
Spielberg produced his first film, the forgettable
I Wanna Hold Your Hand (1978) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0077714/?ls)
,
and followed that effort with
Used Cars (1980) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0081698/?ls)
, a critically
acclaimed, but mostly forgotten,
Kurt Russell (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000621/?ls)
/
Jack Warden (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0912001/?ls)
comedy about devious used-car dealers. Spielberg hit gold yet one more
time with
Raiders of the Lost Ark (1981) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0082971/?ls)
,
with
Harrison Ford (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000148/?ls)
taking the part
of Indiana Jones. Spielberg produced and directed two films in 1982.
The first was
Poltergeist (1982) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0084516/?ls)
, but
the highest-grossing movie of all time up to that point was the alien
story
E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial (1982) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0083866/?ls)
.
Spielberg also helped pioneer the practice of product placement. The
concept, while not uncommon, was still relatively low-key when
Spielberg raised the practice to almost an art form with his famous (or
infamous) placement of Reese's Pieces in "E.T." Spielberg was also one
of the pioneers of the big-grossing special-effects movies, like "E.T."
and "Close Encounters", where a very strong emphasis on special effects
was placed for the first time on such a huge scale. In 1984, Spielberg
followed up "Raiders" with
Indiana Jones and the Temple of Doom (1984) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0087469/?ls)
,
which was a commercial success but did not receive the critical acclaim
of its predecessor. As a producer, Spielberg took on many projects in
the 1980s, such as
The Goonies (1985) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0089218/?ls)
, and was the
brains behind the little monsters in
Gremlins (1984) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0087363/?ls)
. He also produced the
cartoon
An American Tail (1986) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0090633/?ls)
, a
quaint little animated classic. His biggest effort as producer in 1985,
however, was the blockbuster
Back to the Future (1985) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0088763/?ls)
,
which made
Michael J. Fox (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000150/?ls)
an
instant superstar. As director, Spielberg took on the book
The Color Purple (1985) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0088939/?ls)
, with
Whoopi Goldberg (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000155/?ls)
and
Oprah Winfrey (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001856/?ls)
, with great success. In the
latter half of the 1980s, he also directed
Empire of the Sun (1987) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0092965/?ls)
, a
mixed success for the occasionally erratic Spielberg. Success would not
escape him for long, though.
The late 1980s found Spielberg's projects at the center of pop-culture
yet again. In 1988, he produced the landmark animation/live-action film
Who Framed Roger Rabbit (1988) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0096438/?ls)
.
The next year proved to be another big one for Spielberg, as he
produced and directed
Always (1989) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0096794/?ls)
as
well as
Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade (1989) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0097576/?ls)
,
and
Back to the Future Part II (1989) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0096874/?ls)
.
All three of the films were box-office and critical successes. Also, in
1989, he produced the little known comedy-drama
Dad (1989) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0097142/?ls)
, with
Jack Lemmon (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000493/?ls)
and
Ted Danson (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001101/?ls)
, which got mostly mixed results.
Spielberg has also had an affinity for animation and has been a strong
voice in animation in the 1990s. Aside from producing the landmark "Who
Framed Roger Rabbit", he produced the animated series
Tiny Toon Adventures (1990) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0098929/?ls)
,
Animaniacs (1993) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0105941/?ls)
,
Pinky and the Brain (1995) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0112123/?ls)
,
Freakazoid! (1995) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0111970/?ls)
,
Pinky, Elmyra & the Brain (1998) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0170996/?ls)
,
Family Dog (1993) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0105996/?ls)
and
Toonsylvania (1998) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0143068/?ls)
. Spielberg
also produced other cartoons such as
The Land Before Time (1988) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0095489/?ls)
,
We're Back! A Dinosaur's Story (1993) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0108526/?ls)
,
Casper (1995) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0112642/?ls)
(the live action version) as
well as the live-action version of
The Flintstones (1994) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0109813/?ls)
, where
he was credited as "Steven Spielrock". Spielberg also produced many
Roger Rabbit short cartoons, and many Pinky and the Brain, Animaniacs
and Tiny Toons specials. Spielberg was very active in the early 1990s,
as he directed
Hook (1991) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0102057/?ls)
and produced such
films as the cute fantasy
Joe Versus the Volcano (1990) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0099892/?ls)
and
An American Tail: Fievel Goes West (1991) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0101329/?ls)
.
He also produced the unusual comedy thriller
Arachnophobia (1990) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0099052/?ls)
,
Back to the Future Part III (1990) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0099088/?ls)
and
Gremlins 2: The New Batch (1990) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0099700/?ls)
.
While these movies were big successes in their own right, they did not
quite bring in the kind of box office or critical acclaim as previous
efforts. In 1993, Spielberg directed
Jurassic Park (1993) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0107290/?ls)
, which for a
short time held the record as the highest grossing movie of all time,
but did not have the universal appeal of his previous efforts. Big
box-office spectacles were not his only concern, though. He produced
and directed
Schindler's List (1993) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0108052/?ls)
, a
stirring film about the Holocaust. He won best director at the Oscars,
and also got Best Picture. In the mid-90s, he helped found the
production company DreamWorks, which was responsible for many
box-office successes.
As a producer, he was very active in the late 90s, responsible for such
films as
The Mask of Zorro (1998) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0120746/?ls)
,
Men in Black (1997) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0119654/?ls)
and
Deep Impact (1998) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0120647/?ls)
. However, it was
on the directing front that Spielberg was in top form. He directed and
produced the epic
Amistad (1997) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0118607/?ls)
, a
spectacular film that was shorted at the Oscars and in release due to
the fact that its release date was moved around so much in late 1997.
The next year, however, produced what many believe was one of the best
films of his career:
Saving Private Ryan (1998) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0120815/?ls)
, a
film about World War Two that is spectacular in almost every respect.
It was stiffed at the Oscars, losing best picture to
Shakespeare in Love (1998) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0138097/?ls)
.
Spielberg produced a series of films, including
Evolution (2001) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0251075/?ls)
,
The Haunting (1999) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0171363/?ls)
and
Shrek (2001) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0126029/?ls)
. he also produced two sequels
to
Jurassic Park (1993) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0107290/?ls)
, which were
financially but not particularly critical successes. In 2001, he
produced a mini-series about World War Two that definitely *was* a
financial and critical success:
Band of Brothers (2001) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0185906/?ls)
, a
tale of an infantry company from its parachuting into France during the
invasion to the Battle of the Bulge. Also in that year, Spielberg was
back in the director's chair for
A.I. Artificial Intelligence (2001) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0212720/?ls)
,
a movie with a message and a huge budget. It did reasonably at the box
office and garnered varied reviews from critics.
Spielberg has been extremely active in films there are many other
things he has done as well. He produced the short-lived TV series
SeaQuest 2032 (1993) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0106126/?ls)
, an
anthology series entitled
Amazing Stories (1985) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0088478/?ls)
,
created the video-game series "Medal of Honor" set during World War
Two, and was a starting producer of
ER (1994) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0108757/?ls)
. Spielberg, if you haven't
noticed, has a great interest in World War Two. He and
Tom Hanks (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000158/?ls)
collaborated on
Shooting War: World War II Combat Cameramen (2000) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0250730/?ls)
, a
documentary about World War II combat photographers, and he produced a
documentary about the Holocaust called
Eyes of the Holocaust (2000) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0262468/?ls)
.
With all of this to Spielberg's credit, it's no wonder that he's looked
at as one of the greatest ever figures in entertainment.
[No Text] (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000148/?ref_=ls_i_22)
22. Harrison Ford (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000148/?ref_=ls_t_22)
Actor
Writer
Producer
Raiders of the Lost Ark (1981) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0082971/?ref_=ls_knf_22)
Harrison Ford was born on July 13, 1942 in Chicago, Illinois, to Dorothy (Nidelman), a radio actress, and Christopher Ford (born John William Ford), an actor turned advertising executive. His father was of Irish and German ancestry, while his maternal grandparents were Jewish emigrants from Minsk, Belarus. Harrison was a lackluster student at Maine Township High School East in Park Ridge Illinois (no athletic star, never above a C average). After dropping out of Ripon College in Wisconsin, where he did some acting and later summer stock, he signed a Hollywood contract with Columbia and later Universal. His roles in movies and television (
Ironside (1967) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0061266/?ls)
,
The Virginian (1962) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0055710/?ls)
) remained secondary and, discouraged, he turned to a career in professional carpentry. He came back big four years later, however, as Bob Falfa in
American Graffiti (1973) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0069704/?ls)
. Four years after that, he hit colossal with the role of Han Solo in
Star Wars: Episode IV - A New Hope (1977) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0076759/?ls)
. Another four years and Ford was Indiana Jones in
Raiders of the Lost Ark (1981) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0082971/?ls)
.
Four years later and he received Academy Award and Golden Globe nominations for his role as John Book in
Witness (1985) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0090329/?ls)
. All he managed four years after that was his third starring success as Indiana Jones; in fact, many of his earlier successful roles led to sequels as did his more recent portrayal of Jack Ryan in
Patriot Games (1992) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0105112/?ls)
. Another Golden Globe nomination came his way for the part of Dr. Richard Kimble in
The Fugitive (1993) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0106977/?ls)
. He is clearly a well-established Hollywood superstar. He also maintains an 800-acre ranch in Jackson Hole, Wyoming.
Ford is a private pilot of both fixed-wing aircraft and helicopters, and owns an 800-acre (3.2 km2) ranch in Jackson, Wyoming, approximately half of which he has donated as a nature reserve. On several occasions, Ford has personally provided emergency helicopter services at the request of local authorities, in one instance rescuing a hiker overcome by dehydration. Ford began flight training in the 1960s at Wild Rose Idlewild Airport in Wild Rose, Wisconsin, flying in a Piper PA-22 Tri-Pacer, but at $15 an hour, he could not afford to continue the training. In the mid-1990s, he bought a used Gulfstream II and asked one of his pilots, Terry Bender, to give him flying lessons. They started flying a Cessna 182 out of Jackson, Wyoming, later switching to Teterboro, New Jersey, flying a Cessna 206, the aircraft he soloed in. Ford is an honorary board member of the humanitarian aviation organization Wings of Hope.
On March 5, 2015, Ford's plane, believed to be a Ryan PT-22 Recruit, made an emergency landing on the Penmar Golf Course in Venice, California. Ford had radioed in to report that the plane had suffered engine failure. He was taken to Ronald Reagan UCLA Medical Center, where he was reported to be in fair to moderate condition. Ford suffered a broken pelvis and broken ankle during the accident, as well as other injuries.
[No Text] (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000134/?ref_=ls_i_23)
23. Robert De Niro (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000134/?ref_=ls_t_23)
Actor
Producer
Director
Cape Fear (1991) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0101540/?ref_=ls_knf_23)
One of the greatest actors of all time, Robert De Niro was born in 1943, in Manhattan, New York City, to artists Virginia (Admiral) and
Robert De Niro Sr. (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm3902582/?ls)
. His paternal grandfather was of Italian descent, and his other ancestry is Irish, English, Dutch, German, and French. He was trained at the
Stella Adler (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0012245/?ls)
Conservatory and the American Workshop. De Niro first gained fame for his role in
Bang the Drum Slowly (1973) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0069765/?ls)
, but he gained his reputation as a volatile actor in
Mean Streets (1973) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0070379/?ls)
, which was his first film with director
Martin Scorsese (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000217/?ls)
. He received an Academy Award for Best Supporting Actor for his role in
The Godfather Part II (1974) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0071562/?ls)
and received Academy Award nominations for best actor in
Taxi Driver (1976) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0075314/?ls)
,
The Deer Hunter (1978) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0077416/?ls)
and
Cape Fear (1991) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0101540/?ls)
. He received the Academy Award for Best Actor for his role as
Jake LaMotta (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0483766/?ls)
in
Raging Bull (1980) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0081398/?ls)
.
De Niro has earned four Golden Globe Award nominations for Best Actor - Motion Picture Musical or Comedy for his work in
New York, New York (1977) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0076451/?ls)
, opposite
Liza Minnelli (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0591485/?ls)
,
Midnight Run (1988) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0095631/?ls)
,
Analyze This (1999) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0122933/?ls)
, and
Meet the Parents (2000) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0212338/?ls)
. Other notable performances include
Brazil (1985) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0088846/?ls)
,
The Untouchables (1987) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0094226/?ls)
,
Backdraft (1991) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0101393/?ls)
,
Frankenstein (1994) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0109836/?ls)
,
Heat (1995) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0113277/?ls)
,
Casino (1995) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0112641/?ls)
, and
Jackie Brown (1997) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0119396/?ls)
. At the same time, he also directed and starred in such films as
A Bronx Tale (1993) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0106489/?ls)
and
The Good Shepherd (2006) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0343737/?ls)
. De Niro has also received the AFI Lifetime Achievement Award in 2003 and the Golden Globe Cecil B. DeMille Award in 2010.
As of 2024, De Niro is 81 years-old. He has never retired from acting, and continues to work regularly in mostly film.
[No Text] (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000199/?ref_=ls_i_24)
24. Al Pacino (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000199/?ref_=ls_t_24)
Actor
Director
Producer
Serpico (1973) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0070666/?ref_=ls_knf_24)
Alfredo James "Al" 'Pacino established himself as a film actor during one of cinema's most vibrant decades, the 1970s, and has become an enduring and iconic figure in the world of American movies.
He was born April 25, 1940 in Manhattan, New York City, to Italian-American parents, Rose (nee Gerardi) and
Sal Pacino (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0655416/?ls)
. They divorced when he was young. His mother moved them into his grandparents' home in the South Bronx. Pacino found himself often repeating the plots and voices of characters he had seen in the movies. Bored and unmotivated in school, he found a haven in school plays, and his interest soon blossomed into a full-time career. Starting onstage, he went through a period of depression and poverty, sometimes having to borrow bus fare to succeed to auditions. He made it into the prestigious Actors Studio in 1966, studying under
Lee Strasberg (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0833448/?ls)
, creator of the Method Approach that would become the trademark of many 1970s-era actors.
After appearing in a string of plays in supporting roles, Pacino finally attained success off-Broadway with
Israel Horovitz (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0395262/?ls)
's "The Indian Wants the Bronx", winning an Obie Award for the 1966-67 season. That was followed by a Tony Award for "Does the Tiger Wear a Necktie?" His first feature films made little departure from the gritty realistic stage performances that earned him respect: he played a drug addict in
The Panic in Needle Park (1971) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0067549/?ls)
after his film debut in
Me, Natalie (1969) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0064651/?ls)
. The role of Michael Corleone in
The Godfather (1972) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0068646/?ls)
was one of the most sought-after of the time:
Robert Redford (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000602/?ls)
,
Warren Beatty (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000886/?ls)
,
Jack Nicholson (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000197/?ls)
,
Ryan O'Neal (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0641939/?ls)
,
Robert De Niro (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000134/?ls)
and a host of other actors either wanted it or were mentioned, but director
Francis Ford Coppola (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000338/?ls)
wanted Pacino for the role.
Coppola was successful but Pacino was reportedly in constant fear of being fired during the very difficult shoot. The film was a monster hit that earned Pacino his first Academy Award nomination for Best Supporting Actor. However, instead of taking on easier projects for the big money he could now command, Pacino threw his support behind what he considered tough but important films, such as the true-life crime drama
Serpico (1973) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0070666/?ls)
and the tragic real-life bank robbery film
Dog Day Afternoon (1975) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0072890/?ls)
. He was nominated three consecutive years for the "Best Actor" Academy Award. He faltered slightly with
Bobby Deerfield (1977) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0075774/?ls)
, but regained his stride with
And Justice for All (1979) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0078718/?ls)
, for which he received another Academy Award nomination for Best Actor. Unfortunately, this would signal the beginning of a decline in his career, which produced flops like
Cruising (1980) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0080569/?ls)
and
Author! Author! (1982) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0083598/?ls)
.
Pacino took on another vicious gangster role and cemented his legendary status in the ultra-violent cult film
Scarface (1983) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0086250/?ls)
, but a monumental mistake was about to follow.
Revolution (1985) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0089913/?ls)
endured an endless and seemingly cursed shoot in which equipment was destroyed, weather was terrible, and Pacino fell ill with pneumonia. Constant changes in the script further derailed the project. The Revolutionary War-themed film, considered among the worst films ever made, resulted in awful reviews and kept him off the screen for the next four years. Returning to the stage, Pacino did much to give back and contribute to the theatre, which he considers his first love. He directed a film,
The Local Stigmatic (1990) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0097769/?ls)
, but it remains unreleased. He lifted his self-imposed exile with the striking
Sea of Love (1989) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0098273/?ls)
as a hard-drinking policeman. This marked the second phase of Pacino's career, being the first to feature his now famous dark, owl eyes and hoarse, gravelly voice.
Returning to the Corleones, Pacino made
The Godfather Part III (1990) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0099674/?ls)
and earned raves for his first comedic role in the colorful adaptation
Dick Tracy (1990) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0099422/?ls)
. This earned him another Academy Award nomination for Best Supporting Actor, and two years later he was nominated for
Glengarry Glen Ross (1992) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0104348/?ls)
. He went into romantic mode for
Frankie and Johnny (1991) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0101912/?ls)
. In 1992, he finally won the Academy Award for Best Actor for his amazing performance in
Scent of a Woman (1992) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0105323/?ls)
. A mixture of technical perfection (he plays a blind man) and charisma, the role was tailor-made for him, and remains a classic.
The next few years would see Pacino becoming more comfortable with acting and movies as a business, turning out great roles in great films with more frequency and less of the demanding personal involvement of his wilder days.
Carlito's Way (1993) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0106519/?ls)
proved another gangster classic, as did the epic crime drama
Heat (1995) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0113277/?ls)
directed by
Michael Mann (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000520/?ls)
and co-starring
Robert De Niro (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000134/?ls)
. He directed the film adaptation of Shakespeare's
Looking for Richard (1996) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0116913/?ls)
. During this period,
City Hall (1996) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0115907/?ls)
,
Donnie Brasco (1997) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0119008/?ls)
and
The Devil's Advocate (1997) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0118971/?ls)
all came out. Reteaming with Mann and then
Oliver Stone (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000231/?ls)
, he gave commanding performances in
The Insider (1999) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0140352/?ls)
and
Any Given Sunday (1999) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0146838/?ls)
.
In the 2000s, Pacino starred in a number of theatrical blockbusters, including
Ocean's Thirteen (2007) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0496806/?ls)
, but his choice in television roles (the vicious, closeted Roy Cohn in the HBO miniseries
Angels in America (2003) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0318997/?ls)
and his sensitive portrayal of Jack Kevorkian, in the television movie
You Don't Know Jack (2010) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1132623/?ls)
) are reminiscent of the bolder choices of his early career. Each television project garnered him an Emmy Award for Outstanding Lead Actor in a Miniseries or a Movie.
Never wed, Pacino has a daughter, Julie Marie, with acting teacher Jan Tarrant, and a set of twins with former longtime girlfriend
Beverly D'Angelo (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000350/?ls)
. His romantic history includes
Jill Clayburgh (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001049/?ls)
,
Veruschka von Lehndorff (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0902610/?ls)
,
Carole Mallory (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0540098/?ls)
,
Debra Winger (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000700/?ls)
,
Tuesday Weld (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001839/?ls)
,
Marthe Keller (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0445715/?ls)
,
Carmen Cervera (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0148947/?ls)
,
Kathleen Quinlan (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000599/?ls)
,
Lyndall Hobbs (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0387605/?ls)
,
Penelope Ann Miller (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000542/?ls)
, and a two-decade intermittent relationship with "Godfather" co-star
Diane Keaton (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000473/?ls)
. He currently lives with Argentinian actress
Lucila Solá (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm1376482/?ls)
, who is 36 years his junior.
As of 2022, Pacino is 82-years-old. He has never retired from acting, and continues to appear regularly in film.

25. Russell Crowe (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000128/?ref_=ls_t_25)
Actor
Producer
Director
Les Misérables (2012) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1707386/?ref_=ls_knf_25)
Russell Ira Crowe was born in Wellington, New Zealand, to Jocelyn Yvonne (Wemyss) and John Alexander Crowe, both of whom catered movie sets. His maternal grandfather, Stanley Wemyss, was a cinematographer. Crowe's recent ancestry includes Welsh (where his paternal grandfather was born, in Wrexham), English, Irish, Scottish, Norwegian, Swedish, Italian, and Maori (one of Crowe's maternal great-grandmothers, Erana Putiputi Hayes Heihi, was Maori).
Crowe's family moved to Australia when he was a small child, settling in Sydney, and Russell got the acting bug early in life. Beginning as a child star on a local Australian TV show, Russell's first big break came with two films ... the first,
Romper Stomper (1992) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0105275/?ls)
, gained him a name throughout the film community in Australia and the neighboring countries. The second,
The Sum of Us (1994) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0111309/?ls)
, helped put him on the American map, so to speak.
Sharon Stone (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000232/?ls)
heard of him from
Romper Stomper (1992) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0105275/?ls)
and wanted him for her film,
The Quick and the Dead (1995) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0114214/?ls)
. But filming on
The Sum of Us (1994) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0111309/?ls)
had already begun. Sharon is reported to have held up shooting until she had her gunslinger-Crowe, for her film. With
The Quick and the Dead (1995) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0114214/?ls)
under his belt as his first American film, the second was offered to him soon after.
Virtuosity (1995) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0114857/?ls)
, starring
Denzel Washington (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000243/?ls)
, put Russell in the body of a Virtual Serial Killer, Sid6.7 ... a role unlike any he had played so far.
Virtuosity (1995) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0114857/?ls)
, a Sci-Fi extravaganza, was a fun film and, again, opened the door to even more American offers.
L.A. Confidential (1997) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0119488/?ls)
, Russell's third American film, brought him the US fame and attention that his fans have felt he deserved all along. Missing the Oscar nod this time around, he didn't seem deterred and signed to do his first film with The
Walt Disney (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000370/?ls)
Company,
Mystery, Alaska (1999) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0134618/?ls)
. He achieved even more success and awards for his performances in
Gladiator (2000) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0172495/?ls)
, for which he won the Academy Award for Best Actor, and
A Beautiful Mind (2001) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0268978/?ls)
.

26. Liam Neeson (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000553/?ref_=ls_t_26)
Actor
Producer
Soundtrack
Kinsey (2004) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0362269/?ref_=ls_knf_26)
Liam Neeson was born on June 7, 1952 in Ballymena, Northern Ireland, to Katherine (Brown), a cook, and Bernard Neeson, a school caretaker. He was raised in a Catholic household. During his early years, Liam worked as a forklift operator for Guinness, a truck driver, an assistant architect and an amateur boxer. He had originally sought a career as a teacher by attending St. Mary's Teaching College, Newcastle. However, in 1976, Neeson joined the Belfast Lyric Players' Theater and made his professional acting debut in the play "The Risen People". After two years, Neeson moved to Dublin's Abbey Theater where he performed the classics. It was here that he was spotted by director
John Boorman (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000958/?ls)
and was cast in the film
Excalibur (1981) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0082348/?ls)
as Sir Gawain, his first high-profile film role.
Through the 1980s Neeson appeared in a handful of films and British TV series - including
The Bounty (1984) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0086993/?ls)
,
A Woman of Substance (1984) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0085114/?ls)
,
The Mission (1986) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0091530/?ls)
, and
Duet for One (1986) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0092934/?ls)
- but it was not until he moved to Hollywood to pursue larger roles that he began to get noticed. His turn as a mute homeless man in
Suspect (1987) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0094082/?ls)
garnered good reviews, as did supporting roles in
The Good Mother (1988) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0095238/?ls)
and
High Spirits (1988) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0095304/?ls)
- though he also starred in the best-to-be-forgotten
Satisfaction (1988) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0096037/?ls)
, which also featured a then-unknown
Julia Roberts (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000210/?ls)
- but leading man status eluded him until the cult favorite
Darkman (1990) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0099365/?ls)
, directed by
Sam Raimi (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000600/?ls)
. From there, Neeson starred in
Under Suspicion (1991) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0105691/?ls)
and
Ethan Frome (1993) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0106833/?ls)
, was hailed for his performance in
Woody Allen (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000095/?ls)
's
Husbands and Wives (1992) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0104466/?ls)
, and ultimately was picked by
Steven Spielberg (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000229/?ls)
to play Oskar Schindler in
Schindler's List (1993) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0108052/?ls)
. The starring role in the Oscar-winning Holocaust film brought Neeson Academy Award, BAFTA and Golden Globe nominations for Best Actor.
Also in 1993, he made his Broadway debut with a Tony-nominated performance in "Anna Christie", in which he co-starred with his future wife
Natasha Richardson (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001670/?ls)
. The next year, the two also starred opposite
Jodie Foster (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000149/?ls)
in the movie
Nell (1994) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0110638/?ls)
, and were married in July of that year. Leading roles as the 18th century Scottish Highlander
Rob Roy (1995) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0114287/?ls)
and the Irish revolutionary leader
Michael Collins (1996) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0117039/?ls)
followed, and soon Neeson was solidified as one of Hollywood's top leading men. He starred in the highly-anticipated
Star Wars: Episode I - The Phantom Menace (1999) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0120915/?ls)
as Qui-Gon Jinn, received a Golden Globe nomination for
Kinsey (2004) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0362269/?ls)
, played the mysterious Ducard in
Christopher Nolan (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0634240/?ls)
's
Batman Begins (2005) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0372784/?ls)
, and provided the voice for Aslan in
The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe (2005) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0363771/?ls)
.
Neeson found a second surprise career as an action leading man with the release of
Taken (2008) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0936501/?ls)
in early 2009, an unexpected box office hit about a retired CIA agent attempting to rescue his daughter from being sold into prostitution. However, less than two months after the release of the film, tragedy struck when his wife Natasha Richardson suffered a fatal head injury while skiing and passed away days afterward. Neeson returned to high-profile roles in 2010 with two back-to-back big-budget films,
Clash of the Titans (2010) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0800320/?ls)
and
The A-Team (2010) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0429493/?ls)
, and returned to the action genre with
Unknown (2011) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1401152/?ls)
,
The Grey (2011) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1601913/?ls)
,
Battleship (2012) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1440129/?ls)
and
Taken 2 (2012) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1397280/?ls)
, as well as the sequel
Wrath of the Titans (2012) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1646987/?ls)
.
Neeson was awarded Officer of the Order of the British Empire in the
1999 Queen's New Year's Honours List for his services to drama. He has two sons from his marriage to Richardson: Micheal Richard Antonio Neeson (born June 22, 1995) and Daniel Jack Neeson (born August 27, 1996).

27. Kate Winslet (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000701/?ref_=ls_t_27)
Actress
Producer
Director
Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind (2004) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0338013/?ref_=ls_knf_27)
Ask Kate Winslet what she likes about any of her characters, and the word "ballsy" is bound to pop up at least once. The British actress has made a point of eschewing straightforward pretty-girl parts in favor of more devilish damsels; as a result, she's built an eclectic resume that runs the gamut from Shakespearean tragedy to modern-day mysticism and erotica.
Kate Elizabeth Winslet was born in Reading, Berkshire, into a family of thespians -- parents
Roger Winslet (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0935474/?ls)
and Sally Anne Bridges-Winslet were both stage actors, maternal grandparents Oliver and Linda Bridges ran the Reading Repertory Theatre, and uncle
Robert Bridges (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0108788/?ls)
was a fixture in London's West End theatre district. Kate came into her talent at an early age. She scored her first professional gig at eleven, dancing opposite the Honey Monster in a commercial for a kids' cereal. She started acting lessons around the same time, which led to formal training at a performing arts high school. Over the next few years, she appeared on stage regularly and landed a few bit parts in sitcoms. Her first big break came at age 17, when she was cast as an obsessive adolescent in
Heavenly Creatures (1994) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0110005/?ls)
. The film, based on the true story of two fantasy-gripped girls who commit a brutal murder, received modest distribution but was roundly praised by critics.
Still a relative unknown, Winslet attended a cattle call audition the next year for
Ang Lee (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000487/?ls)
's
Sense and Sensibility (1995) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0114388/?ls)
. She made an immediate impression on the film's star,
Emma Thompson (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000668/?ls)
, and beat out more than a hundred other hopefuls for the part of plucky Marianne Dashwood. Her efforts were rewarded with both a British Academy Award and an Oscar nomination for Best Supporting Actress. Winslet followed up with two more period pieces, playing the rebellious heroine in
Jude (1996) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0116722/?ls)
and Ophelia in
Kenneth Branagh (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000110/?ls)
's
Hamlet (1996) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0116477/?ls)
.
The role that transformed Winslet from art house attraction to international star was Rose DeWitt Bukater, the passionate, rosy-cheeked aristocrat in
James Cameron (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000116/?ls)
's
Titanic (1997) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0120338/?ls)
. Young girls the world over both idolized and identified with Winslet, swooning over all that face time opposite heartthrob
Leonardo DiCaprio (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000138/?ls)
and noting her refreshingly healthy, unemaciated physique. Winslet's performance also garnered a Best Actress nomination, making her the youngest actress to ever receive two Academy Award nominations.
After the swell of unexpected attention surrounding
Titanic (1997) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0120338/?ls)
, Winslet was eager to retreat into independent projects. Rumor has it that she turned down the lead roles in both
Shakespeare in Love (1998) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0138097/?ls)
and
Anna and the King (1999) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0166485/?ls)
in order to play adventurous soul searchers in
Hideous Kinky (1998) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0136244/?ls)
and
Holy Smoke (1999) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0144715/?ls)
. The former cast her as a young single mother traveling through 1970s Morocco with her daughters in tow; the latter, as a zealous follower of a guru tricked into a "deprogramming" session in the Australian outback. The next year found her back in period dress as the Marquis de Sade's chambermaid and accomplice in
Quills (2000) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0180073/?ls)
. Kate holds the distinction of being the youngest actor ever honored with four Academy Award nominations (she received her fourth at age 29). As of 2016, she has been nominated for an Oscar seven times, winning one of them: she received the Best Actress Oscar for the drama
The Reader (2008) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0976051/?ls)
, playing a former concentration camp guard.
For her performance of Joanna Hoffman in
Steve Jobs (2015) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2080374/?ls)
, she received her seventh Academy Award nomination.
Off camera, Winslet is known for her mischievous pranks and familial devotion. She has two sisters,
Anna Winslet (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0935472/?ls)
and
Beth Winslet (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0935473/?ls)
(both actresses), and a brother, Joss.
In 1998, she married assistant director
Jim Threapleton (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0861909/?ls)
. They had a daughter, Mia Honey Threapleton, in October 2000. They divorced in 2001. She later married director
Sam Mendes (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0005222/?ls)
in 2003 and gave birth to their son, Joe Alfie Winslet-Mendes, later that year. After seven years of marriage, in February 2010 they announced that they had amicably separated, and divorced in October 2010. In 2012, Kate married Ned Rocknroll, with whom she has a son. She was awarded Commander of the Most Excellent Order of the British Empire in the 2012 Queen's Birthday Honours List for her services to Drama.
