28. Sean Connery (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000125/?ref_=ls_t_28)
Actor
Producer
Director
Dr. No (1962) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0055928/?ref_=ls_knf_28)
The tall, handsome and muscular Scottish actor Sean Connery is best known as the original actor to portray James Bond in the hugely successful movie franchise, starring in seven films between 1962 and 1983. Some believed that such a career-defining role might leave him unable to escape it, but he proved the doubters wrong, becoming one of the most notable film actors of his generation, with a host of great movies to his name. This arguably culminated in his greatest acclaim in 1988, when Connery won the Academy Award for Best Supporting Actor for his role as an Irish cop in
The Untouchables (1987) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0094226/?ls)
, stealing the thunder from the movie's principal star
Kevin Costner (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000126/?ls)
. Connery was polled as "The Greatest Living Scot" and "Scotland's Greatest Living National Treasure." In 1989, he was proclaimed "Sexiest Man Alive" by People magazine, and in 1999, at age 69, he was proclaimed "Sexiest Man of the Century."
Thomas "Sean" Connery was born on August 25, 1930 in Fountainbridge, Edinburgh. His mother, Euphemia Maclean, was a cleaning lady, and his father, Joseph Connery, was a factory worker and truck driver. He also had a brother,
Neil Connery (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0175227/?ls)
, a plasterer in Edinburgh, who was eight years younger. Before going into acting, Sean had many different jobs, such as a milkman, lorry driver, a laborer, artist's model for the Edinburgh College of Art, coffin polisher and bodybuilder. He also joined the Royal Navy, but was later discharged because of medical problems. At the age of 23, he had a choice between becoming a professional soccer player or an actor, and even though he showed much promise in the sport, he chose acting and said it was one of his more intelligent decisions.
No Road Back (1957) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0050772/?ls)
was Sean's first major movie role, and it was followed by several made-for-TV movies such as
Anna Christie (1957) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0313207/?ls)
,
Macbeth (1961) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0400618/?ls)
and
Anna Karenina (1961) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0267267/?ls)
as well as guest appearances on TV series, and also films such as
Hell Drivers (1957) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0051713/?ls)
,
Another Time, Another Place (1958) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0051364/?ls)
,
Darby O'Gill and the Little People (1959) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0052722/?ls)
and
The Frightened City (1961) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0054898/?ls)
. In 1962 he appeared in
The Longest Day (1962) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0056197/?ls)
with a host of other stars.
His big breakthrough came in 1962 when he landed the role of secret agent James Bond in
Dr. No (1962) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0055928/?ls)
. He played James Bond in six more films:
From Russia with Love (1963) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0057076/?ls)
,
Goldfinger (1964) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0058150/?ls)
,
Thunderball (1965) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0059800/?ls)
,
You Only Live Twice (1967) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0062512/?ls)
,
Diamonds Are Forever (1971) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0066995/?ls)
and
Never Say Never Again (1983) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0086006/?ls)
.
After and during the success of the Bond films, he maintained a successful career as an actor and has appeared in films, including
Alfred Hitchcock (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000033/?ls)
's
Marnie (1964) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0058329/?ls)
,
The Hill (1965) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0059274/?ls)
,
Murder on the Orient Express (1974) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0071877/?ls)
,
The Man Who Would Be King (1975) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0073341/?ls)
,
The Wind and the Lion (1975) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0073906/?ls)
,
Time Bandits (1981) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0081633/?ls)
,
Highlander (1986) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0091203/?ls)
,
The Name of the Rose (1986) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0091605/?ls)
,
Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade (1989) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0097576/?ls)
,
The Hunt for Red October (1990) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0099810/?ls)
,
Rising Sun (1993) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0107969/?ls)
,
The Rock (1996) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0117500/?ls)
,
Finding Forrester (2000) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0181536/?ls)
and
The League of Extraordinary Gentlemen (2003) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0311429/?ls)
.
Sean married actress
Diane Cilento (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0162283/?ls)
in 1962 and they had Sean's only child,
Jason Connery (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001064/?ls)
, born on January 11, 1963. The couple announced their separation in February 1971 and filed for divorce 2½ years later. Sean then dated
Jill St. John (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001762/?ls)
,
Lana Wood (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0939836/?ls)
,
Magda Konopka (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0465260/?ls)
and
Carole Mallory (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0540098/?ls)
. In 1975 he married
Micheline Roquebrune (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm1315689/?ls)
and they stayed married, despite Sean's well-documented love affair with
Lynsey de Paul (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0210880/?ls)
in the late '80s. Sean had three stepchildren through his marriage to Micheline, who was one year his senior. He is also a grandfather. His son, Jason and Jason's ex-wife, actress
Mia Sara (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000214/?ls)
had a son,
Dashiell Connery (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm2330321/?ls)
, in 1997.
Sean Connery died at the age of 90 on October 31, 2020, in Nassau, the Bahamas, where he resided for many years.
[No Text] (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000242/?ref_=ls_i_29)
29. Mark Wahlberg (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000242/?ref_=ls_t_29)
Producer
Actor
Composer
The Fighter (2010) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0964517/?ref_=ls_knf_29)
American actor Mark Wahlberg is one of a handful of respected entertainers who successfully made the transition from teen pop idol to acclaimed actor. A Best Supporting Actor Oscar nominee for
The Departed (2006) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0407887/?ls)
who went on to receive positive critical reviews for his performance in
The Fighter (2010) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0964517/?ls)
, Wahlberg also is a solid comedy actor, proven by his starring role in
Ted (2012) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1637725/?ls)
.
Mark Robert Michael Wahlberg was born June 5, 1971 in a poor working class district, Dorchester, of Boston, Massachusetts. He is the son of Alma Elaine (Donnelly), a nurse's aide and clerk, and Donald Edward Wahlberg, a delivery driver. Wahlberg is the youngest of nine children. He is of Swedish (from his paternal grandfather), French-Canadian, English, Irish and Scottish, descent. The large Wahlberg brood didn't have a lot growing up, especially after his parents divorced when he was eleven. The kids crammed into a three-bedroom apartment, none of them having very much privacy. Mark's mother has said that after the divorce, she became very self-absorbed with her own life. She has blamed herself for her son's subsequent problems and delinquency. Wahlberg dropped out of high school at age fourteen (but later got his GED) to pursue a life of petty crime and drugs. He'd spend his days scamming and stealing, working on the odd drug deal before treating himself to the substances.
The young man also had a violent streak - one which was often aimed at minorities. At age sixteen, he was convicted of assault against two Vietnamese men after he had tried to rob them. As a result of his assault conviction, he was sentenced to serve 50 days in prison at Deer Island penitentiary. Whilst there, he began working out to pass time and, when he emerged at the end of his sentence, he had gone from being a scrawny young kid to a buff young man. Wahlberg also credits jail time as being his motivation to improve his lifestyle and leave crime behind him.
Around this time, his older brother
Donnie Wahlberg (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0005531/?ls)
had become an overnight teen idol as a member of the 1980s boy band
New Kids on the Block (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm1578753/?ls)
. A precursor to the boy-band craze, the group was dominating the charts and were on top of their game. Mark himself had been an original member of the band but had backed out early on - uncomfortable with the squeaky clean image of the group. Donnie used his connections in the music business to help his little brother secure a recording contract, and soon the world was introduced to Marky Mark and the Funky Bunch, with Wahlberg as a bad-boy rapper who danced in his boxers. Despite a lack of singing ability, promoters took to his dance moves and a physique they knew teenage girls would love.
Donnie scripted some easy songs for Mark, who collected a troupe of dancers and a DJ to become his "Funky Bunch" and "Marky Mark and the Funky Bunch" was born. His debut album, "Music for the People", was a smash hit, which was propelled along by the rapper's willingness to disrobe down to boxer-briefs on stage, not to mention several catchy tunes. Teenage girls thrilled to the rapping "bad boy". Record producer
David Geffen (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0311691/?ls)
saw in Wahlberg a cash-cow of marketing ability. After speaking to designer
Calvin Klein (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0458681/?ls)
, Marky Mark was set up as the designer's chief underwear model.
His scantily clad figure soon adorned billboards across the nation. Ironically, while the
New Kids on the Block (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm1578753/?ls)
's fame was dwindling as audiences tired of their syrupy lyrics, "Marky Mark's" bad boy image was becoming even more of a commodity. He was constantly in the headlines (often of the tabloids) after multiple scandals. In 1992, he released a book dedicated to his penis. Wahlberg was constantly getting into rumored fights, most memorably with
Madonna (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000187/?ls)
and her entourage at a Los Angeles party. While things were always intense, they were relatively harmless and made for enjoyable reading for the public. However, when the story of his arrest for assault (and the allegations of racism) broke in the press, things took on a decidedly darker note. People were not amused. Soon after, while on a British talk show along with rapper
Shabba Ranks (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm1133072/?ls)
, he got into even more trouble. After Ranks made the statement that gays should be crucified, Wahlberg was accused of condoning the comments by his silence. Marky Mark was suddenly surrounded by charges of brutality, homophobia and racial hatred. His second album, "You Gotta Believe", had not been faring well and, after the charges surfaced, it plummeted from the charts.
Adding to the hoopla, Wahlberg was brought to court for allegedly assaulting a security guard. He was ordered to make amends by appearing in a series of anti-bias advertisements. Humbled and humiliated by his fall from grace in the music world, Wahlberg decided to pursue another angle, acting. He dropped the "Marky Mark" moniker and became known simply as Mark Wahlberg. His first big screen role came in
Penny Marshall (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001508/?ls)
's
Renaissance Man (1994) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0110971/?ls)
. Despite the name change, many people snickered at the idea of the has-been rapper thinking he could make it as an actor. From the get-go, he was proving them wrong. In
Renaissance Man (1994) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0110971/?ls)
, he gave an utterly charming performance as a simple but sincere army recruit. What naysayers remained found it increasingly difficult to write Mark Wahlberg off as he delivered one fine performance after another. He blew them away in the controversial
The Basketball Diaries (1995) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0112461/?ls)
and chilled them in
Fear (1996) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0116287/?ls)
as every father's worst nightmare.
The major turning point in Wahlberg's career came with the role of troubled porn star Dirk Diggler in
Paul Thomas Anderson (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000759/?ls)
's
Boogie Nights (1997) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0118749/?ls)
. Since then, Wahlberg has chosen roles that demonstrate a wide range of dramatic ability, starring in critically acclaimed dramas such as
Three Kings (1999) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0120188/?ls)
and
The Perfect Storm (2000) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0177971/?ls)
, popcorn flicks like
Planet of the Apes (2001) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0133152/?ls)
and
Contraband (2012) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1524137/?ls)
, and even indies such as
I Heart Huckabees (2004) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0356721/?ls)
.
Wahlberg was the executive producer of such television series as
Boardwalk Empire (2010) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0979432/?ls)
,
In Treatment (2008) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0835434/?ls)
and the highly successful comedy
Entourage (2004) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0387199/?ls)
, which was partly based on his experiences in Hollywood.
Wahlberg and his wife
Rhea Durham (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm1081113/?ls)
have four children.

30. Natalie Portman (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000204/?ref_=ls_t_30)
Actress
Producer
Director
Black Swan (2010) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0947798/?ref_=ls_knf_30)
Natalie Portman is the first person born in the 1980s to have won the Academy Award for Best Actress (for
Black Swan (2010) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0947798/?ls)
).
Natalie was born Natalie Hershlag on June 9, 1981, in Jerusalem, Israel. She is the only child of Avner Hershlag, an Israeli-born doctor, and Shelley Stevens, an American-born artist (from Cincinnati, Ohio), who also acts as Natalie's agent. Her parents are both of Ashkenazi Jewish descent. Natalie's family left Israel for Washington, D.C., when she was still very young. After a few more moves, her family finally settled in New York, where she still lives to this day. She graduated with honors, and her academic achievements allowed her to attend Harvard University. She was discovered by an agent in a pizza parlor at the age of 11. She was pushed towards a career in modeling but she decided that she would rather pursue a career in acting. She was featured in many live performances, but she made her powerful film debut in the movie
Léon: The Professional (1994) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0110413/?ls)
(aka "Léon"). Following this role Natalie won roles in such films as
Heat (1995) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0113277/?ls)
,
Beautiful Girls (1996) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0115639/?ls)
, and
Mars Attacks! (1996) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0116996/?ls)
.
It was not until 1999 that Natalie received worldwide fame as Queen Amidala in the highly anticipated US$431 million-grossing prequel
Star Wars: Episode I - The Phantom Menace (1999) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0120915/?ls)
. She then she starred in two critically acclaimed comedy dramas,
Anywhere But Here (1999) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0149691/?ls)
and
Where the Heart Is (2000) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0198021/?ls)
, followed by
Closer (2004) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0376541/?ls)
, for which she received an Oscar nomination. She reprised her role as Padme Amidala in the last two episodes of the Star Wars prequel trilogy:
Star Wars: Episode II - Attack of the Clones (2002) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0121765/?ls)
and
Star Wars: Episode III - Revenge of the Sith (2005) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0121766/?ls)
. She received an Academy Award and a Golden Globe Award for Best Actress in
Black Swan (2010) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0947798/?ls)
.
She received a second nomination for Best Actress, for playing
Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0448080/?ls)
in
Jackie (2016) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1619029/?ls)
.

31. Pierce Brosnan (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000112/?ref_=ls_t_31)

Pierce Brendan Brosnan was born in Drogheda, County Louth, Ireland, to May
(Smith), a nurse, and Thomas Brosnan, a carpenter. He lived in Navan,
County Meath, until he moved to England, UK, at an early age (thus
explaining his ability to play men from both backgrounds convincingly).
His father left the household when Pierce was a child and although
reunited later in life, the two have never had a close relationship.
His most popular role is that of British secret agent James Bond. The
death, in 1991, of
Cassandra Harris (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0364520/?ls)
, his wife of
eleven years, left him with three children - Christopher and Charlotte
from Cassandra's first marriage and Sean from their marriage. Since her
death, he has had two children with his second wife,
Keely Shaye Brosnan (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0005444/?ls)
.
Brosnan is most famous for starring in the TV series
Remington Steele (1982) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0083470/?ls)
as the title character, as well as portraying famous movie character James Bond in
GoldenEye (1995) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0113189/?ls)
,
Tomorrow Never Dies (1997) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0120347/?ls)
,
The World Is Not Enough (1999) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0143145/?ls)
and
Die Another Day (2002) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0246460/?ls)
.

32. Keanu Reeves (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000206/?ref_=ls_t_32)
Actor
Producer
Additional Crew
The Matrix (1999) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0133093/?ref_=ls_knf_32)
Keanu Charles Reeves, whose first name means "cool breeze over the mountains" in Hawaiian, was born September 2, 1964 in Beirut, Lebanon. He is the son of
Patric Reeves (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0852983/?ls)
, a showgirl and costume designer, and Samuel Nowlin Reeves, a geologist. Keanu's father was born in Hawaii, of Native Hawaiian and Chinese ancestry while Keanu's mother is originally from Essex England. After his parents' marriage dissolved, Keanu moved with his mother and younger sister,
Kim Reeves (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0716238/?ls)
, to New York City, then Toronto. Stepfather #1 was
Paul Aaron (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0007477/?ls)
, a stage and film director - he and Patricia divorced within a year, after which she went on to marry (and divorce) rock promoter Robert Miller. Reeves never reconnected with his biological father. In high school, Reeves was lukewarm toward academics but took a keen interest in ice hockey (as team goalie, he earned the nickname "The Wall") and drama. He eventually dropped out of school to pursue an acting career.
After a few stage gigs and a handful of made-for-TV movies, he scored a supporting role in the
Rob Lowe (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000507/?ls)
hockey flick
Youngblood (1986) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0092272/?ls)
, which was filmed in Canada. Shortly after the production wrapped, Reeves packed his bags and headed for Hollywood. Reeves popped up on critics' radar with his performance in the dark adolescent drama,
River's Edge (1986) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0091860/?ls)
, and landed a supporting role in the Oscar-nominated
Dangerous Liaisons (1988) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0094947/?ls)
with director
Stephen Frears (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001241/?ls)
.
His first popular success was the role of totally rad dude Ted "Theodore" Logan in
Bill & Ted's Excellent Adventure (1989) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0096928/?ls)
. The wacky time-travel movie became something of a cultural phenomenon, and audiences would forever confuse Reeves's real-life persona with that of his doofy on-screen counterpart. He then joined the casts of
Ron Howard (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000165/?ls)
's comedy,
Parenthood (1989) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0098067/?ls)
and
Lawrence Kasdan (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001410/?ls)
's
I Love You to Death (1990) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0099819/?ls)
.
Over the next few years, Reeves tried to shake the Ted stigma with a series of highbrow projects. He played a slumming rich boy opposite
River Phoenix (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000203/?ls)
's narcoleptic male hustler in
My Own Private Idaho (1991) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0102494/?ls)
, an unlucky lawyer who stumbles into the vampire's lair in
Dracula (1992) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0103874/?ls)
, and Shakespearean party-pooper Don John in
Much Ado About Nothing (1993) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0107616/?ls)
.
In 1994, the understated actor became a big-budget action star with the release of
Speed (1994) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0111257/?ls)
. Its success heralded an era of five years in which Reeves would alternate between small films, like
Feeling Minnesota (1996) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0116289/?ls)
and
The Last Time I Committed Suicide (1997) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0119502/?ls)
, and big films like
A Walk in the Clouds (1995) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0114887/?ls)
and
The Devil's Advocate (1997) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0118971/?ls)
. (There were a couple misfires, too:
Johnny Mnemonic (1995) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0113481/?ls)
and
Chain Reaction (1996) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0115857/?ls)
.) After all this, Reeves did the unthinkable and passed on the Speed sequel, but he struck box-office gold again a few years later with the Wachowski siblings' cyberadventure,
The Matrix (1999) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0133093/?ls)
.
Now a bonafide box-office star, Keanu would appear in a string of smaller films -- among them
The Replacements (2000) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0191397/?ls)
,
The Watcher (2000) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0204626/?ls)
,
The Gift (2000) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0219699/?ls)
,
Sweet November (2001) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0230838/?ls)
, and
Hardball (2001) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0180734/?ls)
- before
The Matrix Reloaded (2003) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0234215/?ls)
and
The Matrix Revolutions (2003) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0242653/?ls)
were both released in 2003.
Since the end of The Matrix trilogy, Keanu has divided his time between mainstream and indie fare, landing hits with
Something's Gotta Give (2003) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0337741/?ls)
,
The Lake House (2006) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0410297/?ls)
, and
Street Kings (2008) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0421073/?ls)
. He's kept Matrix fans satiated with films such as
Constantine (2005) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0360486/?ls)
,
A Scanner Darkly (2006) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0405296/?ls)
, and
The Day the Earth Stood Still (2008) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0970416/?ls)
. And he's waded back into art-house territory with
Ellie Parker (2005) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0436262/?ls)
,
Thumbsucker (2005) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0318761/?ls)
,
The Private Lives of Pippa Lee (2009) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1134629/?ls)
, and
Henry's Crime (2010) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1220888/?ls)
.
Most recently, as post-production on the samurai epic
47 Ronin (2013) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1335975/?ls)
waged on, Keanu appeared in front of the camera in
Side by Side (2012) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2014338/?ls)
, a documentary on celluloid and digital filmmaking, which he also produced. He also directed another Asian-influenced project,
Man of Tai Chi (2013) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2016940/?ls)
.
In 2014, Keanu played the title role in the action revenge film
John Wick (2014) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2911666/?ls)
, which became popular with critics and audiences alike. He reprised the role in
John Wick: Chapter 2 (2017) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt4425200/?ls)
, taking the now-iconic character to a better opening weekend and even more enthusiastic reviews than the first go-around.

33. Orlando Bloom (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0089217/?ref_=ls_t_33)
Actor
Producer
Soundtrack
The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring (2001) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0120737/?ref_=ls_knf_33)
Orlando Jonathan Blanchard Copeland Bloom was born on January 13, 1977 in Canterbury, Kent, England. His mother, Sonia Constance Josephine Bloom (née Copeland),
was born in Kolkata, India, to an English family then-resident there.
The man he first knew as his father, Harry Bloom, was a legendary
political activist who fought for civil rights in South Africa. But
Harry died of a stroke when Orlando was only four years old. After
that, Orlando and his older sister,
Samantha Bloom (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm1043808/?ls)
, were raised by their
mother and family friend, Colin Stone. When Orlando was 13, Sonia
revealed to him that Colin is actually the biological father of Orlando and his sister; the two were conceived after an agreement by his parents, since Harry, who suffered a stroke in 1975, was unable to have children.
Orlando attended St. Edmund's School in Canterbury but struggled in many
courses because of dyslexia. He did embrace the arts, however, and
enjoyed pottery, photography and sculpturing. He also participated in
school plays and was active at his local theater. As a teen, Orlando
landed his first job: he was a clay trapper at a pigeon shooting range.
Encouraged by his mother, he and his sister began studying poetry and
prose, eventually giving readings at Kent Festival. Orlando and
Samantha won many poetry and Bible reciting competitions. Then Orlando,
who always idolized larger-than-life characters, gravitated towards
serious acting. At the age of 16, he moved to London and joined the
National Youth Theatre, spending two seasons there and gaining a
scholarship to train with the British American Drama Academy. Like many
young actors, he also auditioned for a number of television roles to
further his career, landing bit parts in British television shows
Casualty (1986) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0096555/?ls)
,
Midsomer Murders (1997) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0118401/?ls)
and
Smack the Pony (1999) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0195275/?ls)
. He also
appeared in the critically acclaimed movie
Wilde (1997) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0120514/?ls)
.
He then attended the Guildhall School of Music and Drama. It was there,
in 1998, that Orlando fell three stories from a rooftop terrace and
broke his back. Despite fears that he would be permanently paralyzed,
he quickly recovered and returned to the stage. As fate would have it,
seated in the audience one night in 1999 was a director named
Peter Jackson (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001392/?ls)
. After the show, he
met with Orlando and asked him to audition for his new set of movies.
After graduating from Guildhall, Orlando began work on the "Lord of the
Rings" trilogy, spending 18 months in New Zealand bringing to life
"Legolas", a part which made him a household name. Today, he is one of
the busiest and most sought-after actors in the industry.

34. Dwayne Johnson (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0425005/?ref_=ls_t_34)
Actor
Producer
Writer
Black Adam (2022) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt6443346/?ref_=ls_knf_34)
Dwayne Douglas Johnson, also known as The Rock, was born on May 2, 1972 in Hayward, California. He is the son of
Ata Johnson (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm1696097/?ls)
(born Feagaimaleata Fitisemanu) and professional wrestler
Rocky Johnson (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0426117/?ls)
(born Wayde Douglas Bowles). His father, from Amherst, Nova Scotia, Canada, is black (of Black Nova Scotian descent), and his mother is of Samoan background (her own father was
Peter Fanene Maivia (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0537990/?ls)
, also a professional wrestler). While growing up, Dwayne traveled around a lot with his parents and watched his father perform in the ring. During his high school years, Dwayne began playing football and he soon received a full scholarship from the University of Miami, where he had tremendous success as a football player. In 1995, Dwayne suffered a back injury which cost him a place in the NFL. He then signed a three-year deal with the Canadian League but left after a year to pursue a career in wrestling.
He made his wrestling debut in the USWA under the name Flex Kavanah where he won the tag team championship with Brett Sawyer. In 1996, Dwayne joined the WWE and became Rocky Maivia where he joined a group known as "The Nation of Domination" and turned heel. Rocky eventually took over leadership of the "Nation" and began taking the persona of The Rock. After the "Nation" split, The Rock joined another elite group of wrestlers known as the "Corporation" and began a memorable feud with
Steve Austin (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0042524/?ls)
. Soon the Rock was kicked out of the "Corporation". He turned face and became known as "The Peoples Champion". In 2000, the Rock took time off from WWE to film his appearance in
The Mummy Returns (2001) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0209163/?ls)
. He returned in 2001 during the WCW/ECW invasion where he joined a team of WWE wrestlers at
The Scorpion King (2002) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0277296/?ls)
, a prequel to
The Mummy Returns (2001) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0209163/?ls)
.
Dwayne has a daughter,
Simone Alexandra Johnson (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm9426887/?ls)
, born in 2001, with his ex-wife
Dany Garcia (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm1696098/?ls)
, and daughters, Jasmine, born in 2015, and Tiana Gia, born in 2018, with his wife, singer and songwriter
Lauren Hashian (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm3369405/?ls)
.

35. Jackie Chan (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000329/?ref_=ls_t_35)
Producer
Actor
Stunts
Who Am I? (1998) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0127357/?ref_=ls_knf_35)
Hong Kong's cheeky, lovable and best-known film star, Jackie Chan endured many years of long, hard work and multiple injuries to establish international success after his start in Hong Kong's manic martial arts cinema industry.
Jackie was born Kong-sang Chan on April 7, 1954, on Hong Kong's famous Victoria Peak, to Charles and Lee-Lee Chan, and the family immigrated to Canberra, Australia, in early 1960. The young Jackie was less than successful scholastically, so his father sent him back to Hong Kong to attend the rigorous China Drama Academy, one of the Peking Opera schools. Chan excelled at acrobatics, singing and martial arts and eventually became a member of the "Seven Little Fortunes" performing troupe and began lifelong friendships with fellow martial artists / actors
Sammo Kam-Bo Hung (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0005033/?ls)
and
Biao Yuen (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0950707/?ls)
. Chan journeyed back and forth to visit his parents and work in Canberra, but eventually he made his way back to Hong Kong as his permanent home. In the early 1970s, Chan commenced his movie career and interestingly appeared in very minor roles in two films starring then rising martial arts superstar
Bruce Lee (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000045/?ls)
:
Fist of Fury (1972) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0068767/?ls)
(aka "The Chinese Connection"), and the Warner Bros. production
Enter the Dragon (1973) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0070034/?ls)
. Not long after Lee's untimely death, Chan was often cast in films cashing in on the success of Bruce Lee by utilizing words like "fist", "fury" or "dragon" in their US release titles.
Chan's own film career was off and running and he swiftly appeared in many low-budget martial arts films that were churned out at a rapid-fire pace by Hong Kong studios eager to satisfy the early 1970s boom in martial-arts cinema. He starred in
Shaolin Wooden Men (1976) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0075201/?ls)
,
To Kill with Intrigue (1977) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0076227/?ls)
,
Half a Loaf of Kung Fu (1978) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0080623/?ls)
and
Magnificent Bodyguards (1978) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0077541/?ls)
, which all fared reasonably well at the cinemas. However, he scored a major breakthrough with the action comedy
Drunken Master (1978) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0080179/?ls)
, which has become a cult favorite among martial arts film fans. Not too long after this, Chan made his directorial debut with
The Young Master (1980) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0081499/?ls)
and then "Enter the Dragon" producer
Robert Clouse (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0167195/?ls)
lured Jackie to the United States for a film planned to break Jackie into the lucrative US market.
Battle Creek Brawl (1980) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0080436/?ls)
featured Jackie competing in a "toughest Street fighter" contest set in 1940s Texas; however, Jackie was unhappy with the end result, and it failed to fire with US audiences. In a further attempt to get his name known in the United States, Jackie was cast alongside
Burt Reynolds (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000608/?ls)
, Sir
Roger Moore (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000549/?ls)
and
Dean Martin (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001509/?ls)
in the
Hal Needham (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0624102/?ls)
-directed car chase film
The Cannonball Run (1981) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0082136/?ls)
. Regrettably, Jackie was cast as a Japanese race driver and his martial arts skills are only shown in one small sequence near the film's conclusion. Stateside success was still a few years away for Jackie Chan!
Undeterred, he returned to East Asia to do what he did best--make jaw-dropping action films loaded with amazing stunt work. Chan and his legendary stunt team were without parallel in their ability to execute the most incredible fight scenes and action sequences, and the next decade would see some of their best work. Chan paired with the dynamic Sammo Kam-Bo Hung to star in
Winners & Sinners (1983) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0086605/?ls)
,
Project A (1983) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0085127/?ls)
,
Wheels on Meals (1984) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0087578/?ls)
,
My Lucky Stars (1985) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0089177/?ls)
(aka "Winners & Sinners 2"),
Twinkle Twinkle Lucky Stars (1985) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0090342/?ls)
(aka "Winners & Sinners 3"). Chan then journeyed back to the United States for another shot at that market, starring alongside
Danny Aiello (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000732/?ls)
in
The Protector (1985) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0089847/?ls)
, filmed in Hong Kong and New York. However, as with previous attempts, Jackie felt the US director--in this case,
James Glickenhaus (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0322785/?ls)
--failed to understand his audience appeal and the film played to lukewarm reviews and box-office receipts. However, Jackie did decide to "harden" up his on-screen image somewhat and his next film,
Police Story (1985) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0089374/?ls)
was a definite departure from previously light-hearted martial arts fare, and his fans loved the final product!
This was quickly followed up with the
Raiders of the Lost Ark (1981) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0082971/?ls)
-influenced
Armour of God (1986) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0091431/?ls)
, during filming of which Jackie mistimed a leap from a wall to a tree on location in Yugoslavia and fell many quite a few feet onto his head, causing a skull fracture. It was another in a long line of injuries that Chan has suffered as a result of doing his own stunt work, and he was soon back in front of the cameras.
Project A 2 (1987) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0092501/?ls)
,
Police Story 2 (1988) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0095403/?ls)
,
Miracles: The Canton Godfather (1989) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0098019/?ls)
(aka "Mr. Canton and Lady Rose)",
Armour of God 2: Operation Condor (1991) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0099558/?ls)
(aka "Armour of God 2") and
Supercop (1992) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0104558/?ls)
(aka "Police Story 3") were all sizable hits for Jackie, escalating his status to phenomenal heights in Asia, and to his loyal fanbase around the globe. US success was now just around the corner for the hard-working Jackie Chan, and it arrived in the form of the action film
Rumble in the Bronx (1995) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0113326/?ls)
(though it was actually filmed in Canada) that successfully blended humor and action to make a winning formula in US theaters.
Jackie did not waste any time and went to work on
First Strike (1996) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0116704/?ls)
(aka "Police Story 4"),
Mr. Nice Guy (1997) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0117786/?ls)
,
Who Am I? (1998) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0127357/?ls)
, which all met with positive results at the international box office. Jackie then went to work in his biggest-budget US production, starring alongside fast-talking comedian
Chris Tucker (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000676/?ls)
in the action comedy
Rush Hour (1998) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0120812/?ls)
. The film was a bigger hit than "Rumble in the Bronx" and firmly established Jackie as a bona fide star in the United States. Jackie then paired up with rising talent
Owen Wilson (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0005562/?ls)
to star in
Shanghai Noon (2000) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0184894/?ls)
and its sequel,
Shanghai Knights (2003) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0300471/?ls)
, and re-teamed with Tucker in
Rush Hour 2 (2001) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0266915/?ls)
, as well as starring in
The Tuxedo (2002) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0290095/?ls)
,
The Medallion (2003) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0288045/?ls)
and the delightful
Around the World in 80 Days (2004) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0327437/?ls)
. Not one to forget his loyal fanbase, Jackie returned to more gritty and traditional fare with
New Police Story (2004) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0386005/?ls)
and
The Myth (2005) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0365847/?ls)
. The multi-talented Chan (he is also a major recording star in Asia) shows no sign of slowing down and has long since moved out of the shadow of Bruce Lee, to whom he was usually compared early in his career.
Chan is truly one of the international film industry's true maverick actor / director / stuntman / producer combinations - he has done this the hard way, and always his way to achieve his dreams and goals to be an international cinematic star. Off screen, he has been directly involved in many philanthropic ventures providing financial assistance to schools and universities around the world. He is a UNICEF GoodWill Ambassador, and he has campaigned against animal abuse and pollution and assisted with disaster relief efforts to the 2004 Indian Ocean Tsunami victims.
[No Text] (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001401/?ref_=ls_i_36)
36. Angelina Jolie (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001401/?ref_=ls_t_36)
Actress
Producer
Director
Maleficent (2014) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1587310/?ref_=ls_knf_36)
Angelina Jolie is an Academy Award-winning actress who rose to fame after her role in
Girl, Interrupted (1999) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0172493/?ls)
, playing the title role in the "Lara Croft" blockbuster movies, as well as
Mr. & Mrs. Smith (2005) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0356910/?ls)
,
Wanted (2008) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0493464/?ls)
,
Salt (2010) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0944835/?ls)
and
Maleficent (2014) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1587310/?ls)
. Off-screen, Jolie has become prominently involved in international charity projects, especially those involving refugees. She often appears on many "most beautiful women" lists, and she has a personal life that is avidly covered by the tabloid press.
Jolie was born Angelina Jolie Voight in Los Angeles, California. In her earliest years, Angelina began absorbing the acting craft from her actor parents,
Jon Voight (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000685/?ls)
, an Oscar-winner, and
Marcheline Bertrand (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0078395/?ls)
, who had studied with
Lee Strasberg (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0833448/?ls)
. Her good looks may derive from her ancestry, which is German and Slovak on her father's side, and French-Canadian, Dutch, Polish, and remote Huron, on her mother's side. At age eleven, Angelina began studying at the
Lee Strasberg (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0833448/?ls)
Theatre Institute, where she was seen in several stage productions. She undertook some film studies at New York University and later joined the renowned Met Theatre Group in Los Angeles. At age 16, she took up a career in modeling and appeared in some music videos.
In the mid-1990s, Jolie appeared in various small films where she got good notices, including
Hackers (1995) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0113243/?ls)
and
Foxfire (1996) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0116353/?ls)
. Her critical acclaim increased when she played strong roles in the made-for-TV movies
True Women (1997) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0118499/?ls)
, and in
George Wallace (1997) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0119189/?ls)
which won her a Golden Globe Award and an Emmy nomination. Jolie's acclaim increased even further when she played the lead role in the HBO production
Gia (1998) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0123865/?ls)
. This was the true life story of supermodel
Gia Carangi (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm1817020/?ls)
, a sensitive wild child who was both brazen and needy and who had a difficult time handling professional success and the deaths of people who were close to her. Carangi became involved with drugs and because of her needle-using habits she became, at the tender age of 26, one of the first celebrities to die of AIDS. Jolie's performance in
Gia (1998) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0123865/?ls)
again garnered a Golden Globe Award and another Emmy nomination, and she additionally earned a SAG Award.
Angelina got a major break in 1999 when she won a leading role in the successful feature
The Bone Collector (1999) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0145681/?ls)
, starring alongside
Denzel Washington (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000243/?ls)
. In that same year, Jolie gave a tour de force performance in
Girl, Interrupted (1999) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0172493/?ls)
playing opposite
Winona Ryder (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000213/?ls)
. The movie was a true story of women who spent time in a psychiatric hospital. Jolie's role was reminiscent of
Jack Nicholson (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000197/?ls)
's character in
One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest (1975) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0073486/?ls)
, the role which won Nicholson his first Oscar. Unlike "Cuckoo," "Girl" was a small film that received mixed reviews and barely made money at the box office. But when it came time to give out awards, Jolie won the triple crown -- "Girl" propelled her to win the Golden Globe Award, the SAG Award and the Academy Award for best leading actress in a supporting role.
With her newfound prominence, Jolie began to get in-depth attention from the press. Numerous aspects of her controversial personal life became news. At her wedding to her
Hackers (1995) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0113243/?ls)
co-star
Jonny Lee Miller (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001538/?ls)
, she had displayed her husband's name on the back of her shirt painted in her own blood. Jolie and Miller divorced, and in 2000, she married her
Pushing Tin (1999) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0120797/?ls)
co-star
Billy Bob Thornton (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000671/?ls)
. Jolie had become the fifth wife of a man twenty years her senior. During her marriage to Thornton, the spouses each wore a vial of the other's blood around their necks. That marriage came apart in 2002 and ended in divorce. In addition, Jolie was estranged from her famous father,
Jon Voight (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000685/?ls)
.
In 2000, Jolie was asked to star in
Lara Croft: Tomb Raider (2001) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0146316/?ls)
. At first, she expressed disinterest, but then decided that the required training for the athletic role was intriguing. The eponymous character was drawn from a popular video game. Lara Croft was a female cross between Indiana Jones and James Bond. When the movie was released, critics were unimpressed with the final product, but critical acclaim wasn't the point of the movie. The public paid $275 million for theater tickets to see a buffed up Jolie portray the adventuresome Lara Croft. Jolie's father
Jon Voight (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000685/?ls)
appeared in the movie, and during filming there was a brief rapprochement between father and daughter.
One of the Lara Croft movie's filming locations was Cambodia. While there, Jolie witnessed the natural beauty, culture and poverty of that country. She considered this an eye opening experience, and so began the humanitarian chapter of her life. Jolie began visiting refugee camps around the world and came to be formally appointed as a Goodwill Ambassador for the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR). Some of her experiences were written and published in her popular book "Notes from My Travels" whose profits go to UNHCR.
Jolie has stated that she now plans to spend most of her time in humanitarian efforts, to be financed by her actress salary. She devotes one third of her income to savings, one third to living expenses and one third to charity. In 2002, Angelina adopted a Cambodian refugee boy named Maddox, and in 2005, adopted an Ethiopian refugee girl named Zahara. Jolie's dramatic feature film
Beyond Borders (2003) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0294357/?ls)
parallels some of her real life humanitarian experiences although, despite the inclusion of a romance between two westerners, many of the movie's images were too depressingly realistic -- the movie was not popular among critics or at the box office.
In 2004, Jolie began filming
Mr. & Mrs. Smith (2005) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0356910/?ls)
with co-star
Brad Pitt (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000093/?ls)
. The movie became a major box office success. There were rumors that Pitt and Jolie had an affair while filming Mr. and Mrs. Smith. Jolie insisted that because her mother had been hurt by adultery, she herself could never participate in an affair with a married man, therefore there had been no affair with Pitt at that time. Nonetheless, Pitt separated from his wife
Jennifer Aniston (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000098/?ls)
in January 2005 and, in the months that followed, he was frequently seen in public with Jolie, apparently as a couple. Pitt's divorce was finalized later in 2005.
Jolie and Pitt announced in early 2006 that they would have a child together, and Jolie gave birth to daughter Shiloh that May. They also adopted a three-year-old Vietnamese boy named Pax. The couple, who married in 2014 and divorced in 2019, continue to pursue movie and humanitarian projects, and now have a total of six children. She was appointed Honorary Dame Commander of the Order of St. Michael and St. George at the 2014 Queen's Birthday Honours for her services to United Kingdom foreign policy and the campaign to end warzone sexual violence.

37. Adam Sandler (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001191/?ref_=ls_t_37)
Actor
Producer
Writer
The Waterboy (1998) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0120484/?ref_=ls_knf_37)
Adam Richard Sandler was born September 9, 1966 in Brooklyn, New York, to Judith (Levine), a teacher at a nursery school, and Stanley Alan Sandler, an electrical engineer. He is of Russian Jewish descent. At 17, he took his first step towards becoming a stand-up comedian when he spontaneously took the stage at a Boston comedy club. He found he was a natural comic. He nurtured his talent while at New York University (graduating with a Bachelor of Fine Arts degree in 1991) by performing regularly in clubs and at universities. During his freshman year, he snagged a recurring role as the Huxtable family's friend Smitty on
The Cosby Show (1984) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0086687/?ls)
. While working at a comedy club in L.A., he was "discovered" by
Dennis Miller (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0588222/?ls)
, who recommended him to
Saturday Night Live (1975) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0072562/?ls)
producer
Lorne Michaels (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0584427/?ls)
and told him that
Sandler had a big talent. This led to his being cast in the show in 1990, which he also wrote for in addition to performing. After
Saturday Night Live (1975) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0072562/?ls)
, Sandler went on to the movies, starring in such hit comedies as
Airheads (1994) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0109068/?ls)
,
Happy Gilmore (1996) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0116483/?ls)
,
Billy Madison (1995) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0112508/?ls)
and
Big Daddy (1999) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0142342/?ls)
. He has also starred in
Mr. Deeds (2002) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0280590/?ls)
alongside
Winona Ryder (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000213/?ls)
;
Eight Crazy Nights (2002) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0271263/?ls)
, an animated movie about the Jewish festival of Chanukah; and
Punch-Drunk Love (2002) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0272338/?ls)
. He also writes and produces many of his own films and has composed songs for several of them, including
The Wedding Singer (1998) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0120888/?ls)
. Sandler has had several of his songs placed on the "Billboard" charts, including the classic "The Chanukah Song".
[No Text] (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0424060/?ref_=ls_i_38)
38. Scarlett Johansson (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0424060/?ref_=ls_t_38)
Actress
Producer
Director
Lost in Translation (2003) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0335266/?ref_=ls_knf_38)
Scarlett Ingrid Johansson was born on November 22, 1984 in Manhattan, New York City, New York. Her mother,
Melanie Sloan (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0424012/?ls)
is from a Jewish family from the Bronx and her father,
Karsten Johansson (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0423984/?ls)
is a Danish-born architect from Copenhagen. She has a sister,
Vanessa Johansson (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0424089/?ls)
, who is also an actress, a brother, Adrian, a twin brother,
Hunter Johansson (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0423956/?ls)
, born three minutes after her, and a paternal half-brother, Christian. Her grandfather was writer
Ejner Johansson (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm1468214/?ls)
.
Johansson began acting during childhood, after her mother started taking her to auditions. She made her professional acting debut at the age of eight in the off-Broadway production of "Sophistry" with Ethan Hawke, at New York's Playwrights Horizons. She would audition for commercials but took rejection so hard her mother began limiting her to film tryouts. She made her film debut at the age of nine, as John Ritter's character's daughter in the fantasy comedy
North (1994) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0110687/?ls)
. Following minor roles in
Just Cause (1995) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0113501/?ls)
, as the daughter of Sean Connery and Kate Capshaw's character, and
If Lucy Fell (1996) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0116606/?ls)
, she played the role of Amanda in
Manny & Lo (1996) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0116985/?ls)
. Her performance in Manny & Lo garnered a nomination for the Independent Spirit Award for Best Lead Female, and positive reviews, one noting, "[the film] grows on you, largely because of the charm of ... Scarlett Johansson", while San Francisco Chronicle critic Mick LaSalle commentated on her "peaceful aura", and wrote, "If she can get through puberty with that aura undisturbed, she could become an important actress."
After appearing in minor roles in
Fall (1997) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0119098/?ls)
and
Home Alone 3 (1997) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0119303/?ls)
, Johansson garnered widely spread attention for her performance in
The Horse Whisperer (1998) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0119314/?ls)
, directed by Robert Redford, where she played Grace MacLean, a teenager traumatized by a riding accident. She received a nomination for the Chicago Film Critics Association Award for Most Promising Actress for the film. In 1999, she appeared in
My Brother the Pig (1999) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0165396/?ls)
and in the music video for Mandy Moore's single, "Candy". Although the film was not a box office success, she received praise for her breakout role in
Ghost World (2001) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0162346/?ls)
, credited with "sensitivity and talent [that] belie her age". She was also featured in the Coen Brothers' dark drama
The Man Who Wasn't There (2001) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0243133/?ls)
, opposite Billy Bob Thornton and Frances McDormand. She appeared in the horror comedy
Eight Legged Freaks (2002) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0271367/?ls)
with
David Arquette (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000274/?ls)
and
Kari Wuhrer (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001863/?ls)
.
In 2003, she was nominated for two Golden Globe Awards, one for drama (
Girl with a Pearl Earring (2003) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0335119/?ls)
) and one for comedy (
Lost in Translation (2003) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0335266/?ls)
), her breakout role, starring opposite
Bill Murray (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000195/?ls)
, and receiving rave reviews and a Best Actress Award at the Venice Film Festival. Her film roles include the critically acclaimed Weitz brothers' film
In Good Company (2004) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0385267/?ls)
, as well as starring opposite
John Travolta (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000237/?ls)
in
A Love Song for Bobby Long (2004) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0369672/?ls)
, which garnered her a third Golden Globe Award nomination.
She dropped out of
Mission: Impossible III (2006) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0317919/?ls)
due to scheduling conflicts. Her next film role was in
The Island (2005) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0399201/?ls)
alongside
Ewan McGregor (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000191/?ls)
which earned weak reviews from U.S. critics. After this, she appeared in
Woody Allen (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000095/?ls)
's
Match Point (2005) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0416320/?ls)
and was nominated again for a Golden Globe Award. In May 2008, she released her album "Anywhere I Lay My Head", a collection of Tom Waits covers featuring one original song. Also that year, she starred in Frank Miller's
The Spirit (2008) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0831887/?ls)
, the Woody Allen film
Vicky Cristina Barcelona (2008) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0497465/?ls)
, and played Mary Boleyn opposite Natalie Portman in
The Other Boleyn Girl (2008) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0467200/?ls)
.
Since then, she has appeared as part of an ensemble cast in the romantic comedy
He's Just Not That Into You (2009) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1001508/?ls)
, the action superhero film
Iron Man 2 (2010) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1228705/?ls)
, the comedy-drama
We Bought a Zoo (2011) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1389137/?ls)
and starred as the original scream queen,
Janet Leigh (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001463/?ls)
, in
Hitchcock (2012) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0975645/?ls)
. She then played her character, Black Widow, in the blockbuster action films
The Avengers (2012) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0848228/?ls)
,
Captain America: The Winter Soldier (2014) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1843866/?ls)
,
Avengers: Age of Ultron (2015) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2395427/?ls)
,
Captain America: Civil War (2016) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt3498820/?ls)
,
Avengers: Infinity War (2018) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt4154756/?ls)
,
Avengers: Endgame (2019) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt4154796/?ls)
and
Black Widow (2021) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt3480822/?ls)
, and also headlined the sci-fi action thriller
Lucy (2014) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2872732/?ls)
, a box office success. With more than a decade of work already under her belt, Scarlett has proven to be one of Hollywood's most talented young actresses. Her other starring roles are in the sci-fi action thriller
Ghost in the Shell (2017) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1219827/?ls)
and the dark comedy
Rough Night (2017) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt4799050/?ls)
.
Scarlett and Canadian actor
Ryan Reynolds (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0005351/?ls)
were engaged in May 2008 and married in September of that year. In 2010, the couple announced their separation, and subsequently divorced a year later. In 2013, she became engaged to French journalist Romain Dauriac, the couple married a year later. In January 2017, the couple announced their separation, and subsequently divorced in September of that year. They have a daughter, Rose Dorothy Dauriac (born 2014).
She married Colin Jost in October 2020. They have one child, a son.

39. Heath Ledger (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0005132/?ref_=ls_t_39)
Actor
Director
Cinematographer
Brokeback Mountain (2005) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0388795/?ref_=ls_knf_39)
When hunky, twenty-year-old heart-throb Heath Ledger first came to the attention of the public in 1999, it was all too easy to tag him as a "pretty boy" and an actor of little depth. He spent several years trying desperately to sway this image, but this was a double-edged sword. His work comprised nineteen films, including
10 Things I Hate About You (1999) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0147800/?ls)
,
The Patriot (2000) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0187393/?ls)
,
A Knight's Tale (2001) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0183790/?ls)
,
Monster's Ball (2001) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0285742/?ls)
,
Ned Kelly (2003) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0277941/?ls)
,
The Brothers Grimm (2005) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0355295/?ls)
,
Lords of Dogtown (2005) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0355702/?ls)
,
Brokeback Mountain (2005) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0388795/?ls)
,
Casanova (2005) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0402894/?ls)
,
Candy (2006) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0424880/?ls)
,
I'm Not There (2007) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0368794/?ls)
,
The Dark Knight (2008) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0468569/?ls)
and
The Imaginarium of Doctor Parnassus (2009) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1054606/?ls)
. He also produced and directed music videos and aspired to be a film director.
Heath Ledger was born on the fourth of April 1979, in Perth, Western Australia, to Sally (Ramshaw), a teacher of French, and Kim Ledger, a mining engineer who also raced cars. His ancestry was Scottish, English, Irish, and Sephardi Jewish. As the story goes, in junior high school it was compulsory to take one of two electives, either cooking or drama. As Heath could not see himself in a cooking class he tried his hand at drama. Heath was talented, however the rest of the class did not acknowledge his talent. When he was seventeen he and a friend decided to pack up, leave school, take a car and rough it to Sydney. Heath believed Sydney to be the place where dreams were made or, at least, where actors could possibly get their big break. Upon arriving in Sydney with a purported sixty-nine cents to his name, Heath tried everything to get a break.
His first real acting job came in a low-budget movie called
Blackrock (1997) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0118735/?ls)
, a largely unimpressive cliché; an adolescent angst film about one boy's struggle when he learns his best mate raped a girl. He only had a very small role in the film. After that small role Heath auditioned for a role in a T.V. show called
Sweat (1996) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0115379/?ls)
about a group of young Olympic hopefuls. He was offered one of two roles, one as a swimmer, another as a gay cyclist. Heath accepted the latter because he felt to really stand out as an actor one had to accept unique roles that stood out from the bunch. It got him small notice, but unfortunately the show was quickly axed, forcing him to look for other roles. He was in
Home and Away (1988) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0094481/?ls)
for a very short period, in which he played a surfer who falls in love with one of the girls of Summer Bay. Then came his very brief role in
Paws (1997) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0119870/?ls)
, a film which existed solely to cash in on guitar prodigy
Nathan Cavaleri (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0146749/?ls)
's brief moment of fame, where he was the hottest thing in Australia. Heath played a student in the film, involved in a stage production of a Shakespeare play, in which he played "Oberon". A very brief role, this offered him a small paycheck but did nothing to advance his career. Then came
Two Hands (1999) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0145547/?ls)
. He went to the U.S. trying to audition for film roles, showcasing his brief role in
Roar (1997) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0118451/?ls)
opposite then unknown
Vera Farmiga (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0267812/?ls)
.
Then Australian director
Gregor Jordan (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0429963/?ls)
auditioned him for the lead in
Two Hands (1999) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0145547/?ls)
, which he got. An in your face Aussie crime thriller,
Two Hands (1999) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0145547/?ls)
was outstanding and helped him secure a role in
10 Things I Hate About You (1999) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0147800/?ls)
. After that, it seemed Heath was being typecast as a young hunk, which he did not like, so he accepted a role in a very serious war drama
The Patriot (2000) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0187393/?ls)
.
What followed was a stark inconsistency of roles, Ledger accepting virtually every single character role, anything to avoid being typecast. Some met with praise, like his short role in
Monster's Ball (2001) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0285742/?ls)
, but his version of
Ned Kelly (2003) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0277941/?ls)
was an absolute flop, which led distributors hesitant to even release it outside Australia. Heath finally had deserved success with his role in
Brokeback Mountain (2005) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0388795/?ls)
. For his portrayal of Ennis Del Mar in in the film, Ledger won the New York Film Critics Circle Award for Best Actor and Best International Actor from the Australian Film Institute, and was nominated for the BAFTA Award for Best Actor in a Leading Role and for the Academy Award for Best Actor.
Ledger was found dead on January 22, 2008 in his apartment in the Manhattan neighborhood of SoHo, with a bottle of prescription sleeping pills near-by. It was concluded weeks later that he died of an accidental overdose of prescription drugs that included pain-killers, sleeping pills and anti-anxiety medication. His death occurred during editing of
The Dark Knight (2008) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0468569/?ls)
and in the midst of filming his last role as Tony in
The Imaginarium of Doctor Parnassus (2009) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1054606/?ls)
.
Posthumously, he shared the 2007 Independent Spirit Robert Altman Award with the rest of the ensemble cast, the director, and the casting director for the film
I'm Not There (2007) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0368794/?ls)
, which was inspired by the life and songs of American singer-songwriter
Bob Dylan (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001168/?ls)
. In the film, Ledger portrayed a fictional actor named Robbie Clark, one of six characters embodying aspects of Dylan's life and persona.
A few months before his death, Ledger had finished filming his performance as the Joker in '
The Dark Knight (2008) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0468569/?ls)
. His untimely death cast a somber shadow over the subsequent promotion of the $185 million Batman production. Ledger received more than thirty posthumous accolades for his critically acclaimed performance as the Joker, the psychopathic clown prince of crime, in the film, including the Academy Award for Best Supporting Actor, a Best Actor International Award at the 2008 Australian Film Institute Awards (for which he is the second actor to win an acting award posthumously after Peter Finch who won an Oscar for Network (Best Actor 1977)), the 2008 Los Angeles Film Critics Association Award for Best Supporting Actor, the 2009 Golden Globe Award for Best Supporting Actor - Motion Picture, and the 2009 BAFTA Award for Best Supporting Actor.

40. Anne Hathaway (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0004266/?ref_=ls_t_40)
Actress
Producer
Soundtrack
Les Misérables (2012) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1707386/?ref_=ls_knf_40)
Anne Jacqueline Hathaway was born in Brooklyn, New York, to
Kate McCauley Hathaway (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm1684668/?ls)
, an actress, and
Gerald T. Hathaway (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm5362894/?ls)
, a lawyer, both
originally from Philadelphia. She is of mostly Irish descent, along
with English, German, and French. Her first major role came in the
short-lived television series
Get Real (1999) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0212662/?ls)
. She gained
widespread recognition for her roles in
The Princess Diaries (2001) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0247638/?ls)
and its 2004 sequel as a young girl who discovers she is a member of
royalty, opposite
Julie Andrews (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000267/?ls)
and
Heather Matarazzo (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000525/?ls)
.
She also had a notable role in
Nicholas Nickleby (2002) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0309912/?ls)
opposite
Charlie Hunnam (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0402271/?ls)
and
Jamie Bell (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0068260/?ls)
, and a starring role in
Ella Enchanted (2004) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0327679/?ls)
. A former
top-ranking soprano in New York, Hathaway was reportedly a front-runner
for the role of "Christine" in the 2004
The Phantom of the Opera (2004) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0293508/?ls)
.
However, due to scheduling conflicts with
The Princess Diaries 2: Royal Engagement (2004) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0368933/?ls)
,
she couldn't take the role, which was later given to newcomer
Emmy Rossum (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0002536/?ls)
.
Hathaway soon started to move away from family-friendly films.
Following
The Princess Diaries 2: Royal Engagement (2004) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0368933/?ls)
,
she appeared topless in the films
Havoc (2005) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0285175/?ls)
opposite
Josh Peck (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0669681/?ls)
and
Brokeback Mountain (2005) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0388795/?ls)
opposite
Heath Ledger (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0005132/?ls)
and
Jake Gyllenhaal (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0350453/?ls)
. Her desire to break out
of her "Princess Diaries" image parallels that of her one-time co-star,
Julie Andrews (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000267/?ls)
, who went topless in
the film
S.O.B. (1981) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0083015/?ls)
in order to break
away from the image she created from her 1960s musicals. In interviews,
Hathaway said that doing family-friendly films didn't mean she was
similar to their characters or mean she objected to appearing nude in
other films.
[No Text] (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0185819/?ref_=ls_i_41)
41. Daniel Craig (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0185819/?ref_=ls_t_41)
Actor
Producer
Soundtrack
No Time to Die (2021) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2382320/?ref_=ls_knf_41)
One of the British theatre's most famous faces, Daniel Craig, who waited tables as a struggling teenage actor with the National Youth Theatre, has gone on to star as James Bond in
Casino Royale (2006) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0381061/?ls)
,
Quantum of Solace (2008) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0830515/?ls)
,
Skyfall (2012) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1074638/?ls)
,
Spectre (2015) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2379713/?ls)
and
No Time to Die (2021) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2382320/?ls)
.
He was born Daniel Wroughton Craig on March 2, 1968, at 41 Liverpool Road, Chester, Cheshire, England. His father, Timothy John Wroughton Craig, was a merchant seaman turned steel erector, and then became landlord of the "Ring O'Bells" pub in Frodsham, Cheshire. His mother, Carol Olivia (Williams), was an art teacher. Craig has English, as well as Irish, Scottish and Welsh, ancestry. His parents split up in 1972, and young Daniel was raised with his older sister, Lea, in Liverpool, then in Hoylake, Wirral, in the home of his mother. His interest in acting was encouraged by visits to the Liverpool Everyman Theatre arranged by his mother. From the age of six, Craig started acting in school plays, making his debut in the Frodsham Primary School production of "Oliver!", and his mother was the driving force behind his artistic aspirations. The first Bond movie he ever saw at the cinema was
Roger Moore (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000549/?ls)
's
Live and Let Die (1973) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0070328/?ls)
; young Daniel Craig saw it with his father, so it took a special place in his heart. He was also a good athlete and was a rugby player at Hoylake Rugby Club.
At age 14, Craig played roles in "Oliver", "Romeo and Juliet" and "Cinderella" at Hilbre High School in West Kirby, Wirral. He left Hilbre High School at age 16 to audition at the National Youth Theatre's (NYT) troupe on their tour in Manchester in 1984. He was accepted and moved down to London. There, his mother and father watched his stage debut as Agamemnon in Shakespeare's "Troilus and Cressida". As a struggling actor with the NYT, he was toiling in restaurant kitchens and as a waiter. Craig performed with NYT on tours to Valencia, Spain, and to Moscow, Russia, under the leadership of director
Edward Wilson (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0933356/?ls)
. He failed at repeated auditions at the Guildhall, but eventually his persistence paid off, and in 1988, he entered the Guildhall School of Music and Drama at the Barbican. There, he studied alongside
Ewan McGregor (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000191/?ls)
and
Alistair McGowan (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0569607/?ls)
, then later
Damian Lewis (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0507073/?ls)
and
Joseph Fiennes (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001212/?ls)
, among others. He graduated in 1991, after a three-year course under the tutelage of
Colin McCormack (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0566425/?ls)
, the actor from the Royal Shakespeare Company. From 1992-1994, he was married to Scottish actress Fiona Loudon, their daughter, named
Ella Craig (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm3409547/?ls)
(born 1992).
Craig made his film debut in
The Power of One (1992) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0105159/?ls)
. His film career continued on television, notably the BBC2 serial
Our Friends in the North (1996) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0115305/?ls)
. He shot to international fame after playing supporting roles in
Lara Croft: Tomb Raider (2001) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0146316/?ls)
and
Road to Perdition (2002) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0257044/?ls)
. He was nominated for his performances in the leading role in
Layer Cake (2004) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0375912/?ls)
, and received other awards and nominations. Craig was named as the sixth actor to portray James Bond, in October 2005, weeks after he finished his work in
Munich (2005) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0408306/?ls)
, where he co-starred with
Eric Bana (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0051509/?ls)
under the directorship of
Steven Spielberg (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000229/?ls)
. Craig's reserved demeanor and his avoidance of the showbiz-party-red-carpet milieu makes him a cool 007. He is the first blond actor to play Bond, and also the first to be born after the start of the film series, and also the first to be born after the death of author
Ian Fleming (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001220/?ls)
in 1964. Four of the past Bond actors:
Sean Connery (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000125/?ls)
,
Roger Moore (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000549/?ls)
,
Timothy Dalton (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001096/?ls)
and
Pierce Brosnan (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000112/?ls)
have indicated that Craig is a good choice as Bond.
He was appointed Companion of the Order of St. Michael and St. George (CMG) by Queen Elizabeth II at the 2022 Queen's New Years Honours for his services to Film and Theatre.
