42. Jessica Alba (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0004695/?ref_=ls_t_42)
Actress
Producer
Cinematographer
Fantastic Four (2005) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0120667/?ref_=ls_knf_42)
Jessica Marie Alba was born on April 28, 1981, in Pomona, CA, to Catherine (Jensen) and Mark David Alba, who served in the US Air Force. Her father is of Mexican descent (including Spanish and Indigenous Mexican roots), and her mother has Danish, Welsh, English, and French ancestry. Her family moved to Biloxi, MS, when she was an infant. Three years later her father's career brought the family back to California, then to Del Rio, TX, before finally settling in Southern California when Jessica was nine. In love with the idea of becoming an actress from the age of five, she was 12 before she took her first acting class. Nine months later she was signed by an agent. She studied at the Atlantic Theatre Company with founders
William H. Macy (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000513/?ls)
and
David Mamet (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000519/?ls)
.
A gifted young actress, Jessica has played a variety of roles ranging from light comedy to gritty drama since beginning her career. She made her feature film debut in 1993 in Hollywood Pictures' comedy
Camp Nowhere (1994) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0109369/?ls)
. Originally hired for two weeks, she got her break when an actress in a principal role suddenly dropped out. Jessica cheerfully admits it wasn't her prodigious talent or charm that inspired the director to tap her to take over the part--it was her hair, which matched the original performer's. The two-week job stretched to two months, and Jessica ended the film with an impressive first credit. Two national TV commercials for Nintendo and J.C. Penney quickly followed before Jessica was featured in several independent films. She branched out into TV in 1994 with a recurring role in Nickelodeon's popular comedy series
The Secret World of Alex Mack (1994) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0108921/?ls)
. She played an insufferable young snob, devoted to making life miserable for the the title character, played by
Larisa Oleynik (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0646351/?ls)
. That same year, she won the role of "Maya" in
Flipper (1995) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0111964/?ls)
and filmed the pilot for the series. She spent 1995 shooting the first season's episodes in Australia. An avid swimmer and PADI-certified SCUBA diver, Jessica was delighted to be doing a show that allowed her to play with dolphins. The show's success guaranteed it a second season, which she also starred in. Her involvement in the show lasted from 1995 to 1997.
In 1996 she appeared in
Venus Rising (1995) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0114831/?ls)
as "Young Eve." The next year she appeared on
The Dini Petty Show (1989) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0278183/?ls)
, a Canadian talk show, and spoke about her role in "Flipper" and her general acting career. She began working on
P.U.N.K.S. (1998) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0130172/?ls)
, featuring
Randy Quaid (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001642/?ls)
, in 1998. In early 1998 she appeared in
Brooklyn South (1997) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0118275/?ls)
as "Melissa." That same year she was in two episodes of
Beverly Hills, 90210 (1990) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0098749/?ls)
as "Leanne" and in two episodes of
Love Boat: The Next Wave (1998) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0143050/?ls)
.
She appeared in "Teen Magazine" in 1995 and various European magazines over the following years. More importantly, she was featured in the February 1999 issue of "Vanity Fair" magazine. She also had major roles in two movies that year:
Never Been Kissed (1999) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0151738/?ls)
and
Idle Hands (1999) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0138510/?ls)
. In 2000 she had roles in
Paranoid (2000) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0197750/?ls)
and starred in the sci-fi TV series
Dark Angel (2000) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0204993/?ls)
, gaining worldwide recognition.
Her first starring role in a major studio film was the
Honey (2003) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0322589/?ls)
, Universal Pictures' contemporary urban drama that grossed over $60 million worldwide. She has since made over 25 feature films that have earned a combined box-office total of over $800 million, including comedies and dramas, from gritty independents to major studio blockbusters. In 2005 she starred opposite
Bruce Willis (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000246/?ls)
and an all-star cast in the provocative and critically acclaimed
Sin City (2005) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0401792/?ls)
, directed by
Robert Rodriguez (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001675/?ls)
and
Frank Miller (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0588343/?ls)
. She next starred as Sue Storm--"The Invisible Girl"--in Marvel's action-franchise blockbuster
Fantastic Four (2005) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0120667/?ls)
, which was released by 20th Century-Fox in July 2005 and became a worldwide box-office success with over $300 million in revenue.
Jessica was part of
Garry Marshall (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0005190/?ls)
's all-star ensemble romantic comedy,
Valentine's Day (2010) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0817230/?ls)
, which broke box-office records with the largest opening on a four-day President's Day weekend in history. She starred opposite
Casey Affleck (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000729/?ls)
and
Kate Hudson (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0005028/?ls)
in director
Michael Winterbottom (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0935863/?ls)
's controversial screen adaptation of
The Killer Inside Me (2010) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0954947/?ls)
, based on
Jim Thompson (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0860292/?ls)
's novel, as well as Robert Rodriquez's
Machete (2010) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0985694/?ls)
. She co-starred in the third installment of the hit "Meet the Parents" franchise
Little Fockers (2010) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0970866/?ls)
, as well as the 4D family adventure
Spy Kids 4: All the Time in the World (2011) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1517489/?ls)
, marking her third of five collaborations with Robert Rodriguez. Jessica was part of an all-star voice cast for The Weinstein Company's animated adventure,
Escape from Planet Earth (2012) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0765446/?ls)
, also featuring
Sarah Jessica Parker (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000572/?ls)
,
Brendan Fraser (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000409/?ls)
and
James Gandolfini (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001254/?ls)
.
She appeared in the comedy
A.C.O.D. (2013) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1311060/?ls)
, which premiered at the Sundance Film Festival and starred
Adam Scott (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0004395/?ls)
,
Jane Lynch (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0528331/?ls)
and
Amy Poehler (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0688132/?ls)
. She made a cameo appearance in
Machete Kills (2013) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2002718/?ls)
and co-starred in Robert Rodriquez's highly-anticipated, star-studded sequel
Sin City: A Dame to Kill For (2014) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0458481/?ls)
. That year she had a full slate of acting projects, including the period drama
Dear Eleanor (2016) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2927212/?ls)
,
The Englishman (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt3111020/?ls)
opposite
Pierce Brosnan (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000112/?ls)
and
Salma Hayek (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000161/?ls)
; the IFC parody mini-series
The Spoils of Babylon (2014) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2884286/?ls)
, produced by Funny or Die, with a stellar cast including
Will Ferrell (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0002071/?ls)
,
Kristen Wiig (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm1325419/?ls)
,
Tobey Maguire (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001497/?ls)
,
Michael Sheen (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0790688/?ls)
and
Tim Robbins (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000209/?ls)
; and
Stretch (2014) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2494280/?ls)
, co-starring
Patrick Wilson (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0933940/?ls)
,
Chris Pine (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm1517976/?ls)
,
Ray Liotta (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000501/?ls)
,
Ed Helms (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm1159180/?ls)
and
Brooklyn Decker (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm2395937/?ls)
.
Jessica has received Golden Globe and People's Choice Award nominations, was voted TV Guide readers' Breakout Star of the Year, and won Favorite TV Actress at the 2001 Teen Choice Awards for "Dark Angel." She won the Nickelodeon Kids' Choice Award for Favorite Female Actress for her performance in "Fantastic Four" and an MTV Movie Award for Sexiest Performance in "Sin City." She received another Teen Choice Award for Choice Movie Actress in a Horror/Thriller for
The Eye (2008) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0406759/?ls)
and was honored by the Young Hollywood Awards as Superstar of Tomorrow in 2005. She has received ALMA Awards for her performances in "Dark Angel" and "Machete," as well as a Fashion Icon in 2009.

43. Ryan Reynolds (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0005351/?ref_=ls_t_43)
Actor
Producer
Writer
Deadpool 2 (2018) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt5463162/?ref_=ls_knf_43)
Ryan Rodney Reynolds was born on October 23, 1976 in Vancouver, British Columbia, Canada, the youngest of four children. His father, James Chester Reynolds, was a food wholesaler, and his mother, Tamara Lee "Tammy" (Stewart), worked as a retail-store saleswoman. He has Irish and Scottish ancestry. Between 1991-93, Ryan appeared in
Fifteen (1990) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0101099/?ls)
, a Nickelodeon series taped in Florida with many other Canadian actors. After the series ended, he returned to Vancouver where he played in a series of forgettable television movies. He did small roles in
Glenn Close (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000335/?ls)
's
Serving in Silence: The Margarethe Cammermeyer Story (1995) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0114395/?ls)
and CBS's update of
In Cold Blood (1996) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0116619/?ls)
. However, his run of luck had led him to decide to quit acting.
One night, he ran into fellow Vancouver actor and native
Chris William Martin (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0552072/?ls)
. Martin found Ryan rather despondent and told him to pack everything: they were going to head to Los Angeles, California. The two stayed in a cheap Los Angeles motel. On the first night of their stay, Reynolds' jeep was rolled downhill and stripped. For the next four months, Ryan drove it without doors. In 1997, he landed the role of Berg in
Two Guys, a Girl and a Pizza Place (1998) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0137330/?ls)
. Initially, the show was reviled by critics and seemed desperate for any type of ratings success. However, it was renewed for a second season but with a provision for a makeover by former
Roseanne (1988) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0094540/?ls)
writer
Kevin Abbott (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0008003/?ls)
. The show became a minor success and has led to additional film roles for Ryan, most notably in the last-ever MGM film, a remake of
The Amityville Horror (2005) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0384806/?ls)
. Ryan was engaged to Canadian singer-songwriter
Alanis Morissette (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001551/?ls)
, another Nickelodeon veteran, between 2004-2006.
He has been married to
Blake Lively (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0515116/?ls)
since September 9, 2012. They have three daughters and a son. He was previously married to
Scarlett Johansson (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0424060/?ls)
.
[No Text] (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001570/?ref_=ls_i_44)
44. Edward Norton (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001570/?ref_=ls_t_44)
Actor
Producer
Writer
Fight Club (1999) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0137523/?ref_=ls_knf_44)
American actor, filmmaker and activist Edward Harrison Norton was born on August 18, 1969, in Boston, Massachusetts, and was raised in Columbia, Maryland.
His mother, Lydia Robinson "Robin" (Rouse), was a foundation executive and teacher of English, and a daughter of famed real estate developer James Rouse, who developed Columbia, MD; she passed away of brain cancer on March 6, 1997. His father, Edward Mower Norton, was an environmental lawyer and conservationist, who works for the National Trust for Historic Preservation. Edward has two younger siblings, James and Molly.
From the age of five onward, the Yale graduate (majoring in history) was interested in acting. At the age of eight, he would ask his drama teacher what his motivation in a scene was. He attended theater schools throughout his life, and eventually managed to find work on stage in New York as a member of the Signature players, who produced the works of playwright and director
Edward Albee (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0016361/?ls)
. Around the time when he was appearing in Albee's Fragments, in Hollywood, they were looking for a young actor to star opposite
Richard Gere (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000152/?ls)
in a new courtroom thriller,
Primal Fear (1996) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0117381/?ls)
. The role was offered to
Leonardo DiCaprio (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000138/?ls)
but he turned it down. Gere was on the verge of walking away from the project, fed up with the wait for a young star to be found, when Edward auditioned and won the role over 2000 other hopefuls. Before the film was even released, his test screenings for the part were causing a Hollywood sensation, and he was soon offered roles in
Woody Allen (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000095/?ls)
's
Everyone Says I Love You (1996) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0116242/?ls)
and
The People vs. Larry Flynt (1996) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0117318/?ls)
. Edward won the Golden Globe for Best Actor in a Supporting Role and received an Oscar nomination for Best Supporting Actor for his performance in
Primal Fear (1996) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0117381/?ls)
. In 1998, Norton gained 30 pounds of muscle and transformed his look into that of a monstrous skinhead for his role as a violent white supremacist in
American History X (1998) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0120586/?ls)
. This performance earned him his second Oscar nomination, this time for Best Actor.
He received his third Oscar nomination, for Best Supporting Actor, for his work in
Birdman or (The Unexpected Virtue of Ignorance) (2014) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2562232/?ls)
. His most prominent roles also include the critically acclaimed
Everyone Says I Love You (1996) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0116242/?ls)
,
The People vs. Larry Flynt (1996) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0117318/?ls)
,
Fight Club (1999) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0137523/?ls)
,
Red Dragon (2002) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0289765/?ls)
,
25th Hour (2002) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0307901/?ls)
,
Kingdom of Heaven (2005) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0320661/?ls)
,
The Illusionist (2006) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0443543/?ls)
,
Moonrise Kingdom (2012) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1748122/?ls)
, and
The Grand Budapest Hotel (2014) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2278388/?ls)
. He has also directed and co-written films, including his directorial debut,
Keeping the Faith (2000) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0171433/?ls)
. He has done uncredited work on the scripts for
The Score (2001) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0227445/?ls)
,
Frida (2002) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0120679/?ls)
, and
The Incredible Hulk (2008) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0800080/?ls)
.
Alongside his work in cinema, Norton is an environmental and social activist, and is a member of the board of trustees of Enterprise Community Partners, a non-profit organization for developing affordable housing founded by his grandfather James Rouse.
[No Text] (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0461136/?ref_=ls_i_45)
45. Keira Knightley (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0461136/?ref_=ls_t_45)
Actress
Producer
Camera and Electrical Department
Pirates of the Caribbean: The Curse of the Black Pearl (2003) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0325980/?ref_=ls_knf_45)
Keira Christina Knightley was born March 26, 1985 in the South West Greater London suburb of Richmond. She is the daughter of actor
Will Knightley (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0461139/?ls)
and actress turned playwright
Sharman Macdonald (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0531930/?ls)
. An older brother,
Caleb Knightley (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm1045816/?ls)
, was born in 1979. Her father is English, while her Scottish-born mother is of Scottish and Welsh origin. Brought up immersed in the acting profession from both sides - writing and performing - it is little wonder that the young Keira asked for her own agent at the age of three. She was granted one at the age of six and performed in her first TV role as "Little Girl" in
Royal Celebration (1993) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0308821/?ls)
, aged seven.
It was discovered at an early age that Keira had severe difficulties in reading and writing. She was not officially dyslexic as she never sat the formal tests required of the British Dyslexia Association. Instead, she worked incredibly hard, encouraged by her family, until the problem had been overcome by her early teens. Her first multi-scene performance came in
A Village Affair (1995) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0111627/?ls)
, an adaptation of the lesbian love story by
Joanna Trollope (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0873433/?ls)
. This was followed by small parts in the British crime series
The Bill (1984) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0084987/?ls)
, an exiled German princess in
The Treasure Seekers (1996) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0117957/?ls)
and a much more substantial role as the young "Judith Dunbar" in
Giles Foster (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0287821/?ls)
's adaptation of
Rosamunde Pilcher (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0683362/?ls)
's novel
Coming Home (1998) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0158653/?ls)
, alongside
Peter O'Toole (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000564/?ls)
,
Penelope Keith (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0445285/?ls)
and
Joanna Lumley (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0525921/?ls)
. The first time Keira's name was mentioned around the world was when it was revealed (in a plot twist kept secret by director
George Lucas (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000184/?ls)
) that she played
Natalie Portman (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000204/?ls)
's decoy "Padme" to Portman's "Amidala" in
Star Wars: Episode I - The Phantom Menace (1999) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0120915/?ls)
. It was several years before agreement was reached over which scenes featured Keira as the queen and which featured Natalie!
Keira had no formal training as an actress and did it out of pure enjoyment. She went to an ordinary council-run school in nearby Teddington and had no idea what she wanted to do when she left. By now, she was beginning to receive far more substantial roles and was starting to turn work down as one project and her schoolwork was enough to contend with. She reappeared on British television in 1999 as "Rose Fleming" in
Alan Bleasdale (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0088062/?ls)
's faithful reworking of
Charles Dickens (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0002042/?ls)
'
Oliver Twist (1999) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0222608/?ls)
, and traveled to Romania to film her first title role in
Walt Disney (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000370/?ls)
's
Princess of Thieves (2001) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0272790/?ls)
in which she played Robin Hood's daughter, Gwyn. Keira's first serious boyfriend was her
Princess of Thieves (2001) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0272790/?ls)
co-star
Del Synnott (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0843435/?ls)
, and they later co-starred in
Peter Hewitt (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0382072/?ls)
's 'work of fart'
Thunderpants (2002) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0283054/?ls)
.
Nick Hamm (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0358327/?ls)
's dark thriller
The Hole (2001) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0242527/?ls)
kept her busy during 2000, and featured her first nude scene (15 at the time, the film was not released until she was 16 years old). In the summer of 2001, while Keira studied and sat her final school exams (she received six A's), she filmed a movie about an Asian girl's (
Parminder Nagra (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0619406/?ls)
) love for football and the prejudices she has to overcome regarding both her culture and her religion).
Bend It Like Beckham (2002) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0286499/?ls)
was a smash hit in football-mad Britain but it had to wait until another of Keira's films propelled it to the top end of the US box office.
Bend It Like Beckham (2002) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0286499/?ls)
cost just £3.5m to make, and nearly £1m of that came from the British Lottery. It took £11m in the UK and has since gone on to score more than US$76m worldwide.
Meanwhile, Keira had started A-levels at Esher College, studying Classics, English Literature and Political History, but continued to take acting roles which she thought would widen her experience as an actress. The story of a drug-addicted waitress and her friendship with the young son of a drug-addict,
Pure (2002) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0308772/?ls)
, occupied Keira from January to March 2002. Also at this time, Keira's first attempt at Shakespeare was filmed. She played "Helena" in a modern interpretation of a scene from "A Midsummer Night's Dream" entitled
The Seasons Alter (2002) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0399618/?ls)
. This was commissioned by the environmental organization "Futerra", of which Keira's mother is patron. Keira received no fee for this performance or for another short film,
New Year's Eve (2002) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0378437/?ls)
, by award-winning director
Col Spector (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm2980191/?ls)
. But it was a chance encounter with producer
Andy Harries (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0364170/?ls)
at the London premiere of
Bridget Jones's Diary (2001) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0243155/?ls)
which forced Keira to leave her studies and pursue acting full-time. The meeting lead to an audition for the role of "Larisa Feodorovna Guishar" - the classic heroine of
Boris Pasternak (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0664985/?ls)
's novel
Doctor Zhivago (2002) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0324937/?ls)
, played famously in the
David Lean (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000180/?ls)
movie by
Julie Christie (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001046/?ls)
. This was to be a big-budget TV movie with a screenplay written by
Andrew Davies (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0203577/?ls)
. Keira won the part and the mini-series was filmed throughout the Spring of 2002 in Slovakia, co-starring
Sam Neill (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000554/?ls)
and
Hans Matheson (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0558548/?ls)
as "Yuri Zhivago". Keira rounded off 2002 with a few scenes in the first movie to be directed by Blackadder and Vicar of Dibley writer
Richard Curtis (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0193485/?ls)
. Called
Love Actually (2003) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0314331/?ls)
, Keira played "Juliet", a newlywed whose husband's Best Man is secretly besotted with her. A movie filmed after
Love Actually (2003) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0314331/?ls)
but released before it was to make the world sit up and take notice of this beautiful fresh-faced young actress with a cute British accent. It was a movie which Keira very nearly missed out on, altogether. Auditions were held in London for a new blockbuster movie called
Pirates of the Caribbean: The Curse of the Black Pearl (2003) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0325980/?ls)
, but heavy traffic in the city forced Keira to be tagged on to the end of the day's auditions list. It helped - she got the part. Filming took place in Los Angeles and the Caribbean from October 2002 to March 2003 and was released to massive box office success and almost universal acclaim in the July of that year.
Meanwhile, a small British film called
Bend It Like Beckham (2002) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0286499/?ls)
had sneaked onto a North American release slate and was hardly setting the box office alight. But Keira's dominance in "Pirates" had set tongues wagging and questions being asked about the actress playing "Elizabeth Swann". Almost too late, "Bend It"'s distributors realized one of its two stars was the same girl whose name was on everyone's lips due to "Pirates", and took the unusual step of re-releasing "Bend It" to 1,000 screens across the US, catapulting it from no. 26 back up to no. 12. "Pirates", meanwhile, was fighting off all contenders at the top spot, and stayed in the Top 3 for an incredible 21 weeks. It was perhaps no surprise, then, that Keira was on producer
Jerry Bruckheimer (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000988/?ls)
's wanted list for the part of "Guinevere" in a planned accurate telling of the legend of "King Arthur". Filming took place in Ireland and Wales from June to November 2003. In July, Keira had become the celebrity face of British jeweller and luxury goods retailer, Asprey. At a photoshoot for the company on Long Island New York in August, Keira met and fell in love with Northern Irish model
Jamie Dornan (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm1946193/?ls)
.
King Arthur (2004) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0349683/?ls)
was released in July 2004 to lukewarm reviews. It seems audiences wanted the legend after all, and not necessarily the truth. Keira became the breakout star and 'one to watch in 2004' throughout the world's media at the end of 2003.
Keira's 2004 started off in Scotland and Canada filming
John Maybury (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0562266/?ls)
's time-travelling thriller
The Jacket (2005) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0366627/?ls)
with Oscar-winner
Adrien Brody (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0004778/?ls)
. A planned movie of
Deborah Moggach (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0595738/?ls)
's novel, "Tulip Fever", about forbidden love in 17th Century Amsterdam, was canceled in February after the British government suddenly closed tax loopholes which allowed filmmakers to claw back a large proportion of their expenditure. Due to star Keira and
Jude Law (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000179/?ls)
in the main roles, the film remains mothballed. Instead, Keira spent her time wisely, visiting Ethiopia on behalf of the "Comic Relief" charity, and spending summer at various grandiose locations around the UK filming what promises to be a faithful adaptation of
Jane Austen (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000807/?ls)
's classic novel
Pride & Prejudice (2005) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0414387/?ls)
, alongside
Matthew Macfadyen (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0532193/?ls)
as "Mr. Darcy", and with
Donald Sutherland (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000661/?ls)
and
Judi Dench (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001132/?ls)
in supporting roles. In October 2004, Keira received her first major accolade, the Hollywood Film Award for Best Breakthrough Actor - Female, and readers of Empire Magazine voted her the Sexiet Movie Star Ever. The remainder of 2004 saw Keira once again trying a completely new genre, this time the part-fact, part-fiction life story of model turned bounty hunter Domino (2005).
2005 started with the premiere of The Jacket (2005) at the Sundance Film Festival, with the US premiere in LA on February 28th. Much of the year was then spent in the Caribbean filming both sequels to Pirates Of The Caribbean. Keira's first major presenting role came in a late-night bed-in comedy clip show for Comic Relief with presenter Johnny Vaughan. In late July, promotions started for the September release of Pride & Prejudice (2005), with British fans annoyed to learn that the US version would end with a post-marriage kiss, but the European version would not. Nevertheless, when the movie opened in September on both sides of the Atlantic, Keira received her greatest praise thus far in her career, amid much talk of awards. It spent three weeks at No. 1 in the UK box office.
Domino (2005) opened well in October, overshadowed by the death of Domino Harvey earlier in the year. Keira received Variety's Personality Of The Year Award in November, topped the following month by her first Golden Globe nomination, for Pride & Prejudice (2005). KeiraWeb.com exclusively announced that Keira would play Helene Joncour in an adaptation of Alessandro Baricco's novella Silk (2007). Pride & Prejudice (2005) garnered six BAFTA nominations at the start of 2006, but not Best Actress for Keira, a fact which paled soon after by the announcement she had received her first Academy Award nomination, the third youngest Best Actress Oscar hopeful. A controversial nude Vanity Fair cover of Keira and
Scarlett Johansson (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0424060/?ls)
kept the press busy up till the Oscars, with
Reese Witherspoon (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000702/?ls)
taking home the gold man in the Best Actress category, although Keira's Vera Wang dress got more media attention. Keira spent early summer in Europe filming Silk (2007) opposite
Michael Pitt (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0685856/?ls)
, and the rest of the summer in the UK filming Atonement (2007), in which she plays Cecilia Tallis, and promoting the new Pirates movie (her Ellen Degeneres interview became one of the year's Top 10 'viral downloads'). Pirates Of The Caribbean: Dead Man's Chest (2006) broke many box office records when it opens worldwide in July, becoming the third biggest movie ever by early September. Keira sued British newspaper The Daily Mail in early 2007 after her image in a bikini accompanied an article about a woman who blamed slim celebrities for the death of her daughter from anorexia. The case was settled and Keira matched the settlement damages and donated the total amount to an eating disorder charity. Keira filmed a movie about the life of Dylan Thomas, The Edge Of Love (2008) with a screenplay written by her mother
Sharman Macdonald (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0531930/?ls)
. Her co-star
Lindsay Lohan (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0517820/?ls)
pulled out just a week before filming began, and was replaced by
Sienna Miller (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm1092227/?ls)
.
What was announced to be Keira's final Pirates movie in the franchise, Pirates Of The Caribbean: At World's End (2007), opened strongly in June, rising to all-time fifth biggest movie by July. Atonement (2007) opened the Venice Film Festival in August, and opened worldwide in September, again to superb reviews for Keira. Meanwhile, Silk (2007) opened in September on very few screens and disappeared without a trace. Keira spent the rest of the year filming The Duchess (2008), the life story of Georgiana, Duchess of Devonshire, based on Amanda Foreman's award-winning biography of the distant relation of Princess Diana. The year saw more accolades and poll-topping for Keira than ever before, including Women's Beauty Icon 2007 and gracing the covers of all the top-selling magazines. She won Best Actress for Atonement (2007) at the Variety Club Of Great Britain Showbiz Awards, and ended the year with her second Golden Globe nomination. Christmas Day saw - or rather heard - Keira on British TV screens in a new Robbie The Reindeer animated adventure, with DVD proceeds going to Comic Relief. At the start of 2008, Keira received her first BAFTA nomination - Best Actress for Atonement, and the movie wins Best Film: Drama at the Golden Globes. Seven Academy Award nominations for Atonement soon follow. Keira wins Best Actress for her role as Cecilia Tallis at the Empire Film Awards. In May, Keira's first Shakespearean role is announced, when she is confirmed to play Cordelia in a big-screen version of King Lear, alongside Naomi Watts and Gwyneth Paltrow, with Sir Anthony Hopkins as the titular monarch. After two years of rumours, it is confirmed that Keira is on the shortlist to play Eliza Doolittle in a new adaptation of My Fair Lady. The Edge Of Love opens the Edinburgh Film Festival on June 18th, and opens on limited release in the UK and US. A huge round of promotions for The Duchess occurs throughout the summer, with cast and crew trying to play down the marketers' decision to draw parallels between the duchess and Princess Diana. Keira attends the UK and US premieres and Toronto Film Festival within the first week of September. The Duchess opens strongly on both sides of the Atlantic. Two more movies were confirmed for Keira during September - a tale of adultery called
Last Night (2010) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1294688/?ls)
, and a biopic of author F Scott Fitzgerald entitled
The Beautiful and the Damned (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1181615/?ls)
.
Keira spent October on the streets of New York City filming Last Night alongside
Sam Worthington (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0941777/?ls)
and
Guillaume Canet (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0133899/?ls)
. Keira helped to promote the sixtieth anniversary of the UN's Declaration of Human Rights, by contributing to a series of short films produced to mark the occasion. In January 2009 it was announced Keira had signed to play a reclusive actress in an adaptation of Ken Bruen's novel
London Boulevard (2010) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1213648/?ls)
, co-starring
Colin Farrell (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0268199/?ls)
. Keira continues her close ties with the Comic Relief charity by helping to launch their British icons T-shirts campaign. In the same week King Lear was revealed to have been shelved, it was announced that Keira would instead star alongside her Pride & Prejudice co-star Carey Mulligan in an adaptation of Kazuo Ishiguro's novel
Never Let Me Go (2010) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1334260/?ls)
. A new short film emerges in March, recorded in the January of 2008 in which Keira plays a Fairy!
The Continuing and Lamentable Saga of the Suicide Brothers (2009) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1471349/?ls)
was written by Keira's boyfriend
Rupert Friend (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm1670029/?ls)
and actor
Tom Mison (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm2070427/?ls)
. It went to be shown at the London Film Festival in October and won Best Comedy Short at the New Hampshire Film Festival. Keira continued to put her celebrity to good use in 2009 with a TV commercial for WomensAid highlighting domestic abuse against women. Unfortunately, UK censors refused to allow its broadcast and it can only be viewed on YouTube. May and June saw Keira filming
Never Let Me Go (2010) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1334260/?ls)
and
London Boulevard (2010) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1213648/?ls)
back-to-back. In October, a new direction for Keira's career emerged, when it was announced she would appear on the London stage in her West End debut role as Jennifer, in a reworking of Moliere's The Misanthrope, starring
Damian Lewis (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0507073/?ls)
and
Tara Fitzgerald (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001216/?ls)
. More than $2m of ticket sales followed in the first four days, before even rehearsals had begun! The play ran from December to March at London's Comedy Theatre.
[No Text] (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0634240/?ref_=ls_i_46)
46. Christopher Nolan (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0634240/?ref_=ls_t_46)
Writer
Producer
Director
Tenet (2020) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt6723592/?ref_=ls_knf_46)
Best known for his cerebral, often nonlinear, storytelling, acclaimed Academy Award winner writer/director/producer Sir
Christopher Nolan (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0634240/?ls)
CBE was born in London, England. Over the course of more than 25 years of filmmaking, Nolan has gone from low-budget independent films to working on some of the biggest blockbusters ever made and became one of the most celebrated filmmakers of modern cinema.
At 7 years old, Nolan began making short films with his father's Super-8 camera. While studying English Literature at University College London, he shot 16-millimeter films at U.C.L.'s film society, where he learned the guerrilla techniques he would later use to make his first feature,
Following (1998) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0154506/?ls)
, on a budget of around $6,000. The noir thriller was recognized at a number of international film festivals prior to its theatrical release and gained Nolan enough credibility that he was able to gather substantial financing for his next film.
Nolan's second film was
Memento (2000) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0209144/?ls)
, which he directed from his own screenplay based on a short story by his brother
Jonathan Nolan (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0634300/?ls)
. Starring
Guy Pearce (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001602/?ls)
, the film brought Nolan numerous honors, including Academy Award and Golden Globe Award nominations for Best Original Screenplay. Nolan went on to direct the critically acclaimed psychological thriller,
Insomnia (2002) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0278504/?ls)
, starring
Al Pacino (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000199/?ls)
,
Robin Williams (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000245/?ls)
and
Hilary Swank (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0005476/?ls)
.
The turning point in Nolan's career occurred when he was awarded the chance to revive the Batman franchise in 2005. In
Batman Begins (2005) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0372784/?ls)
, Nolan brought a level of gravitas back to the iconic hero, and his gritty, modern interpretation was greeted with praise from fans and critics alike. Before moving on to a Batman sequel, Nolan directed, co-wrote, and produced the mystery thriller
The Prestige (2006) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0482571/?ls)
, starring
Christian Bale (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000288/?ls)
and
Hugh Jackman (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0413168/?ls)
as magicians whose obsessive rivalry leads to tragedy and murder.
In 2008, Nolan directed, co-wrote, and produced
The Dark Knight (2008) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0468569/?ls)
. Co-written with by his brother Jonathan, the film went on to gross more than a billion dollars at the worldwide box office. Nolan was nominated for a Directors Guild of America (D.G.A.) Award, Writers Guild of America (W.G.A.) Award and Producers Guild of America (P.G.A.) Award, and the film also received eight Academy Award nominations. The film is widely considered one of the best comic book adaptations of all times, with
Heath Ledger (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0005132/?ls)
's performance as the Joker receiving an extremely high acclaim. Ledger posthumously became the first Academy Award winning performance in a Nolan film.
In 2010, Nolan captivated audiences with the Sci-Fi thriller
Inception (2010) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1375666/?ls)
, starring
Leonardo DiCaprio (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000138/?ls)
in the lead role, which he directed and produced from his own original screenplay that he worked on for almost a decade. The thought-provoking drama was a worldwide blockbuster, earning more than $800,000,000 and becoming one of the most discussed and debated films of the year, and of all times. Among its many honors, Inception received four Academy Awards and eight nominations, including Best Picture and Best Screenplay. Nolan was recognized by his peers with a W.G.A. Award accolade, as well as D.G.A. and P.G.A. Awards nominations for his work on the film.
As one of the best-reviewed and highest-grossing movies of 2012,
The Dark Knight Rises (2012) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1345836/?ls)
concluded Nolan's Batman trilogy. Due to his success rebooting the Batman character, Warner Bros. enlisted Nolan to produce their revamped Superman movie
Man of Steel (2013) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0770828/?ls)
, which opened in the summer of 2013. In 2014, Nolan directed, wrote, and produced the Science-Fiction epic
Interstellar (2014) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0816692/?ls)
, starring
Matthew McConaughey (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000190/?ls)
,
Anne Hathaway (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0004266/?ls)
and
Jessica Chastain (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm1567113/?ls)
. Paramount Pictures and Warner Bros. released the film on November 5, 2014, to positive reviews and strong box-office results, grossing over $670 million dollars worldwide.
In July 2017, Nolan released his acclaimed War epic
Dunkirk (2017) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt5013056/?ls)
, that earned him his first Best Director nomination at the Academy Awards, as well as winning an additional 3 Oscars. In 2020 he released his mind-bending Sci-Fi espionage thriller
Tenet (2020) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt6723592/?ls)
starring
John David Washington (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0913475/?ls)
in the lead role. Released during the COVID-19 pandemic, the movie grossed relatively less than Nolan's previous blockbusters, though it did do good numbers compared to other movies in that period of time. Hailed as Nolan's most complex film yet, the film was one of Nolan's less-acclaimed films at the time, yet slowly built a fan-base following in later years.
In July 2023, Nolan released his highly acclaimed biographic drama
Oppenheimer (2023) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt15398776/?ls)
starring Nolan's frequent collaborator
Cillian Murphy (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0614165/?ls)
- in the lead role for the first time in a Nolan film. The movie was a cultural phenomenon that on top of grossing almost 1 billion dollars at the Worldwide Box office, also swept the 2023/2024 award-season and gave Nolan his first Oscars, BAFTAs, Golden Globes, D.G.A. and P.G.A. Awards, as well as a handful of regional critics-circles awards and a W.G.A. nomination. Cillian's performance as quantum physicist J. Robert Oppenheimer was highly acclaimed as well, and became the first lead performance in a Nolan film to win the Academy Award.
During 2023, Nolan also received a fellowship from the British Film Institute (BFI). In March 2024, it was announced that Nolan is to be knighted by
King Charles III (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0697608/?ls)
and from now on will go by the title 'Sir Christopher Nolan'.
Nolan resides in Los Angeles, California with his wife, Academy Award winner producer Dame
Emma Thomas (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0858799/?ls)
, and their children. Sir Nolan and Dame Thomas also have their own production company, Syncopy.
[No Text] (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0177896/?ref_=ls_i_47)
47. Bradley Cooper (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0177896/?ref_=ls_t_47)
Actor
Producer
Director
A Star Is Born (2018) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1517451/?ref_=ls_knf_47)
Bradley Charles Cooper was born on January 5, 1975 in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. His mother, Gloria (Campano), is of Italian descent, and worked for a local NBC station. His father, Charles John Cooper, who was of Irish descent, was a stockbroker. Immediately after Bradley graduated from the Honors English program at Georgetown University in 1997, he moved to New York City to enroll in the Masters of Fine Arts program at the Actors Studio Drama School at New School University. There, he developed his stage work, culminating with his thesis performance as John Merrick in
Bernard Pomerance (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0690052/?ls)
's "The Elephant Man", performed in New York's Circle in the Square.
While still in school, Bradley began his professional career, appearing opposite
Sarah Jessica Parker (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000572/?ls)
on
Sex and the City (1998) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0159206/?ls)
and on the drama series
The Beat (2000) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0231013/?ls)
. His weekends were spent with LEAP (Learning through the Expanded Arts Program), a non-profit organization that teaches acting and movement to inner city school children. The summers took him all across the globe, from kayaking in British Columbia with Orca Whales to ice-climbing in the Peruvian Andes, while hosting Lonely Planet's
Treks in a Wild World (2000) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0273027/?ls)
for the Discovery Channel. Bradley had to miss his graduation ceremony from the Actors Studio in order to star in his first feature
Wet Hot American Summer (2001) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0243655/?ls)
. After finishing his second feature
Bending All the Rules (2002) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0349193/?ls)
, his plans to relocate to Los Angeles were delayed when
Darren Star (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0823015/?ls)
hired him to star on the drama series
The $treet (2000) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0247135/?ls)
.
Bradley went on to win the role of young law student Gordon Pinella in
Changing Lanes (2002) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0264472/?ls)
, starring
Ben Affleck (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000255/?ls)
and
Samuel L. Jackson (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000168/?ls)
, and also played Travis Paterson in
My Little Eye (2002) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0280969/?ls)
. He finally decided that it was time to forgo his other New York projects and move to Los Angeles when he was cast on
Alias (2001) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0285333/?ls)
. After supporting roles in
Wedding Crashers (2005) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0396269/?ls)
,
Failure to Launch (2006) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0427229/?ls)
,
The Comebacks (2007) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0790804/?ls)
,
The Rocker (2008) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1031969/?ls)
and
Yes Man (2008) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1068680/?ls)
, Cooper broke out with major roles in
He's Just Not That Into You (2009) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1001508/?ls)
,
The Hangover (2009) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1119646/?ls)
and
Valentine's Day (2010) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0817230/?ls)
. He co-starred in the action film
The A-Team (2010) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0429493/?ls)
and headlined the thriller film
Limitless (2011) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1219289/?ls)
.
Cooper received an Academy Award nomination for Best Actor after starring opposite
Jennifer Lawrence (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm2225369/?ls)
in
David O. Russell (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0751102/?ls)
's
Silver Linings Playbook (2012) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1045658/?ls)
. He then received two more consecutive Oscar nominations, Best Supporting Actor for playing Richie DiMaso in Russell's
American Hustle (2013) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1800241/?ls)
(again opposite Lawrence, though their characters shared no significant screen time), and Best Actor for playing Navy SEAL Chris Kyle in
Clint Eastwood (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000142/?ls)
's
American Sniper (2014) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2179136/?ls)
, the highest grossing film of 2014. During this time period, Cooper also reprised his role in
The Hangover Part II (2011) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1411697/?ls)
and
The Hangover Part III (2013) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1951261/?ls)
, turned in another strong dramatic turn in
The Place Beyond the Pines (2012) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1817273/?ls)
, and voiced Rocket Raccoon in the third highest grossing film of 2014,
Guardians of the Galaxy (2014) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2015381/?ls)
.
In 2015, Bradley headlined two comedies,
Cameron Crowe (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001081/?ls)
's
Aloha (2015) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1243974/?ls)
, set in Hawaii, and
John Wells (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0920274/?ls)
'
Burnt (2015) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2503944/?ls)
, set in London, and starred opposite Jennifer Lawrence again in David O. Russell's
Joy (2015) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2446980/?ls)
.
Bradley has a daughter (born 2017) with his former partner, model
Irina Shayk (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm3356995/?ls)
.

48. Will Ferrell (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0002071/?ref_=ls_t_48)
Producer
Actor
Writer
Talladega Nights: The Ballad of Ricky Bobby (2006) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0415306/?ref_=ls_knf_48)
John William Ferrell was born in Irvine, California, to Betty Kay (Overman), a teacher, and Roy
Lee Ferrell (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm3678552/?ls)
, Jr., a musician. His parents were originally from Roanoke Rapids, North Carolina.
A graduate of the University of Southern California, Ferrell became interested in performing while a student at University High School in Irvine, where he made his school's daily morning announcements over the public address system in disguised voices. He started as a member of the Los Angeles comedy/improvisation group The Groundlings, where fellow cast members
Ana Gasteyer (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0309430/?ls)
,
Maya Rudolph (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0748973/?ls)
and former
Saturday Night Live (1975) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0072562/?ls)
repertory players such as
Laraine Newman (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0628170/?ls)
,
Jon Lovitz (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001484/?ls)
and
Phil Hartman (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0367005/?ls)
began their careers. It was there he met
Chris Kattan (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0441592/?ls)
and the two became good friends and both went on to
Saturday Night Live (1975) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0072562/?ls)
later. He has also appeared on several television programs, including
Strangers with Candy (1999) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0194624/?ls)
,
Grace Under Fire (1993) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0106017/?ls)
and
Living Single (1993) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0106056/?ls)
during his time at The Groundlings. Will also lent his voice to the armless and legless dad of cartoon family "The Oblongs".
In 1995 he became a feature cast member at
Saturday Night Live (1975) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0072562/?ls)
during the show's rapid re-casting. He was declared quite possibly the worst cast member ever during his first season. However, his talents of impersonations and range of characters shot him forward to making him arguably the greatest
Saturday Night Live (1975) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0072562/?ls)
cast member ever. During his seven year run he is one of the few cast members to ever be nominated for an Emmy for a performance and played
George W. Bush (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0124133/?ls)
during the 2000 elections. He has appeared in every
Saturday Night Live (1975) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0072562/?ls)
movie since his premiere on the show in 1995. In 2002 he left
Saturday Night Live (1975) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0072562/?ls)
and was the only cast member to ever receive a farewell from all the current cast members at the end of the season finale show. Since leaving the show Will has pursued a career in films. In 2000, he married
Viveca Paulin (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0667186/?ls)
, and lives in L.A.

49. Julia Roberts (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000210/?ref_=ls_t_49)
Actress
Producer
Soundtrack
Pretty Woman (1990) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0100405/?ref_=ls_knf_49)
Julia Fiona Roberts never dreamed she would become the most popular
actress in America. She was born in Smyrna, Georgia, to Betty Lou
(Bredemus) and Walter Grady Roberts, one-time actors and playwrights,
and is of English, Irish, Scottish, Welsh, German, and Swedish descent.
As a child, due to her love of animals, Julia originally wanted to be a
veterinarian, but later studied journalism. When her brother,
Eric Roberts (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000616/?ls)
, achieved some success
in Hollywood, Julia decided to try acting. Her first break came in 1988
when she appeared in two youth-oriented movies
Mystic Pizza (1988) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0095690/?ls)
and
Satisfaction (1988) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0096037/?ls)
. The movies
introduced her to a new audience who instantly fell in love with this
pretty woman. Julia's biggest success was in the signature movie
Pretty Woman (1990) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0100405/?ls)
, for which Julia
got an Oscar nomination, and also won the People's Choice award for
Favorite Actress. Even though Julia would spend the next few years
either starring in serious movies, or playing fantasy roles like
Tinkerbell, the movie audiences would always love Julia best in
romantic comedies. With
My Best Friend's Wedding (1997) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0119738/?ls)
Julia gave the genre fresh life that had been lacking in Hollywood for
some time. Offscreen, after a brief marriage, Julia has been
romantically linked with several actors, and married cinematographer
Daniel Moder (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0595227/?ls)
in 2002; the couple has three children together.
Julia has also become
involved with UNICEF charities and has made visits to many different
countries, including Haiti and India, in order to promote goodwill.
Julia Robert remains one of the most popular and sought-after talents in Hollywood.

50. Nicolas Cage (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000115/?ref_=ls_t_50)
Actor
Producer
Director
Face/Off (1997) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0119094/?ref_=ls_knf_50)
Nicolas Cage was born Nicolas Kim Coppola in Long Beach, California, the son of comparative literature professor
August Coppola (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm1692024/?ls)
(whose brother is director
Francis Ford Coppola (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000338/?ls)
) and dancer/choreographer Joy Vogelsang. He is of Italian (father) and Polish and German (mother) descent. Cage changed his name early in his career to make his own reputation, succeeding brilliantly with a host of classic, quirky roles by the late 1980s.
Initially studying theatre at Beverly Hills High School (though he dropped out at seventeen), he secured a bit part in
Fast Times at Ridgemont High (1982) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0083929/?ls)
- most of which was cut, dashing his hopes and leading to a job selling popcorn at the Fairfax Theater, thinking that would be the only route to a movie career, but a job reading lines with actors auditioning for uncle Francis's
Rumble Fish (1983) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0086216/?ls)
landed him a role in that film, followed by the romantic lead in
Valley Girl (1983) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0086525/?ls)
, which was released first and truly launched his career.
His one-time passion for method acting reached a personal limit when he smashed a street-vendor's remote-control car to achieve the sense of rage needed for his gangster character in
The Cotton Club (1984) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0087089/?ls)
.
In his early 20s, he dated
Jenny Wright (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0942486/?ls)
for two years and later linked to
Uma Thurman (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000235/?ls)
. After a relationship of several years with
Christina Fulton (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0298489/?ls)
, a model, they split amicably and share custody of a son,
Weston Cage (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm2000606/?ls)
(b. 1990). He also has a son with his ex-wife,
Alice Kim Cage (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm3141716/?ls)
.

51. Ian McKellen (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0005212/?ref_=ls_t_51)
Actor
Writer
Producer
The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring (2001) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0120737/?ref_=ls_knf_51)
Widely regarded as one of the greatest stage and screen actors both in his native Great Britain and internationally, twice nominated for the Oscar and recipient of every major theatrical award in the UK and US, Ian Murray McKellen was born on May 25, 1939 in Burnley, Lancashire, England, to Margery Lois (Sutcliffe) and Denis Murray McKellen, a civil engineer and lay preacher. He is of Scottish, Northern Irish, and English descent. During his early childhood, his parents moved with Ian and his older sister, Jean, to the mill town of Wigan. It was in this small town that young Ian rode out World War II. He soon developed a fascination with acting and the theatre, which was encouraged by his parents. They would take him to plays, those by
William Shakespeare (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000636/?ls)
, in particular. The amateur school productions fostered Ian's growing passion for theatre.
When Ian was of age to begin attending school, he made sure to get roles in all of the productions. At Bolton School in particular, he developed his skills early on. Indeed, his first role in a Shakespearian play was at Bolton, as Malvolio in "Twelfth Night". Ian soon began attending Stratford-upon-Avon theatre festivals, where he saw the greats perform:
Laurence Olivier (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000059/?ls)
,
Wendy Hiller (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0384908/?ls)
,
John Gielgud (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000024/?ls)
,
Ralph Richardson (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0724732/?ls)
and
Paul Robeson (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0732079/?ls)
. He continued his education in English Drama, but soon it fell by the wayside as he concentrated more and more on performing. He eventually obtained his Bachelor of Arts in 1961, and began his career in earnest.
McKellen began working in theatre over the next few years. Very few people knew of Ian's homosexuality; he saw no reason to go public, nor had he told his family. They did not seem interested in the subject and so he saw no reason to bring it up. In 1988, Ian publicly came out of the closet on the BBC Radio 4 program, while discussing
Margaret Thatcher (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0857137/?ls)
's "Section 28" legislation, which made the promotion of homosexuality as a family relationship by local authorities an offense. It was reason enough for McKellen to take a stand. He has been active in the gay rights movement ever since.
Ian resides in Limehouse, where he has also lived with his former long-time partner
Sean Mathias (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0558773/?ls)
. The two men have also worked together on the film
Bent (1997) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0118698/?ls)
as well as in exquisite stage productions. To this day, McKellen works mostly in theatre, and was knighted by
Queen Elizabeth II (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0703070/?ls)
in 1990 for his efforts in the arts. However, he has managed to make several quite successful forays into film. He has appeared in several productions of Shakespeare's works including his well received
Richard III (1995) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0114279/?ls)
, and in a variety of other movies. However, it has only been recently that his star has finally begun to shine in the eyes of North American audiences. Roles in various films,
Cold Comfort Farm (1995) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0112701/?ls)
,
Apt Pupil (1998) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0118636/?ls)
and
Gods and Monsters (1998) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0120684/?ls)
, riveted audiences. The latter, in particular, created a sensation in Hollywood, and McKellen's role garnered him several of awards and nominations, including a Golden Globe and an Oscar nod. McKellen, as he continues to work extensively on stage, he always keeps in 'solidifying' his 'role' as Laurence Olivier's worthy 'successor' in the best sense too, such as
King Lear (2008) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2049483/?ls)
/
King Lear (2008) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1175295/?ls)
directed by
Trevor Nunn (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0638080/?ls)
and in a range of other staggering performances full of generously euphoric delight that have included "Peter Pan" and
Noël Coward (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0002021/?ls)
's "Present Laughter", as well as
Samuel Beckett (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0065716/?ls)
's "Waiting for Godot" and
Harold Pinter (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0056217/?ls)
's "No Man's Land" (
National Theatre Live: No Man's Land (2016) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt6427146/?ls)
), both in acclaimed productions brilliantly directed by
Sean Mathias (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0558773/?ls)
.
McKellen found mainstream success with his performance as Magneto in
X-Men (2000) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0120903/?ls)
and its sequels. His largest mark on the big screen may be as Gandalf in "The Lord of the Rings" film trilogy directed by
Peter Jackson (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001392/?ls)
, which he reprised in "The Hobbit" trilogy. He also reprised the role of 'King Lear' with new artistic perspectives in
National Theatre Live: King Lear (2018) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt9055926/?ls)
offering an invaluable mesmerizing experience as a natural force of stage - and screen - of infinite generosity through his unsurpassable interpretation of the titanically vulnerable king.

52. Halle Berry (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000932/?ref_=ls_t_52)
Actress
Producer
Director
Catwoman (2004) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0327554/?ref_=ls_knf_52)
Halle Maria Berry was born Maria Halle Berry on August 14, 1966 in Cleveland, Ohio and raised in Oakwood, Ohio to Judith Ann Berry (née Hawkins), a psychiatric nurse & Jerome Jesse Berry, a hospital attendant. Her father was African-American and her mother is of mostly English and German descent. Halle first came into the spotlight at seventeen years when she won the Miss Teen All-American Pageant, representing the state of Ohio in 1985 and, a year later in 1986, when she was the first runner-up in the Miss U.S.A. Pageant. After participating in the pageant, Halle became a model. It eventually led to her first weekly TV series, 1989's
Living Dolls (1989) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0096638/?ls)
, where she soon gained a reputation for her on-set tenacity, preferring to "live" her roles and remaining in character even when the cameras stopped rolling. It paid off though when she reportedly refused to bathe for several days before starting work on her role as a crack addict in
Spike Lee (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000490/?ls)
's
Jungle Fever (1991) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0102175/?ls)
because the role provided her big screen breakthrough. The following year, she was cast as
Eddie Murphy (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000552/?ls)
's love interest in
Boomerang (1992) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0103859/?ls)
, one of the few times that Murphy was evenly matched on screen. In 1994, Berry gained a youthful following for her performance as sexy secretary "Sharon Stone" in
The Flintstones (1994) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0109813/?ls)
. She next had a highly publicized starring role with
Jessica Lange (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001448/?ls)
in the adoption drama
Losing Isaiah (1995) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0113691/?ls)
. Though the movie received mixed reviews, Berry didn't let that slow her down, and continued down her path to super-stardom.
In 1998, she received critical success when she starred as a street smart young woman who takes up with a struggling politician in
Warren Beatty (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000886/?ls)
's
Bulworth (1998) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0118798/?ls)
. The following year, she won even greater acclaim for her role as actress
Dorothy Dandridge (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0199268/?ls)
in made-for-cable's
Introducing Dorothy Dandridge (1999) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0172348/?ls)
, for which she won a Golden Globe for Best Actress in a TV Movie/Mini-Series. In 2000, she received box office success in
X-Men (2000) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0120903/?ls)
in which she played "Storm", a mutant who has the ability to control the weather. In 2001, she starred in the thriller
Swordfish (2001) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0244244/?ls)
, and became the first African-American to win Best Actress at the Academy Awards, for her role as a grieving mother in the drama
Monster's Ball (2001) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0285742/?ls)
.
[No Text] (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000246/?ref_=ls_i_53)
53. Bruce Willis (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000246/?ref_=ls_t_53)
Actor
Producer
Writer
Die Hard (1988) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0095016/?ref_=ls_knf_53)
Actor and musician Bruce Willis is well known for playing wisecracking or hard-edged characters, often in spectacular action films. Collectively, he has appeared in films that have grossed in excess of $2.5 billion USD.
Walter Bruce Willis was born on March 19, 1955, in Idar-Oberstein, West Germany, to a German mother, Marlene Kassel, and an American father, David Andrew Willis (from Carneys Point, New Jersey), who were then living on a United States military base. His family moved to the U.S. shortly after he was born, and he was raised in Penns Grove, New Jersey, where his mother worked at a bank and his father was a welder and factory worker. Willis picked up an interest for the dramatic arts in high school, and was allegedly "discovered" whilst working in a café in New York City and then appeared in a couple of off-Broadway productions. While bartending one night, he was seen by a casting director who liked his personality and needed a bartender for a small movie role.
After countless auditions, Willis contributed minor film appearances, usually uncredited, before landing the role of private eye "David Addison" alongside sultry
Cybill Shepherd (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001732/?ls)
in the hit romantic comedy television series
Moonlighting (1985) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0088571/?ls)
. His sarcastic and wisecracking P.I. is seen by some as a dry run for the role of hard-boiled NYC detective "John McClane" in the monster hit
Die Hard (1988) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0095016/?ls)
, in which Willis' character single-handedly battled a gang of ruthless international thieves in a Los Angeles skyscraper. He reprised the role of McClane in the sequel,
Die Hard 2 (1990) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0099423/?ls)
, set at a snowbound Washington's Dulles International Airport as a group of renegade Special Forces soldiers seek to repatriate a corrupt South American general. Excellent box office returns demanded a further sequel
Die Hard with a Vengeance (1995) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0112864/?ls)
, this time co-starring
Samuel L. Jackson (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000168/?ls)
as a cynical Harlem shop owner unwittingly thrust into assisting McClane during a terrorist bombing campaign on a sweltering day in New York.
Willis found time out from all the action mayhem to provide the voice
of "Mikey" the baby in the very popular family comedies
Look Who's Talking (1989) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0097778/?ls)
, and its sequel
Look Who's Talking Too (1990) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0100050/?ls)
also starring
John Travolta (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000237/?ls)
and
Kirstie Alley (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000263/?ls)
. Over the next decade, Willis starred in some very successful films, some very offbeat films and some unfortunate box office flops.
The Bonfire of the Vanities (1990) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0099165/?ls)
and
Hudson Hawk (1991) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0102070/?ls)
were both large scale financial disasters that were savaged by the critics, and both are arguably best left off the CVs of all the actors involved, however Willis was still popular with movie audiences and selling plenty of theatre tickets with the hyper-violent
The Last Boy Scout (1991) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0102266/?ls)
, the darkly humored
Death Becomes Her (1992) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0104070/?ls)
and the mediocre police thriller
Striking Distance (1993) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0108238/?ls)
.
During the 1990s, Willis also appeared in several independent and low budget productions that won him new fans and praise from the critics for his intriguing performances working with some very diverse film directors. He appeared in the oddly appealing
North (1994) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0110687/?ls)
, as a cagey prizefighter in
the
Quentin Tarantino (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000233/?ls)
directed mega-hit
Pulp Fiction (1994) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0110912/?ls)
, the
Terry Gilliam (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000416/?ls)
directed apocalyptic thriller
12 Monkeys (1995) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0114746/?ls)
, the
Luc Besson (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000108/?ls)
directed sci-fi opus
The Fifth Element (1997) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0119116/?ls)
and the
M. Night Shyamalan (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0796117/?ls)
directed spine-tingling epic
The Sixth Sense (1999) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0167404/?ls)
.
Willis next starred in the gangster comedy
The Whole Nine Yards (2000) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0190138/?ls)
,
worked again with "hot" director
M. Night Shyamalan (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0796117/?ls)
in the less than
gripping
Unbreakable (2000) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0217869/?ls)
, and in two military dramas,
Hart's War (2002) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0251114/?ls)
and
Tears of the Sun (2003) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0314353/?ls)
that both failed to really fire with movie audiences or critics alike. However, Willis bounced back into the spotlight in the critically
applauded
Frank Miller (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0588340/?ls)
graphic novel turned movie
Sin City (2005) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0401792/?ls)
, the voice of "RJ" the scheming raccoon in the animated hit
Over the Hedge (2006) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0327084/?ls)
and "Die Hard" fans rejoiced to see "John McClane" return to the big screen in
the high tech
Live Free or Die Hard (2007) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0337978/?ls)
aka "Die Hard 4.0".
Willis was married to actress
Demi Moore (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000193/?ls)
for approximately thirteen years and they share custody to their three daughters.
[No Text] (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000168/?ref_=ls_i_54)
54. Samuel L. Jackson (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000168/?ref_=ls_t_54)
Actor
Producer
Additional Crew
Pulp Fiction (1994) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0110912/?ref_=ls_knf_54)
Samuel L. Jackson is an American producer and highly prolific actor, having appeared in over 100 films, including
Die Hard with a Vengeance (1995) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0112864/?ls)
,
Unbreakable (2000) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0217869/?ls)
,
Shaft (2000) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0162650/?ls)
,
Formula 51 (2001) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0227984/?ls)
,
Black Snake Moan (2006) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0462200/?ls)
,
Snakes on a Plane (2006) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0417148/?ls)
, and the Star Wars prequel trilogy (1999-2005), as well as the Marvel Cinematic Universe.
Samuel Leroy Jackson was born in Washington, D.C., to Elizabeth (Montgomery) and Roy Henry Jackson. He was raised by his mother, a factory worker, and his grandparents. At Morehouse College, Jackson was active in the black student movement. In the seventies, he joined the Negro Ensemble Company (together with
Morgan Freeman (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000151/?ls)
). In the eighties, he became well-known after three movies made by
Spike Lee (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000490/?ls)
:
Do the Right Thing (1989) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0097216/?ls)
,
Mo' Better Blues (1990) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0100168/?ls)
and
Jungle Fever (1991) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0102175/?ls)
. He achieved prominence and critical acclaim in the early 1990s with films such as
Patriot Games (1992) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0105112/?ls)
,
Amos & Andrew (1993) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0106266/?ls)
,
True Romance (1993) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0108399/?ls)
,
Jurassic Park (1993) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0107290/?ls)
, and his collaborations with director
Quentin Tarantino (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000233/?ls)
, including
Pulp Fiction (1994) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0110912/?ls)
,
Jackie Brown (1997) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0119396/?ls)
, and later
Django Unchained (2012) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1853728/?ls)
. Going from supporting player to leading man, his performance in
Pulp Fiction (1994) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0110912/?ls)
gave him an Oscar nomination for his character Jules Winnfield, and he received a Silver Berlin Bear for his part as Ordell Robbi in
Jackie Brown (1997) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0119396/?ls)
. Jackson usually played bad guys and drug addicts before becoming an action hero, co-starring with
Bruce Willis (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000246/?ls)
in
Die Hard with a Vengeance (1995) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0112864/?ls)
and
Geena Davis (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000133/?ls)
in
The Long Kiss Goodnight (1996) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0116908/?ls)
.
With Jackson's permission, his likeness was used for the Ultimate version of the Marvel Comics character, Nick Fury. He later did a cameo as the character in a post-credits scene from
Iron Man (2008) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0371746/?ls)
, and went on to sign a nine-film commitment to reprise this role in future films, including major roles in
Iron Man 2 (2010) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1228705/?ls)
,
The Avengers (2012) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0848228/?ls)
,
Captain America: The Winter Soldier (2014) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1843866/?ls)
and
Avengers: Age of Ultron (2015) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2395427/?ls)
and minor roles in
Thor (2011) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0800369/?ls)
and
Captain America: The First Avenger (2011) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0458339/?ls)
. He has also portrayed the character in the second and final episodes of the first season of the TV show, Marvel's
Agents of S.H.I.E.L.D. (2013) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2364582/?ls)
. He has provided his voice to several animated films, television series and video games, including the roles of Lucius Best / Frozone in Pixar's film
The Incredibles (2004) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0317705/?ls)
, Mace Windu in
Star Wars: The Clone Wars (2008) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1185834/?ls)
, Afro Samurai in the anime television series
Afro Samurai (2007) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0465316/?ls)
, and Frank Tenpenny in the video game
Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas (2004) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0383385/?ls)
.
[No Text] (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001774/?ref_=ls_i_55)
55. Ben Stiller (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001774/?ref_=ls_t_55)
Producer
Actor
Director
Tropic Thunder (2008) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0942385/?ref_=ls_knf_55)
Benjamin Edward Meara Stiller was born on November 30, 1965, in New York City, New York, to legendary comedians
Jerry Stiller (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0005467/?ls)
and
Anne Meara (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0575198/?ls)
. His father was of Austrian Jewish and Polish Jewish descent, and his mother was of Irish Catholic descent (she
converted to Judaism).
His parents made no real effort to keep their son away from the Hollywood lifestyle and he grew up among the stars, wondering
just why his parents were so popular. At a young age, he and his sister
Amy Stiller (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0830243/?ls)
would perform plays at home, wearing Amy's tights to perform Shakespeare. Ben also picked up an interest in being on the other side of the camera and, at age 10, began shooting films on his Super 8 camera. The plots were always simple: someone would pick on the shy, awkward Stiller ... and then he would
always get his revenge. This desire for revenge on the popular, good-looking people may have motivated his teen-angst opus
Reality Bites (1994) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0110950/?ls)
later in his career. He both directed and performed in the film, which co-starred
Winona Ryder (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000213/?ls)
and
Ethan Hawke (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000160/?ls)
.
Before he got to Hollywood, he put in several consistently solid years in the theater. After dropping out of UCLA, he performed in the Tony Award winner, "The House of Blue Leaves". While working on the play, Stiller shot a short spoof of
The Color of Money (1986) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0090863/?ls)
starring him (in the
Tom Cruise (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000129/?ls)
role) and his
The House of Blue Leaves (1987) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0093222/?ls)
costar
John Mahoney (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001498/?ls)
(in the
Paul Newman (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000056/?ls)
role). The short film was so funny that
Lorne Michaels (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0584427/?ls)
purchased it and aired it on
Saturday Night Live (1975) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0072562/?ls)
. This led to his spending a year on the show in 1989.
Stiller made his big screen debut in
Steven Spielberg (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000229/?ls)
's
Empire of the Sun (1987) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0092965/?ls)
in 1987. Demonstrating early on the multifaceted tone his career would take, he soon stepped behind the camera to direct Back to Brooklyn for MTV. The network was impressed and gave Stiller his own show,
The Ben Stiller Show (1992) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0103360/?ls)
. He recruited fellow offbeat comedians
Janeane Garofalo (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000413/?ls)
and
Andy Dick (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0004873/?ls)
and created a bitingly
satirical show. MTV ended up passing on it, but it was picked up by Fox. Unfortunately, the show was a ratings miss. Stiller was soon out
of work, although he did have the satisfaction of picking up an Emmy for the show after its cancellation.
For a while, Stiller had to settle for guest appearance work. While doing this, he saved up his cash and in the end was able to scrape
enough together to make
Reality Bites (1994) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0110950/?ls)
, now a cult classic which is looked upon favorably by the generation it depicted.
Ben continued to work steadily for a time, particularly in independent productions where he was more at ease. However, he never quite managed to catch a big break. His first big budget directing job was
Jim Carrey (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000120/?ls)
's
The Cable Guy (1996) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0115798/?ls)
. Although many
critics were impressed,
Jim Carrey (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000120/?ls)
's fans were not. In 1998,
There's Something About Mary (1998) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0129387/?ls)
had propelled Stiller into the mainstream spotlight. He also starred in such hit movies as
Keeping the Faith (2000) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0171433/?ls)
and
Meet the Parents (2000) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0212338/?ls)
.
