56. Tommy Lee Jones (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000169/?ref_=ls_t_56)
Actor
Director
Writer
The Homesman (2014) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2398231/?ref_=ls_knf_56)
Tommy Lee Jones was born in San Saba, Texas, the son of Lucille Marie
(Scott), a police officer and beauty shop owner, and Clyde C. Jones,
who worked on oil fields. Tommy himself worked in underwater
construction and on an oil rig. He attended St. Mark's School of Texas,
a prestigious prep school for boys in Dallas, on a scholarship, and
went to Harvard on another scholarship. He roomed with future Vice
President
Al Gore (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0330722/?ls)
and played offensive
guard in the famous 29-29 Harvard-Yale football game of '68 known as
"The Tie." He received a B.A. in English literature and graduated cum
laude from Harvard in 1969.
Following college, he moved to New York and began his theatrical career
on Broadway in "A Patriot for Me" (1969). In 1970, he made his film
debut in
Love Story (1970) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0066011/?ls)
. While
living in New York, he continued to appear in various plays, both on-
and off-Broadway: "Fortune and Men's Eyes" (1969); "Four on a Garden"
(1971); "Blue Boys" (1972); "Ulysses in Nighttown" (1974). During this
time, he also appeared on a daytime soap opera,
One Life to Live (1968) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0062595/?ls)
as
Dr. Mark Toland from 1971-75. He moved with wife
Kate Lardner (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0488061/?ls)
, granddaughter of short-story
writer/columnist
Ring Lardner (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0488066/?ls)
, and
her two children from a previous marriage, to Los Angeles.
There he began to get some roles on television:
Charlie's Angels (1976) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0073972/?ls)
(pilot episode);
Smash-Up on Interstate 5 (1976) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0075236/?ls)
;
and
The Amazing Howard Hughes (1977) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0075670/?ls)
.
While working on the movie
Back Roads (1981) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0082042/?ls)
, he met and fell in
love with Kimberlea Cloughley, whom he later married. More roles in
television--both on network and cable--stage and film garnered him a
reputation as a strong, explosive, thoughtful actor who could handle
supporting as well as leading roles. He made his directorial debut in
The Good Old Boys (1995) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0113196/?ls)
on TNT. In addition to directing and starring in the film, he co-wrote
the teleplay (with
J.T. Allen (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0020599/?ls)
). The
film, based on
Elmer Kelton (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0447118/?ls)
's novel, is set
in west Texas where Jones has strong family ties. Consequently, this
story of a cowboy facing the end of an era has special meaning for him.

57. Jack Black (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0085312/?ref_=ls_t_57)

School of Rock (2003) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0332379/?ref_=ls_knf_57)
Thomas Jacob "Jack" Black was born on August 28, 1969 in Santa Monica, California and raised in Hermosa Beach, California to
Judith Love Cohen (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm2091941/?ls)
& Thomas William Black, both satellite engineers. He is of Russian Jewish & British-German ancestry. Black attended the University of California at Los Angeles. While at UCLA, he was a member of
Tim Robbins (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000209/?ls)
' acting troupe & it was through this collaboration that led to his 1992 film debut in
Bob Roberts (1992) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0103850/?ls)
. Although he was just a background voice in his first film, Jack's appearances in such television shows as
The X-Files (1993) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0106179/?ls)
, his breakthrough performance in
High Fidelity (2000) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0146882/?ls)
& his rock-comedy band,
Tenacious D (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm1627732/?ls)
have created an ever-growing cult following.

58. Antonio Banderas (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000104/?ref_=ls_t_58)
Actor
Producer
Writer
The Mask of Zorro (1998) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0120746/?ref_=ls_knf_58)
Antonio Banderas, one of Spain's most famous faces, was a soccer player until breaking his foot at the age of fourteen; he is now an international movie star known for playing Zorro in the eponymous movie series.
He was born José Antonio Domínguez Banderas on August 10, 1960, in Málaga, Andalusia, Spain. His father, Jose Dominguez, was a policeman in the Spanish civil guards. His mother, Doña Ana Banderas Gallego, was a school teacher. Young Banderas was brought up a Roman Catholic. He wanted to play soccer professionally and made much success playing for his school team until the age of 14, albeit his dream ended when he broke his foot. At that time, he developed a passion for theatre after seeing the stage production of "Hair". Banderas began his acting studies at the School of Dramatic Arts in Málaga, and made his acting debut at a small theatre in Málaga. He was arrested by the Spanish police for performance in a play by
Bertolt Brecht (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0106517/?ls)
, because of political censorship under the rule of General
Francisco Franco (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0290542/?ls)
. Banderas spent a whole night at the police station, he had three or four such arrests while he was working with a small theatre troupe that toured all over Spain and was giving performances in small town theatres and on the street.
In 1979, at age 19, he moved to Madrid in pursuit of an acting career. Being a struggling young actor, he also worked as a waiter and took small modeling jobs. At that time, he joined the troupe at the National Theatre of Spain, becoming the youngest member of the company. Banderas' stage performances caught the attention of movie director
Pedro Almodóvar (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000264/?ls)
, who cast the young actor in his movie debut
Labyrinth of Passion (1982) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0084228/?ls)
. Banderas and Almodovar joined forces in making innovative and sexually provocative movies during the 1980s. In 1984, Banderas made headlines in Spain with his performance as a gay man, making his first male-to-male on-screen kiss in Almodovar's
Law of Desire (1987) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0093412/?ls)
. Banderas' long and fruitful collaboration with
Pedro Almodóvar (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000264/?ls)
eventually prepared him for international recognition that came with his work in the Academy Award-nominated film
Women on the Verge of a Nervous Breakdown (1988) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0095675/?ls)
. In 1991, he appeared as an object of Madonna's affection in
Madonna: Truth or Dare (1991) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0102370/?ls)
.
In 1992, Banderas made his Hollywood debut with
The Mambo Kings (1992) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0104802/?ls)
. Because he did not speak English at that time, his dialogue for the movie was taught to him phonetically. Banderas shot to international fame with his sensitive performance as a lover of
Tom Hanks (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000158/?ls)
' AIDS-infected lawyer in
Philadelphia (1993) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0107818/?ls)
, then played opposite
Tom Cruise (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000129/?ls)
and
Brad Pitt (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000093/?ls)
in
Interview with the Vampire (1994) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0110148/?ls)
. Banderas further established himself as one of Hollywood's leading men after co-starring in
Evita (1996) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0116250/?ls)
opposite
Madonna (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000187/?ls)
in the title role. In 1998, he won acclaim for his portrayal of Zorro, opposite
Anthony Hopkins (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000164/?ls)
and
Catherine Zeta-Jones (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001876/?ls)
, in
The Mask of Zorro (1998) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0120746/?ls)
. For the role as Zorro, Banderas took training with the Olympic national fencing team in Spain, and practiced his moves with real steel swords, then he used the lighter aluminum swords in the movie. He also took a month-long course of horse-riding before the filming. He later returned to the role in
The Legend of Zorro (2005) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0386140/?ls)
. In 1999, Banderas made his directorial debut in
Crazy in Alabama (1999) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0142201/?ls)
, starring his wife,
Melanie Griffith (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000429/?ls)
. He received critical acclaim for his portrayal of Mexican artist
David Alfaro Siqueiros (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm1563837/?ls)
opposite
Salma Hayek (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000161/?ls)
in
Frida (2002) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0120679/?ls)
. He voiced Puss in Boots in the Shrek franchise.
Banderas established himself as internationally known Latin heartthrob with charismatic looks, and was chosen as one of the 50 most beautiful people in the world by People magazine in 1996. He won numerous awards and nominations for his works in film, including three ALMA awards and three Golden Globe nominations, among many other. From 1996 to 2014, Banderas was married to American actress
Melanie Griffith (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000429/?ls)
and the couple have one daughter, Stella (born 1996). Outside of his acting profession, Banderas has been a passionate soccer fan and a staunch supporter of the Real Madrid Football Club. He shares time between his two residencies, one in the United States, and one in the South of Spain.
[No Text] (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000243/?ref_=ls_i_59)
59. Denzel Washington (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000243/?ref_=ls_t_59)
Actor
Producer
Director
Fences (2016) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2671706/?ref_=ls_knf_59)
Denzel Hayes Washington, Jr. was born on December 28, 1954 in Mount Vernon, New York. He is the middle of three children of a beautician mother, Lennis, from Georgia, and a Pentecostal minister father, Denzel Washington, Sr., from Virginia. After graduating from high school, Denzel enrolled at Fordham University, intent on a career in journalism. However, he caught the acting bug while appearing in student drama productions and, upon graduation, he moved to San Francisco and enrolled at the American Conservatory Theater. He left A.C.T. after only one year to seek work as an actor. His first paid acting role was in a summer stock theater stage production in St. Mary's City, Maryland. The play was "Wings of the Morning", which is about the founding of the colony of Maryland (now the state of Maryland) and the early days of the Maryland colonial assembly (a legislative body). He played the part of a real historical character, Mathias Da Sousa, although much of the dialogue was created. Afterwards he began to pursue screen roles in earnest. With his acting versatility and powerful presence, he had no difficulty finding work in numerous television productions.
He made his first big screen appearance in
Carbon Copy (1981) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0082138/?ls)
with
George Segal (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001719/?ls)
. Through the 1980s, he worked in both movies and television and was chosen for the plum role of Dr. Philip Chandler in NBC's hit medical series
St. Elsewhere (1982) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0083483/?ls)
, a role that he would play for six years. In 1989, his film career began to take precedence when he won the Oscar for Best Supporting Actor for his portrayal of Tripp, the runaway slave in
Edward Zwick (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001880/?ls)
's powerful historical masterpiece
Glory (1989) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0097441/?ls)
.
Washington has received much critical acclaim for his film work since the 1990s, including his portrayals of real-life figures such as South African anti-apartheid activist Steve Biko in
Cry Freedom (1987) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0092804/?ls)
, Muslim minister and human rights activist Malcolm X in
Malcolm X (1992) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0104797/?ls)
, boxer Rubin "Hurricane" Carter in
The Hurricane (1999) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0174856/?ls)
, football coach Herman Boone in
Remember the Titans (2000) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0210945/?ls)
, poet and educator Melvin B. Tolson in
The Great Debaters (2007) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0427309/?ls)
, and drug kingpin Frank Lucas in
American Gangster (2007) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0765429/?ls)
. Malcolm X and The Hurricane garnered him Oscar nominations for Best Actor, before he finally won that statuette in 2002 for his lead role in
Training Day (2001) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0139654/?ls)
.
Through the 1990s, Denzel also co-starred in such big budget productions as
The Pelican Brief (1993) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0107798/?ls)
,
Philadelphia (1993) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0107818/?ls)
,
Crimson Tide (1995) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0112740/?ls)
,
The Preacher's Wife (1996) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0117372/?ls)
, and
Courage Under Fire (1996) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0115956/?ls)
, a role for which he was paid $10 million. He continued to define his onscreen persona as the tough, no-nonsense hero through the 2000s in films like
Out of Time (2003) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0313443/?ls)
,
Man on Fire (2004) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0328107/?ls)
,
Inside Man (2006) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0454848/?ls)
, and
The Taking of Pelham 123 (2009) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1111422/?ls)
. Cerebral and meticulous in his film work, he made his debut as a director with
Antwone Fisher (2002) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0168786/?ls)
; he also directed
The Great Debaters (2007) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0427309/?ls)
and
Fences (2016) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2671706/?ls)
.
In 2010, Washington headlined
The Book of Eli (2010) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1037705/?ls)
, a post-Apocalyptic drama. Later that year, he starred as a veteran railroad engineer in the action film
Unstoppable (2010) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0477080/?ls)
, about an unmanned, half-mile-long runaway freight train carrying dangerous cargo. The film was his fifth and final collaboration with director
Tony Scott (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001716/?ls)
, following
Crimson Tide (1995) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0112740/?ls)
,
Man on Fire (2004) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0328107/?ls)
,
Déjà Vu (2006) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt5649074/?ls)
and The Taking of Pelham 1 2 3. He has also been a featured actor in the films produced by
Jerry Bruckheimer (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000988/?ls)
and has been a frequent collaborator of director
Spike Lee (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000490/?ls)
.
In 2012, Washington starred in
Flight (2012) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1907668/?ls)
, for which he was nominated for an Academy Award for Best Actor. He co-starred with
Ryan Reynolds (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0005351/?ls)
in
Safe House (2012) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1599348/?ls)
, and prepared for his role by subjecting himself to a torture session that included waterboarding. In 2013, Washington starred in
2 Guns (2013) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1272878/?ls)
, alongside
Mark Wahlberg (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000242/?ls)
. In 2014, he starred in
The Equalizer (2014) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0455944/?ls)
, an action thriller film directed by
Antoine Fuqua (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0298807/?ls)
and written by
Richard Wenk (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0921013/?ls)
, based on the television series of same name starring
Edward Woodward (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0940919/?ls)
. During this time period, he also took on the role of producer for some of his films, including The Book of Eli and Safe House.
In 2016, he was selected as the recipient for the Cecil B. DeMille Lifetime Achievement Award at the 73rd Golden Globe Awards.
He lives in Los Angeles, California with his wife,
Pauletta Washington (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0669353/?ls)
, and their four children.

60. Steve Carell (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0136797/?ref_=ls_t_60)
Actor
Producer
Writer
The Office (2005–2013) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0386676/?ref_=ls_knf_60)
Steve Carell, one of America's most versatile comics, was born Steven John Carell on August 16, 1962, in Concord, Massachusetts. He is the son of Harriet Theresa (Koch), a psychiatric nurse, and Edwin A. Carell, an electrical engineer. His mother was of Polish descent and his father of Italian and German ancestry (Steve's grandfather had changed the surname from "Caroselli" to "Carell"). Steve was educated at The Fenn School, an all-boys private school in Concord, Massachusetts, then at Middlesex School in Concord. After graduating from Denison University in Granville, Ohio, he moved to Chicago where he taught an improvisational comedy class and performed with The Second City troupe, alongside
Stephen Colbert (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0170306/?ls)
.
Carell made his film debut as "Tesio" in
Curly Sue (1991) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0101635/?ls)
. In 1996, he became a cast member of
The Dana Carvey Show (1996) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0115148/?ls)
, and provided the voice for Gary, opposite Colbert in "The Ambiguously Gay Duo". This animated short series produced by
Robert Smigel (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0806912/?ls)
continued on
Saturday Night Live (1975) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0072562/?ls)
, but Carell has joked that he auditioned for SNL and lost the job to
Will Ferrell (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0002071/?ls)
. Carell made a number of guest appearances on such shows as
Come to Papa (2004) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0381741/?ls)
,
Just Shoot Me! (1997) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0118364/?ls)
, and
Watching Ellie (2002) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0306410/?ls)
, before landing a regular stint as a correspondent on
The Daily Show (1996) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0115147/?ls)
from 1999 until 2005.
Carell played Evan Baxter opposite
Jim Carrey (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000120/?ls)
in
Bruce Almighty (2003) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0315327/?ls)
, and Uncle Arthur opposite
Nicole Kidman (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000173/?ls)
and
Will Ferrell (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0002071/?ls)
in
Bewitched (2005) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0374536/?ls)
. He broke out as a leading man after starring in the summer box-office hit
The 40-Year-Old Virgin (2005) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0405422/?ls)
, which he also co-wrote; the film was chosen as one of the Top Ten movies of 2006 by the American Film Institute. He next starred in the critically acclaimed
Little Miss Sunshine (2006) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0449059/?ls)
, an indie dark comedy which became a surprise hit and earned four Oscar nominations, and won two (Best Supporting Actor for
Alan Arkin (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000273/?ls)
and Best Screenplay for
Michael Arndt (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm1578335/?ls)
). In 2007, Carell reprised his role as Evan Baxter, filling Jim Carrey's leading-man shoes as a politician asked by God to build a giant ark in
Evan Almighty (2007) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0413099/?ls)
, the second installment of the "Almighty" franchise, co-starring
Lauren Graham (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0334179/?ls)
and
Morgan Freeman (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000151/?ls)
. In 2008, he re-united with Jim Carrey in the highly successful animation hit
Horton Hears a Who! (2008) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0451079/?ls)
, then appeared as Agent Maxwell Smart in the popular comedy
Get Smart (2008) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0425061/?ls)
.
Throughout this time, Carell maintained a successful career in television, starring as Michael Scott in the American remake of the Britain's existential comedy,
The Office (2005) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0386676/?ls)
. He received the Golden Globe Award for Best Actor in Television Comedy for this leading role in 2006, and earned both Emmy and Golden Globe nominations each consecutive show until he departed in 2011.
In 2010, Carell announced he was leaving "The Office" to concentrate on his film career, and has made steady appearance in such films as
Date Night (2010) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1279935/?ls)
,
Despicable Me (2010) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1323594/?ls)
,
Crazy, Stupid, Love. (2011) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1570728/?ls)
, and
Seeking a Friend for the End of the World (2012) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1307068/?ls)
. Carell's most recent roles are the comedies
Despicable Me 2 (2013) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1690953/?ls)
,
Anchorman 2: The Legend Continues (2013) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1229340/?ls)
, and
Alexander and the Terrible, Horrible, No Good, Very Bad Day (2014) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1698641/?ls)
, and the drama
Foxcatcher (2014) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1100089/?ls)
, and the more serious
Beautiful Boy (2018) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1226837/?ls)
and
Vice (2018) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt6266538/?ls)
.
Steve Carell has been enjoying a happy family life with his wife, actress
Nancy Carell (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0909391/?ls)
, whom he met when she was a student in an improv class he was teaching at The Second City comedy troupe in Chicago. The couple have two children, daughter Elizabeth (born in May 2001), and son John (born in June 2004). Steve Carell lives with his family in Los Angeles, California.

Actress

Actress and singer Selena Gomez was born on July 22, 1992 in Grand Prairie, Texas. She is the daughter of
Mandy Teefey (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm2196442/?ls)
and Ricardo Gomez. Her mother is of part Italian ancestry, and her father is of Mexican descent. She was named after Tejano singer
Selena (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0702373/?ls)
, who died in 1995.
Her first acting role was as "Gianna" in the popular '90s children's television show
Barney & Friends (1992) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0144701/?ls)
, alongside
Demi Lovato (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm1416215/?ls)
from 2002-2004. Gomez also had roles in
Spy Kids 3: Game Over (2003) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0338459/?ls)
,
Walker, Texas Ranger: Trial by Fire (2005) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0480273/?ls)
, and
House Broken (2006) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0443538/?ls)
.
Gomez moved to Los Angeles, California when she booked the lead role of "Alex Russo" and rose to fame in the Disney Channel series
Wizards of Waverly Place (2007) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0799922/?ls)
. She then starred in
Another Cinderella Story (2008) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1071358/?ls)
on ABC Family, had her first voice-role in the animated film
Horton Hears a Who! (2008) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0451079/?ls)
, and co-starred with childhood friend,
Demi Lovato (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm1416215/?ls)
, in
Princess Protection Program (2009) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1196339/?ls)
.
In 2009, Gomez released her first album with her band called
Selena Gomez & The Scene (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm4251467/?ls)
, which ranked #9 on the Billboard 200 album charts. Gomez later released two other albums with her band and starred in
Monte Carlo (2011) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1067774/?ls)
,
Spring Breakers (2012) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2101441/?ls)
, and
Hotel Transylvania (2012) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0837562/?ls)
.
In 2013, she released her first solo album "Stars Dance" and the lead single "Come & Get It" from the album, became Gomez's first top ten entry on the Billboard Hot 100 list. She starred in
Getaway (2013) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2167202/?ls)
,
Rudderless (2014) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1798243/?ls)
, and
Behaving Badly (2014) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2314824/?ls)
.
In 2015, she released her second solo album "Revival," which debuted #1 on the Billboard 200 list, and starred in
Hotel Transylvania 2 (2015) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2510894/?ls)
,
The Fundamentals of Caring (2016) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2452386/?ls)
,
In Dubious Battle (2016) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt4411618/?ls)
, and
Neighbors 2: Sorority Rising (2016) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt4438848/?ls)
. She made her third solo album "Rare" in 2020.

62. Shia LaBeouf (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0479471/?ref_=ls_t_62)
Actor
Writer
Honey Boy (2019) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt8151874/?ref_=ls_knf_62)
Shia LaBeouf's natural talent and raw energy have secured his place as one of Hollywood's leading men.
Most recently, LaBeouf starred alongside Vanessa Kirby and Ellen Burstyn in Kornel Mundruczo's Oscar® nominated Pieces of a Woman. In the critically acclaimed film, a grieving couple (Kirby/LaBeouf) embarks on an emotional journey after the loss of their baby. Previously, Shia was also seen in the crime drama, The Tax Collector, which was written and directed by David Ayer. He most recently wrapped production on Abel Ferrarra's Padre Pio which follows the life of the now saint during his time as a monk in Puglia, Italy.
LaBeouf received rave reviews for his performance in Honey Boy, which premiered at the 2019 Sundance Film Festival. The film also marks Shia's first feature length film as a screenwriter. LaBeouf portrays a law breaking, alcohol-abusing father who tries to mend his tumultuous relationship with his son (Lucas Hedges & Noah Jupe) over the course of a decade. The film received a Special Jury Award for Vision and Craft at the festival. In 2019, Shia starred in The Peanut Butter Falcon, the highest grossing indie film of the year with $20,500,000 domestic box office receipts. The film, also starring Dakota Johnson, Bruce Dern and Zachary Gottsagen, won the Audience Award at the SXSW Film Festival.
Other credits include drama, Borg vs. McEnroe (critics heralded LaBeouf's performance as "perfection," "flawless" and "explosive"); the critically acclaimed independent film American Honey , directed by Andrea Arnold, (his performance earned him a British Independent Film Award nomination for "Best Actor," a London Critics' Circle Film Award nomination for "Supporting Actor of the Year," and an Independent Spirit Award nomination for "Best Supporting Male"); the post-apocalyptic thriller, Man Down alongside Gary Oldman and Kate Mara; the war drama Fury, directed by David Ayer, opposite Brad Pitt; Lars von Trier's drama, Nymphomaniac: Vol. 1; Lars von Trier's Nymphomaniac: Vol. 2; and the suspense drama Charlie Countryman, opposite Evan Rachel Wood, Mads Mikkelsen and Melissa Leo.
LaBeouf starred in Transformers: Dark of the Moon (grossing over $1 billion worldwide), which marked his third and final turn as the enterprising and heroic Sam Witwicky. From the original Transformers released in 2007 (which earned over $700 million around the world in theatrical release and became the highest grossing DVD of the year) to the second installment in 2009, Transformers: Revenge of the Fallen, (which garnered global receipts upwards of $836 million,) Sam continued to find himself in the middle of a life and death struggle between warring robot legions on earth. Additional film credits include Robert Redford's The Company You Keep, Lawless alongside Tom Hardy, Gary Oldman and Guy Pearce, Oliver Stone's Wall Street: Money Never Sleeps opposite Michael Douglas, the fourth installment of Steven Spielberg's "Indiana Jones" series, Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull, alongside Harrison Ford, D.J. Caruso's Eagle Eye, the Anthony Minghella-scripted segment of New York, I Love You, a romantic anthology also starring Julie Christie and John Hurt, the popular thriller Disturbia, the Oscar® nominated animated film Surf's Up alongside Jeff Bridges, A Guide to Recognizing Your Saints, which won "Best Ensemble Cast" at the Sundance Film Festival, Emilio Estevez's acclaimed drama Bobby, Disney's The Greatest Game Ever Played which follows the true story of a 19-year-old amateur athlete's journey to winning the U.S. Open, I, Robot, Constantine, Charlie's Angels: Full Throttle, HBO's "Project Greenlight" featuring The Battle of Shaker Heights produced by Matt Damon and Ben Affleck and in 2003 he made his feature film debut in the comedy Holes, based on the best-selling book by Louis Sacher.
On television, LaBeouf garnered much praise from critics everywhere for his portrayal of "Louis Stevens" on the Disney Channel's original series "Even Stevens." In 2003, he earned a Daytime Emmy award for "Outstanding Performer in a Children's Series" for his work on the highly-rated family show.

Megan Denise Fox was born on May 16, 1986 in Oak Ridge, Tennessee and raised in Rockwood, Tennessee to Gloria Darlene Tonachio (née Cisson), a real estate manager and Franklin Thomas Fox, a parole officer. Mary-Kate Olsen (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001581/?ls)
and
Ashley Olsen (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001580/?ls)
film,
Holiday in the Sun (2001) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0297169/?ls)
. Her best-known roles are as Sam Witwicky's love interest, Mikaela Banes in
Transformers (2007) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0418279/?ls)
and
Transformers: Revenge of the Fallen (2009) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1055369/?ls)
, as April O'Neil in the remake
Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles (2014) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1291150/?ls)
and its sequel
Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Out of the Shadows (2016) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt3949660/?ls)

Known for his breakthrough starring role on
Freaks and Geeks (1999) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0193676/?ls)
, James Franco was born April 19, 1978 in Palo Alto, California, to
Betsy Franco (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm4136056/?ls)
, a writer, artist, and actress, and Douglas Eugene "Doug" Franco, who ran a Silicon Valley business. His mother is Jewish and his father was of Portuguese and Swedish descent.
Growing up with his two younger brothers,
Dave Franco (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm2002649/?ls)
, also an actor, and
Tom Franco (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm2703058/?ls)
, James graduated from Palo Alto High School in 1996 and went on to attend UCLA, majoring in English. To overcome his shyness, he got into acting while studying there, which, much to his parents' dismay, he left after only one year. After fifteen months of intensive study at Robert Carnegie's Playhouse West, James began actively pursuing his dream of finding work as an actor in Hollywood. In that short time, he landed himself a starring role on
Freaks and Geeks (1999) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0193676/?ls)
. The show, however, was not a hit to its viewers at the time, and was canceled after its first year. Now, it has become a cult-hit. Prior to joining
Freaks and Geeks (1999) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0193676/?ls)
, Franco starred in the TV miniseries
To Serve and Protect (1999) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0181216/?ls)
. After that, he had a starring role in
Whatever It Takes (2000) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0202402/?ls)
.
Although he'd been working steadily, it wasn't until the TNT made-for-television movie,
James Dean (2001) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0240628/?ls)
that James rose to fan-magazine fame and got to show off his talent. Since then, he has been working non-stop. After losing the lead role to
Tobey Maguire (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001497/?ls)
, James settled for the part of "Harry Osborne", Spider-Man's best friend in the summer 2002 major hit
Spider-Man (2002) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0145487/?ls)
. He returned to the Osborne role for the next two films in the trilogy.
Next was
Deuces Wild (2002) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0231448/?ls)
and
City by the Sea (2002) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0269095/?ls)
, in which
Robert De Niro (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000134/?ls)
personally had him cast, after viewing his performance in
James Dean (2001) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0240628/?ls)
. He was seen in
David Gordon Green (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0337773/?ls)
's
Pineapple Express (2008) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0910936/?ls)
opposite
Seth Rogen (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0736622/?ls)
, in
George C. Wolfe (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0938045/?ls)
's
Nights in Rodanthe (2008) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0956038/?ls)
, starring
Richard Gere (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000152/?ls)
and
Diane Lane (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000178/?ls)
and in
Paul Haggis (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0353673/?ls)
'
In the Valley of Elah (2007) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0478134/?ls)
, starring
Tommy Lee Jones (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000169/?ls)
. Also starring opposite
Sean Penn (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000576/?ls)
in
Gus Van Sant (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001814/?ls)
's
Milk (2008) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1013753/?ls)
in which his performance earned him an Independent Spirit Award for Best Supporting Actor. Definitely growing out of his shyness, James Franco is turning into a legend of his own.

65. Mel Gibson (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000154/?ref_=ls_t_65)
Actor
Producer
Director
Braveheart (1995) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0112573/?ref_=ls_knf_65)
Mel Columcille Gerard Gibson was born January 3, 1956 in Peekskill, New York, USA, as the sixth of eleven children of
Hutton Gibson (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm1585176/?ls)
, a railroad brakeman, and Anne Patricia (Reilly) Gibson (who died in December of 1990). His mother was Irish, from County Longford, while his American-born father is of mostly Irish descent.
Mel and his family moved to Australia in the late 1960s, settling in New South Wales, where Mel's paternal grandmother, contralto opera singer Eva Mylott, was born. After high school, Mel studied at the University of New South Wales in Sydney, performing at the National Institute of Dramatic Arts alongside future film thespians
Judy Davis (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001114/?ls)
and
Geoffrey Rush (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001691/?ls)
.
After college, Mel had a few stints on stage and starred in a few TV shows. Eventually, he was chosen to star in the films
Mad Max (1979) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0079501/?ls)
and
Tim (1979) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0080024/?ls)
, co-starring
Piper Laurie (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001453/?ls)
. The small budgeted Mad Max made him known worldwide, while Tim garnered him an award for Best Actor from the Australian Film Institute (equivalent to the Oscar).
Later, he went on to star in
Gallipoli (1981) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0082432/?ls)
, which earned him a second award for Best Actor from the AFI.
In 1980, he married Robyn Moore and had seven children. In 1984, Mel made his American debut in
The Bounty (1984) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0086993/?ls)
, which co-starred
Anthony Hopkins (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000164/?ls)
.
Then in 1987, Mel starred in what would become his signature series,
Lethal Weapon (1987) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0093409/?ls)
, in which he played "Martin Riggs". In 1990, he took on the interesting starring role in
Hamlet (1990) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0099726/?ls)
, which garnered him some critical praise.
He also made the more endearing
Forever Young (1992) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0104291/?ls)
and the somewhat disturbing
The Man Without a Face (1993) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0107501/?ls)
.
1995 brought his most famous role as "Sir William Wallace" in
Braveheart (1995) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0112573/?ls)
, for which he won two Oscars for Best Picture and Best Director.
From there, he made such box office hits as
The Patriot (2000) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0187393/?ls)
,
Ransom (1996) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0117438/?ls)
, and
Payback (1999) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0120784/?ls)
. Today, Mel remains an international superstar mogul, continuously topping the Hollywood power lists as well as the Most Beautiful and Sexiest lists.

66. Vin Diesel (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0004874/?ref_=ls_t_66)
Producer
Actor
Director
Guardians of the Galaxy (2014) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2015381/?ref_=ls_knf_66)
Vin Diesel was born Mark Sinclair in Alameda County, California, along with his fraternal twin brother,
Paul Vincent (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0898731/?ls)
. He was raised by his astrologer/psychologist mother, Delora Sherleen (Sinclair), and adoptive father, Irving H. Vincent, an acting instructor and theatre manager, in an artists' housing project in New York City's Greenwich Village. He never knew his biological father. His mother is white (with English, German, Scottish, and Irish ancestry), and his adoptive father is African-American; referring to his biological father's background, Diesel has said that he himself is "definitely a person of colour".
His first break in acting happened by chance, when at the age of seven he and his friends broke into a theatre to vandalize it. A woman stopped them and offered them each a script and $20, on the condition that they would attend everyday after school. From there, Vin's fledgling career progressed from the New York repertory company run by his father, to the Off-Off-Broadway circuit. At age seventeen and already sporting a well-honed physique, he became a bouncer at some of New York's hippest clubs to earn himself some extra cash. It was at this time that he changed his name to Vin Diesel.
Following high school, Vin enrolled as an English major at Hunter College, but dropped out after three years to go to Hollywood to further his acting career. Being an experienced theatre actor did not make any impression in Hollywood and after a year of struggling to make his mark, he returned to New York. His mother then gave him a book called "Feature Films at used Car Prices" by Rick Schmidt. The book showed him that he could take control of his career and make his own movies. He wrote a short film based on his own experiences as an actor, called
Multi-Facial (1995) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0226168/?ls)
, which was shot in less than three days at a cost of $3,000.
Multi-Facial (1995) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0226168/?ls)
was eventually accepted for the 1995 Cannes Film Festival where it got a tumultuous reception.
Afterwards, Vin returned to Los Angeles and raised almost $50,000 through telemarketing to fund the making of his first feature,
Strays (1997) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0149171/?ls)
. Six months after shooting, the film was accepted for the 1997 Sundance Film Festival, and although it received a good reception, it did not sell as well as hoped. Yet again Vin returned disappointed to New York only to receive a dream phone call.
Steven Spielberg (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000229/?ls)
was impressed by
Multi-Facial (1995) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0226168/?ls)
and wanted to meet Vin, leading him to be cast in
Saving Private Ryan (1998) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0120815/?ls)
.
Multi-Facial (1995) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0226168/?ls)
earned Vin more work, when the director of
The Iron Giant (1999) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0129167/?ls)
saw it and decided to cast Vin in the title role. From there, Vin's career steadily grew, with him securing his first lead role, as Richard B. Riddick in the sci-fi film
Pitch Black (2000) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0134847/?ls)
. The role has earned him a legion of devoted fans and the public recognition he deserves.
Since then, he has headlined a series of blockbusters, often but not only centered on fast-driving motor vehicles:
The Fast and the Furious (2001) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0232500/?ls)
,
xXx (2002) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0295701/?ls)
,
The Pacifier (2005) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0395699/?ls)
,
Fast & Furious (2009) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1013752/?ls)
,
Fast Five (2011) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1596343/?ls)
,
Fast & Furious 6 (2013) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1905041/?ls)
, and
Furious 7 (2015) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2820852/?ls)
. He also voiced Groot in
Guardians of the Galaxy (2014) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2015381/?ls)
and starred in the lower-budgeted courtroom drama
Find Me Guilty (2006) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0419749/?ls)
, the latter directed by
Sidney Lumet (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001486/?ls)
.

Toy Story (1995) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0114709/?ref_=ls_knf_67)
Timothy Allen Dick was born on June 13, 1953, in Denver, Colorado, to Martha Katherine (Fox) and Gerald M. Dick. His father, a real estate salesman, was killed in a collision with a drunk driver while driving his family home from a University of Colorado football game, when Tim was eleven years old. His mother, a community service worker, remarried her high school sweetheart, an Episcopalian deacon, two years after Tim's father's death. He was raised with his many siblings and step-siblings. When Tim was young, his family moved to Birmingham, Michigan.
In high school, his favorite subject was shop, of course, and after high school, he attended Western Michigan University and graduated with a degree in Television Production in 1975. In 1978, he was arrested on drug charges and spent two years in jail. Upon his release, he had a new outlook on life and on a dare from a friend, started his comedy career at the Comedy Castle in the Northern suburbs of Detroit. Later, he went on to do several cable specials, including,
Comedy's Dirtiest Dozen (1988) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0188516/?ls)
and
Tim Allen: Men Are Pigs (1990) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0259057/?ls)
. In 1991, he became the star of his own hit television series on ABC called
Home Improvement (1991) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0101120/?ls)
. While continuing to film his television series throughout most of the 1990s, he starred in a string of blockbuster movies, including
The Santa Clause (1994) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0111070/?ls)
,
Toy Story (1995) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0114709/?ls)
,
Toy Story 2 (1999) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0120363/?ls)
and
Galaxy Quest (1999) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0177789/?ls)
. In August 1996, he developed and unveiled his own signature line of power tools, manufactured by Ryobi. On top of all that, he has his own racing team, Tim Allen/Saleen RRRRacing. In May 1999, he ended his series
Home Improvement (1991) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0101120/?ls)
after eight seasons and in 2001, he filmed such movies as
Big Trouble (2002) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0246464/?ls)
and
Joe Somebody (2001) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0279889/?ls)
.

68. Robin Williams (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000245/?ref_=ls_t_68)

Writer
Producer
Mrs. Doubtfire (1993) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0107614/?ref_=ls_knf_68)
Robin McLaurin Williams was born on Saturday, July 21st, 1951, in Chicago, Illinois, a great-great-grandson of Mississippi Governor and Senator, Anselm J. McLaurin. His mother, Laurie McLaurin (née Janin), was a former model from
Mississippi, and his father, Robert Fitzgerald Williams, was a Ford Motor Company executive from Indiana. Williams had English, German, French, Welsh, Irish, and Scottish ancestry.
Robin briefly studied political science at Claremont Men's College and theater at College of Marin before enrolling at The Juilliard School to focus on theater. After leaving Juilliard, he performed in nightclubs where he was discovered for the role of "Mork, from Ork", in an episode of
Happy Days (1974) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0070992/?ls)
. The episode,
My Favorite Orkan (1978) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0596274/?ls)
, led to his famous spin-off weekly TV series,
Mork & Mindy (1978) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0077053/?ls)
. He made his feature starring debut playing the title role in
Popeye (1980) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0081353/?ls)
, directed by
Robert Altman (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000265/?ls)
.
Williams' continuous comedies and wild comic talents involved a great deal of improvisation, following in the footsteps of his idol
Jonathan Winters (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0005565/?ls)
. Williams also proved to be an effective dramatic actor, receiving Academy Award nominations for Best Actor in a Leading Role in
Good Morning, Vietnam (1987) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0093105/?ls)
,
Dead Poets Society (1989) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0097165/?ls)
, and
The Fisher King (1991) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0101889/?ls)
, before winning the Academy Award for Best Actor in a Supporting Role in
Good Will Hunting (1997) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0119217/?ls)
.
During the 1990s, Williams became a beloved hero to children the world over for his roles in a string of hit family-oriented films, including
Hook (1991) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0102057/?ls)
,
FernGully: The Last Rainforest (1992) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0104254/?ls)
,
Aladdin (1992) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0103639/?ls)
,
Mrs. Doubtfire (1993) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0107614/?ls)
,
Jumanji (1995) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0113497/?ls)
,
Flubber (1997) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0119137/?ls)
, and
Bicentennial Man (1999) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0182789/?ls)
. He continued entertaining children and families into the 21st century with his work in
Robots (2005) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0358082/?ls)
,
Happy Feet (2006) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0366548/?ls)
,
Night at the Museum (2006) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0477347/?ls)
,
Night at the Museum: Battle of the Smithsonian (2009) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1078912/?ls)
,
Happy Feet Two (2011) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1402488/?ls)
, and
Night at the Museum: Secret of the Tomb (2014) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2692250/?ls)
. Other more adult-oriented films for which Williams received acclaim include
The World According to Garp (1982) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0084917/?ls)
,
Moscow on the Hudson (1984) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0087747/?ls)
,
Awakenings (1990) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0099077/?ls)
,
The Birdcage (1996) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0115685/?ls)
,
Insomnia (2002) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0278504/?ls)
,
One Hour Photo (2002) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0265459/?ls)
,
World's Greatest Dad (2009) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1262981/?ls)
, and
Boulevard (2014) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2624412/?ls)
.
On Monday, August 11th, 2014, Robin Williams was found dead at his home in Tiburon, California USA, the victim of an apparent suicide, according to the Marin County Sheriff's Office. A 911 call was received at 11:55 a.m. PDT, firefighters and paramedics arrived at his home at 12:00 p.m. PDT, and he was pronounced dead at 12:02 p.m. PDT.

Jason Matthew Biggs was born on May 12, 1978, in Pompton Plains, New

manager. Jason has two sisters, Heather, a tax specialist born in 1971,
and Chiara, born in 1980. He was raised Catholic, and is of English and mostly Italian descent. Jason started acting at age five, appearing in several
national commercials. In 1991, at 13 he won a part on the FOX sitcom
Drexell's Class (1991) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0101085/?ls)

Camp Stories (1996) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0115811/?ls)

. His performance

71. Jean-Claude Van Damme (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000241/?ref_=ls_t_71)
Actor
Producer
Writer
Double Impact (1991) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0101764/?ref_=ls_knf_71)
Van Damme was born Jean-Claude Camille François Van Varenberg in Berchem-Sainte-Agathe, Brussels, Belgium, to
Eliana and Eugène Van Varenberg, an accountant. "The Muscles from
Brussels" started
martial arts at the age of eleven. His father introduced him to martial
arts when he saw his son was physically weak. At the age of 12, Van
Damme began his martial arts training at Centre National De Karate
(National Center of Karate) under the guidance of Master
Claude Goetz (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm1851360/?ls)
in Ixelles, Belgium. Van Damme
trained for 4 years and earned a spot on the Belgium Karate Team. He
won the European professional karate association's middleweight
championship as a teenager, and also beat the 2nd best karate fighter
in the world. His goal was to be number one but got sidetracked when he
left his hometown of Brussels. In 1976 at the age of sixteen,
Jean-Claude started his Martial Arts fight career.
Over the next
6-years, he competed in both full-contact and semi-contact matches. He
debuted under his birth name of Jean Claude Van Varenberg. In his first
match, Jean-Claude was staggered by a round-house kick thrown by fellow
countryman, Toon Van Oostrum in Brussels, Belgium. Van Damme was badly
stunned, but came back to knockout Van Oostrum moments later. In 1977,
at the WAKO Open International in Antwerp, Belgium, Jean-Claude lost a
decision to fellow team mate Patrick Teugels in a semi-contact match.
At the 1978 Challenge De Espoirs Karate Tournament (1st
Trials),Jean-Claude placed 2nd in the semi-contact division. He
defeated twenty-five opponents during the week long tournament, but
lost in the finals to Angelo Spataro from the Naha Club. Later in 1978,
Jean-Claude lost a 3-round match for the Belgium Lightweight
Championship (semi-contact) to his fellow team-mate to Patrick Teugels.
In 1979, Jean-Claude traveled to the United States of America, to
Tampa, Florida. In his first and only match against a United States
opponent, Van Damme faced 'Sherman 'Big Train'Bergman', a kick-boxer
from Miami Beach, Florida. For the first and only time in his career,
Jean-Claude was knocked to the canvas after absorbing a powerful left
hook from Bergman. However, Jean-Claude climbed off the canvas and with
a perfectly timed ax-kick, knocked Bergman out in 56 seconds of the
first round. Jean-Claude was a member of the Belgium team which
competed on December 26, 1979 at the La Coupe Fancois Persoons Karate
Tournament which was sanctioned by the Federation bruxelloise de
Karate. Van Damme's final match victory enabled his team to win the
European Team Karate Championship. In Full-Contact karate, Jean-Claude
knocked out England's Micheal Heming in 46 seconds of the first round.
In 1980, Van Damme knocked out France's Georges Verlugels in 2 rounds
of a match fought under kick-boxing rules. Jean-Claude wanted to defeat
his rival Patrick Teugels. At the Forest Nationals in Brussels, on
March 8, 1980, Jean-Claude knocked Teugels down and Teugels suffered a
nose injury and was unable to continue. Jean-Claude was awarded a first
round victory.
Jean-Claude retired from martial arts in 1982, following
a knockout over Nedjad Gharbi in Brussels,Belgium. Jean-Claude posted a
18-1 (18 knockouts) Kickboxing record, and a Semi-Contact record of
41-4. He came to Hong Kong at the age of 19 for the first time and felt
insured to do action movies in Hong Kong. In 1981 Van Damme moved to
Los Angeles. He took English classes while working as carpet layer,
pizza delivery man, limo driver, and thanks to
Chuck Norris (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001569/?ls)
he got a job as a bouncer at a
club. Norris gave Van Damme a small role in the movie
Missing in Action (1984) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0087727/?ls)
, but
it wasn't good enough to get anybody's attention. Then in 1984 he got a
role as a villain named Ivan in the low-budget movie
No Retreat, No Surrender (1986) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0089695/?ls)
.
Then one day, while walking on the streets, Jean-Claude spotted a
producer for Cannon Pictures, and showed some of his martial arts
abilities which led to a role in
Bloodsport (1988) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0092675/?ls)
. But the movie,
filmed in Hong Kong, was so bad when it was completed, it was shelved
for almost two years. It might have never been released if Van Damme
did not help them to recut the film and begged producers to release it.
They finally released the film, first in Malaysia and France and then
into the U.S. Shot on a meager $1.5 million dollar budget, it became a
U.S box-office hit in the spring of 1988. It made about $50 million
worldwide and audiences supported this film for its new sensational
action star Jean-Claude Van Damme.
His martial arts assets, highlighted
by his ability to deliver a kick to an opponent's head during a leaping
360-degree turn, and his good looks led to starring roles in higher
budgeted movies like
Cyborg (1989) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0097138/?ls)
,
Lionheart (1990) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0100029/?ls)
,
Double Impact (1991) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0101764/?ls)
and
Universal Soldier (1992) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0105698/?ls)
. In
1994, he scored with his big breakthrough $100 million worldwide hit
Timecop (1994) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0111438/?ls)
. But in the meantime, his
personal life was coming apart. A divorce, followed by a new marriage,
followed by another divorce. It began to show up in his career when his
projects began to tank at the box office -
The Quest (1996) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0117420/?ls)
, which he directed;
Maximum Risk (1996) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0117011/?ls)
and
Double Team (1997) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0119013/?ls)
. The three films
made less than $50 million combined. In 1999 he remarried his ex-wife
Gladys Portugues (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0692543/?ls)
and restarted his lost
career to attain new goals. With help from his family he faced his
problems and made movies like
Replicant (2001) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0238552/?ls)
,
Derailed (2002) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0298296/?ls)
, and
In Hell (2003) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0339135/?ls)
which did averagely in box
office terms, but he tried to give his fans the best, his acting in
those movies got better, more emotional and each movie was basically in
different action tones.

Self-proclaimed troublemaker Owen Cunningham Wilson was born in Dallas, to Irish-American parents originally from Massachusetts. He grew up in Texas with his mother, Laura (Cunningham), a photographer; his father, Robert Andrew Wilson, an ad exec; and his brothers,
Andrew Wilson (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0932992/?ls)
(the eldest) and
Luke Wilson (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0005561/?ls)
(the youngest). Expelled from St. Mark's School of Texas (Dallas, TX) in the tenth grade, Wilson finished his sophomore year at Thomas Jefferson School and then headed to a military academy in New Mexico. He then attended the University of Texas at Austin, where he met his future mentor and friend,
Wes Anderson (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0027572/?ls)
. They wrote a screenplay,
Bottle Rocket (1996) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0115734/?ls)
, and sent it to their family friend, screenwriter
L.M. Kit Carson (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0141281/?ls)
, who sent it to producer
Polly Platt (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0686895/?ls)
, who gave it to
James L. Brooks (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000985/?ls)
, who gave the Texans $5 million to make it into a feature film. Despite critical praise,
Bottle Rocket (1996) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0115734/?ls)
only grossed one million dollars. After making the film, Wilson moved to Hollywood, setting up house with his two brothers and Anderson. Fairly quickly, Owen found himself acting in a series of big budget films, such as
The Cable Guy (1996) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0115798/?ls)
,
The Haunting (1999) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0171363/?ls)
,
Anaconda (1997) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0118615/?ls)
and
Breakfast of Champions (1999) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0120618/?ls)
. This led to more work, such as
Shanghai Noon (2000) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0184894/?ls)
,
Meet the Parents (2000) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0212338/?ls)
and
Behind Enemy Lines (2001) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0159273/?ls)
. He's known not only for his nose, which has been broken several times, but also for his 'free wheeling ways' with a script. He co-wrote the film
The Royal Tenenbaums (2001) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0265666/?ls)
with his oft partner
Wes Anderson (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0027572/?ls)
.

The Secret Agent (1996) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0117582/?ls)
,
Metroland (1997) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0119665/?ls)
,
Velvet Goldmine (1998) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0120879/?ls)
,
All the Little Animals (1998) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0120584/?ls)
, and
A Midsummer Night's Dream (1999) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0140379/?ls)
. Toward the end of the decade, with the rise of the Internet, Bale found himself becoming one of the most popular online celebrities around, though he, with a couple notable exceptions, maintained a private, tabloid-free mystique.
Bale roared into the next decade with a lead role in
American Psycho (2000) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0144084/?ls)
, director
Mary Harron (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0366004/?ls)
's adaptation of the controversial
Bret Easton Ellis (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0254735/?ls)
novel. In the film, Bale played a murderous Wall Street executive obsessed with his own physicality - a trait for which Bale would become a specialist. Subsequently, the 10th Anniversary issue for "Entertainment Weekly" crowned Bale one of the "Top 8 Most Powerful Cult Figures" of the past decade, citing his cult status on the Internet. EW also called Bale one of the "Most Creative People in Entertainment", and "Premiere" lauded him as one of the "Hottest Leading Men Under 30".
Bale was truly on the Hollywood radar at this time, and he turned in a range of performances in the remake
Shaft (2000) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0162650/?ls)
,
Captain Corelli's Mandolin (2001) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0238112/?ls)
, the balmy
Laurel Canyon (2002) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0298408/?ls)
, and
Reign of Fire (2002) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0253556/?ls)
, a dragons-and-magic commercial misfire that has its share of defenders.
Two more cult films followed:
Equilibrium (2002) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0238380/?ls)
and
The Machinist (2004) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0361862/?ls)
, the latter of which gained attention mainly due to Bale's physical transformation - he dropped a reported 60+ pounds for the role of a lathe operator with a secret that causes him to suffer from insomnia for over a year.
Bale's abilities to transform his body and to disappear into a character influenced the decision to cast him in
Batman Begins (2005) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0372784/?ls)
, the first chapter in
Christopher Nolan (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0634240/?ls)
's definitive trilogy that proved a dark-themed narrative could resonate with audiences worldwide. The film also resurrected a character that had been shelved by Warner Bros. after a series of demising returns, capped off by the commercial and critical failure of
Batman & Robin (1997) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0118688/?ls)
. A quiet, personal victory for Bale: he accepted the role after the passing of his father in late 2003, an event that caused him to question whether he would continue performing.
Bale segued into two indie features in the wake of Batman's phenomenal success:
The New World (2005) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0402399/?ls)
and
Harsh Times (2005) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0433387/?ls)
. He continued working with respected independent directors in 2006's
Rescue Dawn (2006) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0462504/?ls)
,
Werner Herzog (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001348/?ls)
's feature version of his earlier, Emmy-nominated documentary,
Little Dieter Needs to Fly (1997) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0145046/?ls)
. Leading up to the second Batman film, Bale starred in
The Prestige (2006) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0482571/?ls)
, the remake of
3:10 to Yuma (2007) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0381849/?ls)
, and a reunion with director
Todd Haynes (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001331/?ls)
in the experimental
Bob Dylan (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001168/?ls)
biography,
I'm Not There (2007) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0368794/?ls)
.
Anticipation for
The Dark Knight (2008) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0468569/?ls)
was spun into unexpected heights with the tragic passing of
Heath Ledger (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0005132/?ls)
, whose performance as The Joker became the highlight of the sequel. Bale's graceful statements to the press reminded us of the days of the refined Hollywood star as the second installment exceeded the box-office performance of its predecessor.
Bale's next role was the eyebrow-raising decision to take over the role of John Connor in the Schwarzenegger-less
Terminator Salvation (2009) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0438488/?ls)
, followed by a turn as federal agent Melvin Purvis in
Michael Mann (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000520/?ls)
's
Public Enemies (2009) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1152836/?ls)
. Both films were hits but not the blockbusters they were expected to be.
For all his acclaim and box-office triumphs, Bale would earn his first Oscar in 2011 in the wake of
The Fighter (2010) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0964517/?ls)
's critical and commercial success. Bale earned the Best Supporting Actor award for his portrayal of Dicky Eklund, brother to and trainer of boxer "Irish" Micky Ward, played by
Mark Wahlberg (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000242/?ls)
. Bale again showed his ability to reshape his body with another gaunt, skeletal transformation.
Bale then turned to another auteur,
Yimou Zhang (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0955443/?ls)
, for the epic
The Flowers of War (2011) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1410063/?ls)
, in which Bale portrayed a priest trapped in the midst of the Rape of Nanking. Bale earned headlines for his attempt to visit with Chinese civil-rights activist Chen Guangcheng, which was blocked by the Chinese government.
Bale capped his role as Bruce Wayne/Batman in
The Dark Knight Rises (2012) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1345836/?ls)
; in the wake of the Aurora, Colorado tragedy, Bale made a quiet pilgrimage to the state to visit with survivors of the attack that left theatergoers dead and injured. He also starred in the thriller
Out of the Furnace (2013) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1206543/?ls)
with
Crazy Heart (2009) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1263670/?ls)
writer/director
Scott Cooper (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0178376/?ls)
, and the drama-comedy
American Hustle (2013) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1800241/?ls)
, reuniting with David O. Russell.
Bale will re-team with
The New World (2005) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0402399/?ls)
director
Terrence Malick (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000517/?ls)
for two upcoming projects:
Knight of Cups (2015) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2101383/?ls)
and an as-yet-untitled drama.
In his personal life, he devotes time to charities including Greenpeace and the World Wildlife Foundation. He lives with his wife,
Sibi Blazic (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0088023/?ls)
, and their two children.
[No Text] (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001392/?ref_=ls_i_74)
74. Peter Jackson (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001392/?ref_=ls_t_74)
Producer
Director
Writer
The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring (2001) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0120737/?ref_=ls_knf_74)
Sir Peter Jackson made history with The Lord of the Rings trilogy, becoming the first person to direct three major feature films simultaneously. The Fellowship of the Ring, The Two Towers and The Return of the King were nominated for and collected a slew of awards from around the globe, with The Return of the King receiving his most impressive collection of awards. This included three Academy Awards® (Best Adapted Screenplay, Best Director and Best Picture), two Golden Globes (Best Director and Best Motion Picture-Drama), three BAFTAs (Best Adapted Screenplay, Best Film and Viewers' Choice), a Directors Guild Award, a Producers Guild Award and a New York Film Critics Circle Award.
As a follow up to The Lord of the Rings trilogy, in 2005, Jackson directed, wrote, and produced King Kong, for Universal Pictures. The film grossed over $500 million and won three Oscars®.
Jackson previously received widespread acclaim for his 1994 feature Heavenly Creatures, which received an Academy Award® nomination for Best Screenplay. Other film credits include The Frighteners, starring Michael J. Fox; the adult puppet feature Meet the Feebles; and Braindead, which won 16 international science fiction awards, including the Saturn. Jackson also co-directed the television documentary Forgotten Silver, which also hit the film festival circuit.
Jackson directed the Academy Award®-nominated The Lovely Bones, an adaptation of the acclaimed best-selling novel by Alice Sebold and produced the worldwide sci-fi hit District 9. He was a producer on Steven Spielberg's The Adventures of Tintin: The Secret of the Unicorn in 2011, with two more films set to come out in the future.
His most recent films include producer of 2018's action film Mortal Engines, based on a post-apocalyptic world where cities ride on wheels and consume each other to survive. Following Mortal Engines, he produced They Shall Not Grow Old, a documentary on World War I with never-before-seen footage. BAFTA nominated the film for Best Documentary, and it won the award for Outstanding Achievement in Sound Editing from the Motion Picture Sound Editors.
Jackson's next project is the music documentary The Beatles: Get Back, which he directed and produced, due to be released August, 2021.
Jackson works closely with partner Dame Fran Walsh, with whom he shares his writing and producing credits, as well as a family. Jackson has a special interest in WWI memorabilia and is the proud owner of several aircraft from that era.
[No Text] (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000113/?ref_=ls_i_75)
75. Sandra Bullock (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000113/?ref_=ls_t_75)
Producer
Actress
Music Department
The Proposal (2009) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1041829/?ref_=ls_knf_75)
Sandra Annette Bullock was born in Arlington, a Virginia suburb of Washington, D.C. Her
mother,
Helga Bullock (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm1184542/?ls)
(née Helga Mathilde
Meyer), was a German opera singer. Her father, John W. Bullock, was an
American voice teacher, who was born in Alabama, of German descent. Sandra grew up on the road with her parents
and younger sister, chef
Gesine Bullock-Prado (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm1618331/?ls)
, and spent much of her childhood in Nuremberg, Germany. She often performed in the children's chorus of
whatever production her mother was in. That singing talent later came
in handy for her role as an aspiring country singer in
The Thing Called Love (1993) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0108327/?ls)
.
Her family moved back to the Washington area when she was adolescent.
She later enrolled in East Carolina University in North Carolina, where
she studied acting. Shortly afterward she moved to New York to pursue a
career on the stage. This led to acting in television programs and then
feature films. She gave memorable performances in
Demolition Man (1993) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0106697/?ls)
and
Wrestling Ernest Hemingway (1993) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0108596/?ls)
,
but did not achieve the stardom that seemed inevitable for her until
her work in the smash hit
Speed (1994) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0111257/?ls)
. She
now ranks as one of the most popular actresses in Hollywood. For her
role in
The Blind Side (2009) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0878804/?ls)
she
won the Oscar, and her blockbusters
The Proposal (2009) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1041829/?ls)
,
The Heat (2013) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2404463/?ls)
and
Gravity (2013) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1454468/?ls)
made her a bankable star.
With $56,000,000, she was listed in the Guinness Book Of World Records
as the highest-paid actress in the world.

1. Donald Sutherland (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000661/?ref_=ls_t_1)
Actor
Producer
Writer
The Hunger Games: Catching Fire (2013) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1951264/?ref_=ls_knf_1)
The towering presence of Canadian actor Donald Sutherland was often
noticed, as were his legendary contributions to cinema. He appeared in almost 200 different shows and films. He was also the father of renowned actor
Kiefer Sutherland (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000662/?ls)
, among others.
Donald McNichol Sutherland was born in Saint John, New Brunswick, to Dorothy Isobel
(McNichol) and Frederick McLea Sutherland, who worked in sales and
electricity. He had Scottish, as well as German and English, ancestry. Sutherland
worked in several different jobs - he was a radio DJ in his youth - and
was almost set on becoming an engineer after graduating from the
University of Toronto with a degree in engineering. However, he also
graduated with a degree in drama, and he chose to abandon becoming an
engineer in favour of an actor.
Sutherland's first roles were bit parts and consisted of such films as
the horror film
Dr. Terror's House of Horrors (1965) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0059125/?ls)
which starred
Christopher Lee (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000489/?ls)
.
He was also appearing in episodes of TV shows such as "The Saint" and
"Court Martial". Sutherland's break would come soon, though, and it
would come in the form of a war film in which he was barely cast.
The reason he was barely cast was because he had been a last-minute
replacement for an actor that had dropped out of the film. The role he
played was that of the dopey but loyal Vernon Pinkley in the war film
The Dirty Dozen (1967) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0061578/?ls)
. The film
also starred
Lee Marvin (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001511/?ls)
,
Charles Bronson (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000314/?ls)
, and
Telly Savalas (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001699/?ls)
. The picture was an instant
success as an action/war film, and Sutherland played upon this success
by taking another role in a war film: this was, however, a comedy
called
M*A*S*H (1970) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0066026/?ls)
which landed Sutherland
the starring role alongside
Elliott Gould (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001285/?ls)
and
Tom Skerritt (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000643/?ls)
. This is now
considered a classic among film goers, and the 35-year old actor was
only getting warmed up.
Sutherland took a number of other roles in between these two films,
such as the theatrical adaptation
Oedipus the King (1968) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0063376/?ls)
, the
musical
Joanna (1968) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0063157/?ls)
and the
Clint Eastwood (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000142/?ls)
-helmed war comedy
Kelly's Heroes (1970) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0065938/?ls)
. It was
Kelly's Heroes (1970) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0065938/?ls)
that became
more well-known, and it reunited Sutherland with
Telly Savalas (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001699/?ls)
. 1970 and 1971 offered
Sutherland a number of other films, the best of them would have to be
Klute (1971) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0067309/?ls)
. The film, which made
Jane Fonda (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000404/?ls)
a star, is about a prostitute
whose friend is mysteriously murdered. Sutherland received no critical
acclaim like his co-star Fonda (she won an Oscar) but his career did
not fade.
Moving on from
Klute (1971) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0067309/?ls)
, Sutherland
landed roles such as the lead in the thriller
Lady Ice (1973) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0070284/?ls)
, and another lead in the
western
Alien Thunder (1974) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0069688/?ls)
. These
films did not match up to "Klute"'s success, though Sutherland took a
supporting role that would become one of his most infamous and most
critically acclaimed. He played the role of the murderous fascist
leader in the
Bernardo Bertolucci (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000934/?ls)
Italian epic
1900 (1976) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0074084/?ls)
.
Sutherland also gained another memorable role as a marijuana-smoking
university professor in
National Lampoon's Animal House (1978) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0077975/?ls)
among other work
that he did in this time.
Another classic role came in the form of the
Robert Redford (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000602/?ls)
film,
Ordinary People (1980) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0081283/?ls)
.
Sutherland portrayed an older father figure who must deal with his
children in an emotional drama of a film. It won Best Picture, and
while both the supporting stars were nominated for Oscars, Sutherland
once again did not receive any Academy Award nomination. He moved on to
play a Nazi spy in a film based on
Ken Follett (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0284336/?ls)
's book "Eye of the Needle" and
he would star alongside
Al Pacino (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000199/?ls)
in the
commercial and critical disaster that was
Revolution (1985) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0089913/?ls)
. While it drove
Al Pacino (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000199/?ls)
out of films for four years,
Sutherland continued to find work. This work led to the dramatic,
well-told story of apartheid
A Dry White Season (1989) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0097243/?ls)
alongside the legendary actor
Marlon Brando (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000008/?ls)
.
Sutherland's next big success came in the
Oliver Stone (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000231/?ls)
film
JFK (1991) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0102138/?ls)
where Sutherland plays the
chilling role of Mister X, an anonymous source who gives crucial
information about the politics surrounding President Kennedy. Once
again, he was passed over at the Oscars, though
Tommy Lee Jones (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000169/?ls)
was nominated for his
performance as Clay Shaw. Sutherland went on to appear in
Buffy the Vampire Slayer (1992) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0103893/?ls)
,
Shadow of the Wolf (1992) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0105377/?ls)
, and
Disclosure (1994) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0109635/?ls)
.
The new millennium provided an interesting turn in Sutherland's career:
reuniting with such former collaborators as
Clint Eastwood (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000142/?ls)
and
Tommy Lee Jones (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000169/?ls)
, Sutherland starred in
Space Cowboys (2000) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0186566/?ls)
. He also
appeared as the father figure to
Nicole Kidman (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000173/?ls)
's character in
Cold Mountain (2003) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0159365/?ls)
and
Charlize Theron (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000234/?ls)
's character in
The Italian Job (2003) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0317740/?ls)
. He also made a fascinating, Oscar-worthy performance as the revolutionist
Mr. Thorne in
Land of the Blind (2006) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0433405/?ls)
and
also as a judge in
Reign Over Me (2007) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0490204/?ls)
. He
also joined forces with his son
Rossif Sutherland (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm1160472/?ls)
and Canadian comic
Russell Peters (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0992289/?ls)
with the new comedy
The Con Artist (2010) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1401607/?ls)
, as well as
acting alongside
Jamie Bell (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0068260/?ls)
and
Channing Tatum (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm1475594/?ls)
in the sword-and-sandal
film
The Eagle (2011) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1034389/?ls)
. Sutherland
also taken a role in the remake of
Charles Bronson (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000314/?ls)
's film
The Mechanic (1972) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0068931/?ls)
.
Donald Sutherland made a lasting legacy on Hollywood, whether
portraying a chilling and horrifying villain, or playing the older
respectable character in his films. A true character actor, Sutherland
was one of Canada's most well-known names and will hopefully continue to be remembered long after his time.

The Two Popes (2019) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt8404614/?ls)
,
Brazil (1985) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0088846/?ls)

. He has been married to
