31. Mickey Rourke (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000620/?ref_=ls_t_31)
Actor
Writer
Producer
Sin City (2005) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0401792/?ref_=ls_knf_31)
Mickey Rourke was born Phillip Andre Rourke, Jr. on September 16, 1952, in Schenectady, New York, the son of Annette Elizabeth (Cameron) and Philip Andre Rourke. His father was of Irish and German descent, and his mother was of mostly English and French-Canadian ancestry. When he was six years old, his parents divorced. A year later, his mother married Eugene Addis, a Miami Beach police officer, and moved to Miami Shores, Florida. After graduating from Horace Mann Junior High School, Rourke's family moved to a house located on 47th Street and Prairie Avenue in Miami Beach. In 1969 Rourke attended Miami Beach Senior High School, where he played second-string first baseman under coach Skip Bertman. He also acted in a school play, "The Serpent," directed by legendary "Teacher To The Stars"
Jay W. Jensen (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm1913148/?ls)
.
In 1971 he graduated from Miami Beach Senior High School, and after working for a short time as a bus boy at the famed Forge Restaurant on Miami Beach, Rourke moved back to New York to seek out a career in acting.
Rourke's teenage years were more aimed toward sports more than acting. He took up self-defense training at the Boys Club of Miami. It was there he learned boxing skills and decided on an amateur career. At the age of 12, Rourke won his first boxing match as an 118-pound bantamweight, defeating Javier Villanueva. Some of his early matches were fought as Andre Rourke. He continued his boxing training at the famed 5th Street Gym in Miami Beach, soon joining the Police Athletic League boxing program. In 1969 Rourke, now weighing 140 pounds, sparred with former World Welterweight champion Luis Rodriguez. Rodriguez was the number one-rated middleweight boxer in the world and was training for his match with world champion
Nino Benvenuti (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0073058/?ls)
. Rourke claims to have received a concussion in this sparring match.
In 1971, at the Florida Golden Gloves, Rourke received another concussion from a boxing match. Doctors told him to take a year off and rest. In 1972 Rourke knocked out Ron Robinson in 18 seconds and John Carver in 39 seconds. On Aug. 20, 1973, Rourke knocked out 'Sherman "Big Train"' Bergman' in 31 seconds. Shortly after, Rourke decided to retire from amateur boxing.
From 1964 to 1973, Rourke compiled an amateur boxing record of 27 wins (17 by knockout) and 3 defeats. At one point, he reportedly scored 12 consecutive first-round knockouts. As an amateur, Rourke had been friendly with pro-boxer Tommy Torino. When Rourke decided to return to boxing as a professional in 1991, Torino promoted some of Rourke's fights. Rourke was trained by former pro-boxer
Freddie Roach (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm2635565/?ls)
at Miami Beach's 5th Street Gym and the Outlaw Boxing Club Gym in Los Angeles. He made $250 for his pro debut, but by the end of his second year of boxing, he had earned a million dollars. In June 1994, Rourke appeared on the cover of World Boxing Magazine. He sparred with world champions
James Toney (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0867199/?ls)
,
John David Jackson (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm1230627/?ls)
, and
Tommy Morrison (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0607338/?ls)
.
Rourke wished to have 16 professional fights and then fight for a world title. However, he retired in 1994 after eight bouts and never got his desired title fight. His boxing career resulted in severe facial injuries that required a number of operations to repair his damaged face. Rourke went back to acting but worked in relative obscurity until he won a Golden Globe Award for his role as Randy "The Ram" Robinson in
The Wrestler (2008) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1125849/?ls)
. He was nominated for Best Actor, as well, but lost.

32. Keanu Reeves (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000206/?ref_=ls_t_32)
Actor
Producer
Additional Crew
The Matrix (1999) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0133093/?ref_=ls_knf_32)
Keanu Charles Reeves, whose first name means "cool breeze over the mountains" in Hawaiian, was born September 2, 1964 in Beirut, Lebanon. He is the son of
Patric Reeves (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0852983/?ls)
, a showgirl and costume designer, and Samuel Nowlin Reeves, a geologist. Keanu's father was born in Hawaii, of Native Hawaiian and Chinese ancestry while Keanu's mother is originally from Essex England. After his parents' marriage dissolved, Keanu moved with his mother and younger sister,
Kim Reeves (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0716238/?ls)
, to New York City, then Toronto. Stepfather #1 was
Paul Aaron (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0007477/?ls)
, a stage and film director - he and Patricia divorced within a year, after which she went on to marry (and divorce) rock promoter Robert Miller. Reeves never reconnected with his biological father. In high school, Reeves was lukewarm toward academics but took a keen interest in ice hockey (as team goalie, he earned the nickname "The Wall") and drama. He eventually dropped out of school to pursue an acting career.
After a few stage gigs and a handful of made-for-TV movies, he scored a supporting role in the
Rob Lowe (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000507/?ls)
hockey flick
Youngblood (1986) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0092272/?ls)
, which was filmed in Canada. Shortly after the production wrapped, Reeves packed his bags and headed for Hollywood. Reeves popped up on critics' radar with his performance in the dark adolescent drama,
River's Edge (1986) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0091860/?ls)
, and landed a supporting role in the Oscar-nominated
Dangerous Liaisons (1988) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0094947/?ls)
with director
Stephen Frears (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001241/?ls)
.
His first popular success was the role of totally rad dude Ted "Theodore" Logan in
Bill & Ted's Excellent Adventure (1989) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0096928/?ls)
. The wacky time-travel movie became something of a cultural phenomenon, and audiences would forever confuse Reeves's real-life persona with that of his doofy on-screen counterpart. He then joined the casts of
Ron Howard (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000165/?ls)
's comedy,
Parenthood (1989) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0098067/?ls)
and
Lawrence Kasdan (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001410/?ls)
's
I Love You to Death (1990) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0099819/?ls)
.
Over the next few years, Reeves tried to shake the Ted stigma with a series of highbrow projects. He played a slumming rich boy opposite
River Phoenix (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000203/?ls)
's narcoleptic male hustler in
My Own Private Idaho (1991) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0102494/?ls)
, an unlucky lawyer who stumbles into the vampire's lair in
Dracula (1992) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0103874/?ls)
, and Shakespearean party-pooper Don John in
Much Ado About Nothing (1993) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0107616/?ls)
.
In 1994, the understated actor became a big-budget action star with the release of
Speed (1994) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0111257/?ls)
. Its success heralded an era of five years in which Reeves would alternate between small films, like
Feeling Minnesota (1996) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0116289/?ls)
and
The Last Time I Committed Suicide (1997) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0119502/?ls)
, and big films like
A Walk in the Clouds (1995) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0114887/?ls)
and
The Devil's Advocate (1997) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0118971/?ls)
. (There were a couple misfires, too:
Johnny Mnemonic (1995) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0113481/?ls)
and
Chain Reaction (1996) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0115857/?ls)
.) After all this, Reeves did the unthinkable and passed on the Speed sequel, but he struck box-office gold again a few years later with the Wachowski siblings' cyberadventure,
The Matrix (1999) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0133093/?ls)
.
Now a bonafide box-office star, Keanu would appear in a string of smaller films -- among them
The Replacements (2000) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0191397/?ls)
,
The Watcher (2000) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0204626/?ls)
,
The Gift (2000) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0219699/?ls)
,
Sweet November (2001) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0230838/?ls)
, and
Hardball (2001) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0180734/?ls)
- before
The Matrix Reloaded (2003) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0234215/?ls)
and
The Matrix Revolutions (2003) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0242653/?ls)
were both released in 2003.
Since the end of The Matrix trilogy, Keanu has divided his time between mainstream and indie fare, landing hits with
Something's Gotta Give (2003) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0337741/?ls)
,
The Lake House (2006) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0410297/?ls)
, and
Street Kings (2008) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0421073/?ls)
. He's kept Matrix fans satiated with films such as
Constantine (2005) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0360486/?ls)
,
A Scanner Darkly (2006) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0405296/?ls)
, and
The Day the Earth Stood Still (2008) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0970416/?ls)
. And he's waded back into art-house territory with
Ellie Parker (2005) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0436262/?ls)
,
Thumbsucker (2005) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0318761/?ls)
,
The Private Lives of Pippa Lee (2009) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1134629/?ls)
, and
Henry's Crime (2010) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1220888/?ls)
.
Most recently, as post-production on the samurai epic
47 Ronin (2013) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1335975/?ls)
waged on, Keanu appeared in front of the camera in
Side by Side (2012) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2014338/?ls)
, a documentary on celluloid and digital filmmaking, which he also produced. He also directed another Asian-influenced project,
Man of Tai Chi (2013) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2016940/?ls)
.
In 2014, Keanu played the title role in the action revenge film
John Wick (2014) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2911666/?ls)
, which became popular with critics and audiences alike. He reprised the role in
John Wick: Chapter 2 (2017) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt4425200/?ls)
, taking the now-iconic character to a better opening weekend and even more enthusiastic reviews than the first go-around.

33. Adan Canto (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm3841486/?ref_=ls_t_33)
Actor
Producer
Director
Designated Survivor (2016–2019) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt5296406/?ref_=ls_knf_33)
Adan Canto is a Mexican-American actor and director. He left home at the age of 16 to pursue a career as a musician. Canto wrote for and produced several songs for film and television while living in Mexico City. He began acting in a handful of commercials in Mexico City and was soon cast in a television series called Estado de Gracia. Canto eventually turned to the stage after being cast as a lead for the adaptation of Pedro Almodovar's All About My Mother.
In 2013, Canto made his debut in American television, playing the role of Paul Torres on the Fox drama series, The Following. In 2015 Canto played real life politician Rodrigo Lara Bonia in Netflix drama series Narcos. In 2016, he was cast in the ABC political drama series, Designated Survivor, playing White House Chief of Staff Aaron Shore opposite Kiefer Sutherland, Natascha McElhone, and Maggie Q. Canto wrote and directed his first short film Before Tomorrow in 2014. His short film The Shot earned several festival awards for Best Narrative Short Film in 2020.

Michael C. Hall is

Jason Statham was born in Shirebrook, Derbyshire, to Eileen (Yates), a dancer, and Barry Statham, a street merchant and lounge singer. He received the audition for his debut role as Bacon in
Lock, Stock and Two Smoking Barrels (1998) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0120735/?ls)
through French Connection, for whom he was modeling. They became a major investor in the film and introduced Jason to
Guy Ritchie (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0005363/?ls)
, who invited him to audition for a part in the film by challenging him to impersonate an illegal street vendor and convince him to purchase fake jewelry. Jason must have been doing something right because after the success of
Lock, Stock and Two Smoking Barrels (1998) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0120735/?ls)
he teamed up again with
Guy Ritchie (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0005363/?ls)
for
Snatch (2000) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0208092/?ls)
, with co-stars including
Brad Pitt (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000093/?ls)
,
Dennis Farina (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001199/?ls)
and
Benicio Del Toro (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001125/?ls)
. After
Snatch (2000) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0208092/?ls)
came
Turn It Up (2000) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0216772/?ls)
with US music star
Ja Rule (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0750019/?ls)
, followed by a supporting actor role in the sci-fi film
Ghosts of Mars (2001) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0228333/?ls)
,
Jet Li (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001472/?ls)
's
The One (2001) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0267804/?ls)
and another screen partnership with
Vinnie Jones (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0005068/?ls)
in
Mean Machine (2001) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0291341/?ls)
under
Guy Ritchie (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0005363/?ls)
's and
Matthew Vaughn (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0891216/?ls)
's SKA Films. Finally in 2002 he was cast as the lead role of Frank Martin in
The Transporter (2002) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0293662/?ls)
. Jason was also in the summer 2003 blockbuster remake of
The Italian Job (1969) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0064505/?ls)
,
The Italian Job (2003) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0317740/?ls)
, playing Handsome Rob.
Throughout the 2000s, Statham became a star of juicy action B-films, most significantly
Crank (2006) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0479884/?ls)
and
Crank: High Voltage (2009) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1121931/?ls)
, and also
War (2007) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0499556/?ls)
, opposite Jet Li, and
The Bank Job (2008) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0200465/?ls)
and
Death Race (2008) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0452608/?ls)
, among others. In the 2010s, his reputation for cheeky and tough leading performances led to his casting as Lee Christmas in
The Expendables (2010) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1320253/?ls)
and its sequels, the comedy
Spy (2015) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt3079380/?ls)
, and as (apparently) reformed villain Deckard Shaw in
Fast & Furious 6 (2013) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1905041/?ls)
,
Furious 7 (2015) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2820852/?ls)
,
The Fate of the Furious (2017) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt4630562/?ls)
, and
Fast & Furious Presents: Hobbs & Shaw (2019) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt6806448/?ls)

Homefront (2013) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2312718/?ls)
.
In 2017, he had his first child, a son with his partner, model
Rosie Huntington-Whiteley (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm2492819/?ls)
.

Ansel Elgort is an American actor, known for playing Augustus Waters in the romance
The Fault in Our Stars (2014) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2582846/?ls)
and the title character in the action thriller
Baby Driver (2017) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt3890160/?ls)
. He was born in New York City to photographer
Arthur Elgort (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0253394/?ls)
and opera director
Grethe Holby (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm5028442/?ls)
. His father is of Russian-Jewish heritage, while his mother has Norwegian and British Isles ancestry.
As a child, Ansel tried out for the School of American Ballet, and attended Stagedoor Manor summer camp and Fiorello H. LaGuardia High School. He began his professional acting career on stage, appearing in
Matt Charman (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm4131020/?ls)
's play "Regrets," which was performed off-Broadway. Ansel made his film debut in the horror remake
Carrie (2013) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1939659/?ls)
, and co-starred with
Shailene Woodley (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0940362/?ls)
in both the science-fiction tale
Divergent (2014) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1840309/?ls)
(playing her character's brother) and the romantic drama
The Fault in Our Stars (2014) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2582846/?ls)
(playing male lead Augustus Waters, who is Woodley's character's love interest). The film was based on the book by 'John Green' (XII). Ansel also had a role in
Jason Reitman (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0718646/?ls)
's drama film
Men, Women & Children (2014) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt3179568/?ls)
, and returned for the sequels to Divergent,
Insurgent (2015) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2908446/?ls)
and
Allegiant (2016) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt3410834/?ls)
. He had a cameo in

, also based on a teen drama book by author Green.
Ansel played the title role in
Baby Driver (2017) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt3890160/?ls)
, director
Edgar Wright (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0942367/?ls)
's action film, starring opposite
Lily James (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm4141252/?ls)
and
Kevin Spacey (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000228/?ls)
. Baby Driver was critically acclaimed, and emerged as a box office hit in the summer of 2017. Ansel also starred in the 2017 book adaptation
November Criminals (2017) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt3266284/?ls)
, a crime thriller. His upcoming roles include the indie films
Jonathan (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt6467822/?ls)
,
Billionaire Boys Club (2018) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt5179598/?ls)
, and
The Goldfinch (2019) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt3864056/?ls)
.

38. Jared Leto (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001467/?ref_=ls_t_38)
Actor
Producer
Director
Dallas Buyers Club (2013) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0790636/?ref_=ls_knf_38)
Jared Leto is a very familiar face in recent film history. Although he has always been the lead vocals, rhythm guitar, and songwriter for American band
Thirty Seconds to Mars (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm2012087/?ls)
, Leto is an accomplished actor merited by the numerous, challenging projects he has taken in his life. He is known to be selective about his film roles.
Jared Leto was born in Bossier City, Louisiana, to Constance "Connie" (Metrejon) and Anthony L. "Tony" Bryant. The surname "Leto" is from his stepfather. His ancestry includes English, Cajun (French), as well as Irish, German, and Scottish. Jared and his family traveled across the United States throughout his childhood, living in such states as Wyoming, Virginia and Colorado. Leto would continue this trend when he initially dropped a study of painting at Philadelphia's University of the Arts in favor of a focus on acting at the School of Visual Arts in New York City.
In 1992, Leto moved to Los Angeles to pursue a musical career, intending to take acting roles on the side. Leto's first appearances on screen were guest appearances on the short-lived television shows
Camp Wilder (1992) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0103382/?ls)
,
Almost Home (1993) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0105939/?ls)
and
Rebel Highway (1994) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0108902/?ls)
. However, his next role would change everything for Leto. While searching for film roles, he was cast in the show,
My So-Called Life (1994) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0108872/?ls)
(TV Series 1994-1995). Leto's character was "Jordan Catalano", the handsome, dyslexic slacker, the main love interest of "Angela" (played by
Claire Danes (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000132/?ls)
). Leto contributed to the soundtrack of the film, and so impressed the producers initially that he was soon a regular on the show until its end.
Elsewhere, Leto began taking film roles. His first theatrically released film was the ensemble piece,
How to Make an American Quilt (1995) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0113347/?ls)
, based on a novel of the same name and starring renowned actresses
Winona Ryder (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000213/?ls)
,
Anne Bancroft (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000843/?ls)
,
Ellen Burstyn (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000995/?ls)
,
Jean Simmons (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001739/?ls)
and
Alfre Woodard (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0005569/?ls)
. The film was a modest success and, while Leto's next film,
The Last of the High Kings (1996) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0116833/?ls)
, was a failure, Leto secured his first leading role in
Prefontaine (1997) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0119937/?ls)
, based on long-distance runner Steven Prefontaine. The film was a financial flop, but was praised by critics, notably
Gene Siskel (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0803021/?ls)
and
Roger Ebert (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001170/?ls)
. He also took a supporting role in the action thriller,
Switchback (1997) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0119210/?ls)
, which starred
Dennis Quaid (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000598/?ls)
, but the film was another failure.
Leto's work was slowly becoming recognized in Hollywood, and he continued to find work in film. In 1998, everything turned for the better on all fronts. This was the year that Leto founded the band,
Thirty Seconds to Mars (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm2012087/?ls)
, with his brother,
Shannon Leto (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0504720/?ls)
, as well as
Matt Wachter (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm2428680/?ls)
(who later left the group), and after two guitarists joined and quit,
Tomo Milicevic (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm2430595/?ls)
was brought in as lead guitarist and keyboardist. As well as the formation of his now-famous band, Leto's luck in film was suddenly shooting for the better. He was cast as the lead in the horror film,
Urban Legend (1998) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0146336/?ls)
, which told a grisly tale of a murderer who kills his victims in the style of urban legends. The film was a massive success commercially, though critics mostly disliked the film. That same year, Leto also landed a supporting role in the film,
The Thin Red Line (1998) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0120863/?ls)
. Renowned director
Terrence Malick (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000517/?ls)
's first film in nearly twenty years, the film had dozens of famous actors in the cast, including
Sean Penn (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000576/?ls)
,
Woody Harrelson (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000437/?ls)
,
John Travolta (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000237/?ls)
,
Nick Nolte (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000560/?ls)
and
Elias Koteas (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000480/?ls)
, to name a few. The film went through much editing, leaving several actors out of the final version, but Leto luckily remained in the film.
The Thin Red Line (1998) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0120863/?ls)
was nominated for seven Oscars and was a moderate success at the box office. Leto's fame had just begun. He had supporting roles in both
James Mangold (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0003506/?ls)
's
Girl, Interrupted (1999) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0172493/?ls)
, and in
David Fincher (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000399/?ls)
's cult classic,
Fight Club (1999) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0137523/?ls)
, dealing with masculinity, commercialism, fascism and insomnia. While
Edward Norton (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001570/?ls)
and
Brad Pitt (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000093/?ls)
were the lead roles, Leto took a supporting role and dyed his hair blond. The film remains hailed by many, but at the time, Leto was already pushing himself further into controversial films. He played a supporting role of "Paul Allen" in the infamous
American Psycho (2000) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0144084/?ls)
, starring
Christian Bale (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000288/?ls)
, and he played the lead role in
Darren Aronofsky (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0004716/?ls)
's
Requiem for a Dream (2000) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0180093/?ls)
, which had Leto take grueling measures to prepare for his role as a heroin addict trying to put his plans to reality and escape the hell he is in. Both films were massive successes, if controversially received.
The 2000s brought up new film opportunities for Leto. He reunited with
David Fincher (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000399/?ls)
in
Panic Room (2002) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0258000/?ls)
, which was another success for Leto, as well as
Oliver Stone (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000231/?ls)
's epic passion project,
Alexander (2004) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0346491/?ls)
. The theatrical cut was poorly received domestically (although it recouped its budget through DVD sales and international profit), and though a Final Cut was released that much improved the film in all aspects, it continues to be frowned upon by the majority of film goers. Leto rebounded with
Lord of War (2005) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0399295/?ls)
,
which starred
Nicolas Cage (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000115/?ls)
as an arms dealer who ships weapons to war zones, with Leto playing his hapless but more moral-minded brother. The film was an astounding look at the arms industry, but was not a big financial success. Leto's flush of successes suddenly ran dry when he acted in the period piece,
Lonely Hearts (2006) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0441774/?ls)
, which had Leto playing "Ray Fernandez", one of the two infamous "Lonely Hearts Killers" in the 1940s. The film was a financial failure and only received mixed responses. Leto then underwent a massive weight gain to play "Mark David Chapman", infamous murderer of
John Lennon (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0006168/?ls)
, in the movie,
Chapter 27 (2007) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0488988/?ls)
. While Leto did a fantastic job embodying the behavior and speech patterns of Chapman, the film was a complete flop, and was a critical bomb to boot. It was during this period that Leto focused increasingly on his band, turning down such films as
Clint Eastwood (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000142/?ls)
's World War 2 film,
Flags of Our Fathers (2006) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0418689/?ls)
.
In 2009, however, Leto returned to acting with
Mr. Nobody (2009) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0485947/?ls)
. Leto's role as "Nemo Nobody" required him to play the character as far aged as 118, even as he undergoes a soul-searching as to whether his life turned out the way he wanted it to. The film was mostly funded through Belgian and French financiers, and was given limited release in only certain countries. Critical response, however, has praised the film's artistry and Leto's acting.
He made his directorial debut in 2012 with the documentary film
Artifact (2012) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2370718/?ls)
.
Leto remains the lead vocalist, multi-instrumentalist and main songwriter for Thirty Seconds to Mars. Their debut album, 30 Seconds to Mars (2002), was released to positive reviews but only to limited success. The band achieved worldwide fame with the release of their second album A Beautiful Lie (2005). Their following releases, This Is War (2009) and Love, Lust, Faith and Dreams (2013), received further critical and commercial success.
After a five years hiatus from filming, Leto returned to act in the drama Dallas Buyers Club (2013), directed by Jean-Marc Vallée and co-starring Matthew McConaughey. Leto portrayed Rayon, a drug-addicted transgender woman with AIDS who befriends McConaughey's character Ron Woodroof. Leto's performance earned him an Academy Award, a Golden Globe Award, and a Screen Actors Guild Award for Best Supporting Actor. In order to accurately portray his role, Leto lost 30 pounds, shaved his eyebrows and waxed his entire body. He stated the portrayal was grounded in his meeting transgender people while researching the role. During filming, Leto refused to break character. Dallas Buyers Club received widespread critical acclaim and became a financial success, resulting in various accolades for Leto, who was awarded the Academy Award for Best Supporting Actor, Golden Globe Award for Best Supporting Actor - Motion Picture, Screen Actors Guild Award for Outstanding Performance by a Male Actor in a Supporting Role and a variety of film critics' circle awards for the role.
In 2016, he played the Joker in the super villain film
Suicide Squad (2016) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1386697/?ls)
.
Leto is considered to be a method actor, known for his constant devotion to and research of his roles. He often remains completely in character for the duration of the shooting schedules of his films, even to the point of adversely affecting his health.

It Follows (2014) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt3235888/?ref_=ls_knf_42)
Jacob Weary is an American actor, musician, singer-songwriter and music producer. He is most known for his role as Deran Cody in TNT's hit crime drama series Animal Kingdom, and for his role as Dwayne in Neon's explosive Eco heist-thriller How to Blow Up a Pipeline. Weary is from Montclair, NJ and is the son to 4 time Emmy Award Winning Actress Kim Zimmer and actor/director A.C Weary.

Leila George D'Onofrio is an Australian actress. George was born in Sydney, New South Wales, Australia, to actor and producer Vincent D'Onofrio and actress Greta Scacchi, and raised by her mother in Brighton, East Sussex, United Kingdom. She has three younger half-brothers. In 2008, she took acting classes at Brighton College. The following year, she attended Crawley College, her mother's Alma mater, and in 2010, studied at the Arts Educational Schools, London. In 2011, she went to Australia to study at Sydney Film School. In 2012, she went to the United States to study at the Lee Strasberg Institute in New York City near her father.

46. Jennifer Lawrence (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm2225369/?ref_=ls_t_46)
Actress
Producer
Writer
The Hunger Games (2012) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1392170/?ref_=ls_knf_46)
As the highest-paid actress in the world in 2015 and 2016, and with her films grossing over $5.5 billion worldwide, Jennifer Lawrence is often cited as the most successful actress of her generation. She is also the first person born in the 1990s to have won an acting Oscar.
Jennifer Shrader Lawrence was born August 15, 1990, in Louisville, Kentucky, to Karen (Koch), who manages a children's camp, and Gary Lawrence, who works in construction. She has two older brothers, Ben and Blaine, and has English, German, Irish, and Scottish ancestry.
Her career began when she traveled to Manhattan at the age of fourteen after dropping out of the 8th grade. After conducting her first cold read, agents told her mother that "it was the best cold read by a 14-year-old they had ever heard," and tried to convince her stage mother that she needed to spend the summer in Manhattan. After leaving the agency, Jennifer was spotted by an agent in the midst of shooting an H&M ad and asked to take her picture. The next day, that agent followed up with her and invited her to the studio for a cold-read audition. Again, the agents were highly impressed and strongly urged her mother to allow her to spend the summer in New York City. As fate would have it, she did and subsequently appeared in commercials such as MTV's "My Super Sweet 16" and played a role in the movie
The Devil You Know (2013) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0463960/?ls)
.
Shortly thereafter, her career forced her and her family to move to Los Angeles, where she was cast in the TBS sitcom
The Bill Engvall Show (2007) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0926732/?ls)
, and in smaller movies such as
The Poker House (2008) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1014806/?ls)
and
The Burning Plain (2008) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1068641/?ls)
.
Her big break came when she played Ree in
Winter's Bone (2010) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1399683/?ls)
, which landed her Academy Award and Golden Globe nominations. Shortly thereafter, she secured the role of Mystique in franchise reboot
X-Men: First Class (2011) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1270798/?ls)
, which went on to be a hit in Summer 2011. Around this time, Lawrence scored the role of a lifetime when she was cast as Katniss Everdeen in the big-screen adaptation of literary sensation
The Hunger Games (2012) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1392170/?ls)
. The film went on to become one of the highest-grossing movies ever, with over $407 million at the US box office, and instantly propelled Lawrence to the A-list among young actors and actresses. Three Hunger Games sequels were released in each consecutive November:
The Hunger Games: Catching Fire (2013) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1951264/?ls)
,
The Hunger Games: Mockingjay - Part 1 (2014) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1951265/?ls)
, and
The Hunger Games: Mockingjay - Part 2 (2015) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1951266/?ls)
, with Lawrence reprising her role.
In 2012, the romantic comedy
Silver Linings Playbook (2012) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1045658/?ls)
earned her the Academy Award, Golden Globe Award, Screen Actors Guild Award, Satellite Award, and the Independent Spirit Award for Best Actress, among other accolades, making her the youngest person ever to be nominated for two Academy Awards for Best Actress and the second-youngest Best Actress winner.
She starred in David O. Russell's popular drama-comedy
American Hustle (2013) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1800241/?ls)
, as Roselyn Rosenfield, and teamed with the director again to play inventor Joy Mangano in another family comedy,
Joy (2015) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2446980/?ls)
, for which she earned Oscar nominations for both roles (Best Supporting Actress and Best Actress, respectively).

47. Ralph Fiennes (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000146/?ref_=ls_t_47)
Actor
Producer
Director
The Constant Gardener (2005) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0387131/?ref_=ls_knf_47)
Actor Ralph Nathaniel Twisleton-Wykeham-Fiennes was born on December 22, 1962 in Suffolk, England, to Jennifer Anne Mary Alleyne (Lash), a novelist, and Mark Fiennes, a photographer. He is the eldest of six children. Four of his siblings are also in the arts:
Martha Fiennes (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0276397/?ls)
, a director;
Magnus Fiennes (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0276396/?ls)
, a musician;
Sophie Fiennes (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0276400/?ls)
, a producer; and
Joseph Fiennes (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001212/?ls)
, an actor. He is of English, Irish, and Scottish origin.
A noted Shakespeare interpreter, he first achieved success onstage at the Royal National Theatre. Fiennes first worked on screen in 1990 and then made his film debut in 1992 as Heathcliff in Emily Brontë's
Wuthering Heights (1992) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0104181/?ls)
, opposite Juliette Binoche. 1993 was his "breakout year". He had a major role in the controversial Peter Greenaway film
The Baby of Mâcon (1993) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0106335/?ls)
, with Julia Ormond, which was poorly received. Later that year he became known internationally for portraying the amoral Nazi concentration camp commandant Amon Goeth in Steven Spielberg's
Schindler's List (1993) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0108052/?ls)
. For this he was nominated for the Academy Award for Best Supporting Actor and the Golden Globe Award for Best Supporting Actor. He did not win, but did win the Best Supporting Actor BAFTA Award for the role, as well as Best Supporting Actor honors from numerous critics groups, including the National Society of Film Critics, and the New York, Chicago, Boston, and London Film Critics associations. His portrayal as Göth also earned him a spot on the American Film Institute's list of Top 50 Film Villains. To look suitable to represent Goeth, Fiennes gained weight, but he managed to shed it afterwards. In 1994, he portrayed American academic Charles Van Doren in
Quiz Show (1994) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0110932/?ls)
. In 1996, he was nominated for the Academy Award for Best Actor for his performance as Count Almásy the World War II epic romance, and another Best Picture winner,
Anthony Minghella (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0005237/?ls)
's
The English Patient (1996) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0116209/?ls)
, in which he starred with Kristin Scott Thomas. He also received BAFTA and Golden Globe nominations, as well as
two Screen Actors Guild (SAG) Award nominations, one for Best Actor and another shared with the film's ensemble cast.
Since then, Fiennes has been in a number of notable films, including
Strange Days (1995) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0114558/?ls)
,
Oscar and Lucinda (1997) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0119843/?ls)
, the animated
The Prince of Egypt (1998) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0120794/?ls)
,
István Szabó (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0843640/?ls)
's
Sunshine (1999) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0145503/?ls)
,
Neil Jordan (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001403/?ls)
-directed films
The End of the Affair (1999) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0172396/?ls)
and
The Good Thief (2002) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0281820/?ls)
,
Red Dragon (2002) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0289765/?ls)
,
Maid in Manhattan (2002) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0252076/?ls)
,
The Constant Gardener (2005) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0387131/?ls)
,
In Bruges (2008) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0780536/?ls)
,
The Reader (2008) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0976051/?ls)
, co-starring
Kate Winslet (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000701/?ls)
,
Kathryn Bigelow (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000941/?ls)
's Oscar®-winning
The Hurt Locker (2008) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0887912/?ls)
,
Clash of the Titans (2010) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0800320/?ls)
,
Mike Newell (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001565/?ls)
's screen adaptation of
Charles Dickens (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0002042/?ls)
'
Great Expectations (2012) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1836808/?ls)
, with
Helena Bonham Carter (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000307/?ls)
and
Jeremy Irvine (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm3528539/?ls)
, and
Wes Anderson (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0027572/?ls)
's
The Grand Budapest Hotel (2014) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2278388/?ls)
.
He is also known for his roles in major film franchises such as the Harry Potter film series (2005-2011), in which he played the evil Lord
Voldemort. His nephew,
Hero Fiennes Tiffin (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm2842005/?ls)
played Tom
Riddle, the young Lord Voldemort, in
Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (2009) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0417741/?ls)
. Ralph also appears in the James Bond series, in which he has played M, starting with the 2012 film
Skyfall (2012) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1074638/?ls)
.
In 2011, Fiennes made his directorial debut with his film adaptation of Shakespeare's tragedy political thriller
Coriolanus (2011) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1372686/?ls)
, in which he also played the title character, opposite
Gerard Butler (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0124930/?ls)
and
Vanessa Redgrave (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000603/?ls)
. Fiennes has won a Tony Award for playing Prince Hamlet on Broadway.
In 2015, Fiennes played a music producer in
Luca Guadagnino (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0345174/?ls)
's
A Bigger Splash (2015) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2056771/?ls)
, starring opposite
Tilda Swinton (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0842770/?ls)
and
Matthias Schoenaerts (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0774386/?ls)
, and in 2016, Fiennes starred in Joel and Ethan Coen's
Hail, Caesar! (2016) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0475290/?ls)
.
Since 1999, Fiennes has served as an ambassador for UNICEF UK.

48. Jim Caviezel (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001029/?ref_=ls_t_48)
Actor
Producer
Soundtrack
The Passion of the Christ (2004) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0335345/?ref_=ls_knf_48)
James Patrick Caviezel was born on September 26, 1968 in Mount Vernon,
Washington. He was one of five children born to Margaret (Lavery), a
former stage actress, and James Caviezel, a chiropractor. The Caviezels
are a closely knit Catholic family. He is of Irish (mother) and Swiss-Romansh
and Slovak (father) descent; the surname, "Caviezel", is
Romansh. As a boy, Jim was described as being "very intense." His
two main interests growing up were sports and religion. He was
athletically gifted on the basketball court and dreamed of someday
playing in the N.B.A. He was also instilled with Christianity at a very
young age, attending Church regularly with his family. In 1984, he went
to Mount Vernon High School but transferred to O'Dea High School after
two years. The following spring, he transferred again to Burien Kennedy
High School in Burien, Washington where he was a star on the basketball
team and graduated in 1987. While at O'Dea and Kennedy, he stayed with
family friends. Following high school Jim enrolled at Bellevue
Community College where he again played on the basketball team. A foot
injury in his sophomore season put an end to Jim's basketball career
and his dreams of playing in the N.B.A. Shortly after this, he turned
his focus toward acting. In 1990, he auditioned for a part in the
independent film
My Own Private Idaho (1991) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0102494/?ls)
.
He won a very small role as a foreign airline clerk after he told
casting agents that he was a recent Italian immigrant. The following
year, Jim moved to Los Angeles where he worked as a waiter between
auditions. He landed small roles in
Diggstown (1992) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0104107/?ls)
and
Wyatt Earp (1994) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0111756/?ls)
and guest starring
roles on
The Wonder Years (1988) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0094582/?ls)
and
Murder, She Wrote (1984) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0086765/?ls)
.
He continued to go relatively unnoticed in small roles and even thought
about quitting acting until 1998 when he received critical recognition
for his role as idealist Private Witt in
The Thin Red Line (1998) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0120863/?ls)
. The
following year, he gained further recognition with roles in
Ride with the Devil (1999) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0134154/?ls)
and
Frequency (2000) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0186151/?ls)
. In 2001, his role
as
Jennifer Lopez (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000182/?ls)
's love interest
in
Angel Eyes (2001) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0225071/?ls)
helped to
establish him as a versatile actor and leading man. It wasn't until
2002 that Jim made his strong religious beliefs known. While filming
High Crimes (2002) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0257756/?ls)
, he refused to do
any love scenes with on-screen wife
Ashley Judd (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000171/?ls)
because it conflicted with his
strong Catholic faith. It was also around this time when he was chosen
by
Mel Gibson (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000154/?ls)
to star as Jesus Christ
in
The Passion of the Christ (2004) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0335345/?ls)
.
The movie made headlines and broke box-office records around the world,
becoming one of the highest grossing films of all time. Although the
movie dealt with controversial matters, Caviezel's performance was
acclaimed by both critics and viewers. Jim's next big role would be on
the small screen. In 2011, he landed the lead role in the CBS crime
drama
Person of Interest (2011) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1839578/?ls)
.
The show instantly clicked with audiences, becoming one of the highest
rated shows on television. From an outcast actor to a respected film
star to a television star, James Caviezel is continuing to give his
best to play challenging roles. Off screen, Jim lives with his wife,
Kerri, a school teacher whom he met on a blind date in 1993 and married
in 1996, and their adopted children.

Christopher Michael "Chris" Pratt was born on June 21, 1979 in Virginia, Minnesota and raised in Lake Stevens, Washington, to Kathleen Louise (Indahl), who worked at a supermarket, and Daniel Clifton Pratt, who remodeled houses. He is of mostly Norwegian descent. He graduated from Lake Stevens High School in 1997, and has two older siblings, Cully and Angie.
Chris came to prominence for his small-screen roles, including Bright Abbott in
Everwood (2002) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0318883/?ls)
, Ché in
The O.C. (2003) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0362359/?ls)
, and Andy Dwyer and
Parks and Recreation (2009) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1266020/?ls)
, and notable film roles in
Moneyball (2011) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1210166/?ls)
,
The Five-Year Engagement (2012) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1195478/?ls)
,
Zero Dark Thirty (2012) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1790885/?ls)
,
Delivery Man (2013) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2387559/?ls)
, and
Her (2013) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1798709/?ls)
. In 2014, he broke out as a leading man after headlining two of the year's biggest films: he voiced Emmet Brickowski in
The Lego Movie (2014) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1490017/?ls)
& starred as Peter Quill/Star-Lord in
Guardians of the Galaxy (2014) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2015381/?ls)
. In 2015, he headlined the sci-fi thriller
Jurassic World (2015) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0369610/?ls)
, the fourth installment in the Jurassic Park franchise and his most financially successful film. In 2016, he co-starred in the remake
The Magnificent Seven (2016) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2404435/?ls)
, with
Denzel Washington (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000243/?ls)
and
Ethan Hawke (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000160/?ls)
, and appeared with
Jennifer Lawrence (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm2225369/?ls)
in the sci-fi drama
Passengers (2016) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1355644/?ls)
. In the near future, he returns as Star-Lord for
Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2 (2017) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt3896198/?ls)
, with
Jurassic World: Fallen Kingdom (2018) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt4881806/?ls)
not far behind.

1. Mark Wahlberg (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000242/?ref_=ls_t_1)
Producer
Actor
Composer
The Fighter (2010) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0964517/?ref_=ls_knf_1)
American actor Mark Wahlberg is one of a handful of respected entertainers who successfully made the transition from teen pop idol to acclaimed actor. A Best Supporting Actor Oscar nominee for
The Departed (2006) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0407887/?ls)
who went on to receive positive critical reviews for his performance in
The Fighter (2010) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0964517/?ls)
, Wahlberg also is a solid comedy actor, proven by his starring role in
Ted (2012) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1637725/?ls)
.
Mark Robert Michael Wahlberg was born June 5, 1971 in a poor working class district, Dorchester, of Boston, Massachusetts. He is the son of Alma Elaine (Donnelly), a nurse's aide and clerk, and Donald Edward Wahlberg, a delivery driver. Wahlberg is the youngest of nine children. He is of Swedish (from his paternal grandfather), French-Canadian, English, Irish and Scottish, descent. The large Wahlberg brood didn't have a lot growing up, especially after his parents divorced when he was eleven. The kids crammed into a three-bedroom apartment, none of them having very much privacy. Mark's mother has said that after the divorce, she became very self-absorbed with her own life. She has blamed herself for her son's subsequent problems and delinquency. Wahlberg dropped out of high school at age fourteen (but later got his GED) to pursue a life of petty crime and drugs. He'd spend his days scamming and stealing, working on the odd drug deal before treating himself to the substances.
The young man also had a violent streak - one which was often aimed at minorities. At age sixteen, he was convicted of assault against two Vietnamese men after he had tried to rob them. As a result of his assault conviction, he was sentenced to serve 50 days in prison at Deer Island penitentiary. Whilst there, he began working out to pass time and, when he emerged at the end of his sentence, he had gone from being a scrawny young kid to a buff young man. Wahlberg also credits jail time as being his motivation to improve his lifestyle and leave crime behind him.
Around this time, his older brother
Donnie Wahlberg (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0005531/?ls)
had become an overnight teen idol as a member of the 1980s boy band
New Kids on the Block (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm1578753/?ls)
. A precursor to the boy-band craze, the group was dominating the charts and were on top of their game. Mark himself had been an original member of the band but had backed out early on - uncomfortable with the squeaky clean image of the group. Donnie used his connections in the music business to help his little brother secure a recording contract, and soon the world was introduced to Marky Mark and the Funky Bunch, with Wahlberg as a bad-boy rapper who danced in his boxers. Despite a lack of singing ability, promoters took to his dance moves and a physique they knew teenage girls would love.
Donnie scripted some easy songs for Mark, who collected a troupe of dancers and a DJ to become his "Funky Bunch" and "Marky Mark and the Funky Bunch" was born. His debut album, "Music for the People", was a smash hit, which was propelled along by the rapper's willingness to disrobe down to boxer-briefs on stage, not to mention several catchy tunes. Teenage girls thrilled to the rapping "bad boy". Record producer
David Geffen (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0311691/?ls)
saw in Wahlberg a cash-cow of marketing ability. After speaking to designer
Calvin Klein (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0458681/?ls)
, Marky Mark was set up as the designer's chief underwear model.
His scantily clad figure soon adorned billboards across the nation. Ironically, while the
New Kids on the Block (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm1578753/?ls)
's fame was dwindling as audiences tired of their syrupy lyrics, "Marky Mark's" bad boy image was becoming even more of a commodity. He was constantly in the headlines (often of the tabloids) after multiple scandals. In 1992, he released a book dedicated to his penis. Wahlberg was constantly getting into rumored fights, most memorably with
Madonna (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000187/?ls)
and her entourage at a Los Angeles party. While things were always intense, they were relatively harmless and made for enjoyable reading for the public. However, when the story of his arrest for assault (and the allegations of racism) broke in the press, things took on a decidedly darker note. People were not amused. Soon after, while on a British talk show along with rapper
Shabba Ranks (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm1133072/?ls)
, he got into even more trouble. After Ranks made the statement that gays should be crucified, Wahlberg was accused of condoning the comments by his silence. Marky Mark was suddenly surrounded by charges of brutality, homophobia and racial hatred. His second album, "You Gotta Believe", had not been faring well and, after the charges surfaced, it plummeted from the charts.
Adding to the hoopla, Wahlberg was brought to court for allegedly assaulting a security guard. He was ordered to make amends by appearing in a series of anti-bias advertisements. Humbled and humiliated by his fall from grace in the music world, Wahlberg decided to pursue another angle, acting. He dropped the "Marky Mark" moniker and became known simply as Mark Wahlberg. His first big screen role came in
Penny Marshall (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001508/?ls)
's
Renaissance Man (1994) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0110971/?ls)
. Despite the name change, many people snickered at the idea of the has-been rapper thinking he could make it as an actor. From the get-go, he was proving them wrong. In
Renaissance Man (1994) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0110971/?ls)
, he gave an utterly charming performance as a simple but sincere army recruit. What naysayers remained found it increasingly difficult to write Mark Wahlberg off as he delivered one fine performance after another. He blew them away in the controversial
The Basketball Diaries (1995) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0112461/?ls)
and chilled them in
Fear (1996) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0116287/?ls)
as every father's worst nightmare.
The major turning point in Wahlberg's career came with the role of troubled porn star Dirk Diggler in
Paul Thomas Anderson (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000759/?ls)
's
Boogie Nights (1997) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0118749/?ls)
. Since then, Wahlberg has chosen roles that demonstrate a wide range of dramatic ability, starring in critically acclaimed dramas such as
Three Kings (1999) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0120188/?ls)
and
The Perfect Storm (2000) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0177971/?ls)
, popcorn flicks like
Planet of the Apes (2001) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0133152/?ls)
and
Contraband (2012) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1524137/?ls)
, and even indies such as
I Heart Huckabees (2004) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0356721/?ls)
.
Wahlberg was the executive producer of such television series as
Boardwalk Empire (2010) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0979432/?ls)
,
In Treatment (2008) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0835434/?ls)
and the highly successful comedy
Entourage (2004) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0387199/?ls)
, which was partly based on his experiences in Hollywood.
Wahlberg and his wife
Rhea Durham (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm1081113/?ls)
have four children.
Boston, Massachusetts
Actor/director/producer megastar, former Calvin Klein model
[No Text] (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000255/?ref_=ls_i_2)
2. Ben Affleck (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000255/?ref_=ls_t_2)
Producer
Actor
Writer
Argo (2012) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1024648/?ref_=ls_knf_2)
Benjamin Géza "Ben" Affleck-Boldt was born on August 15, 1972 in Berkeley, California and raised in Cambridge, Massachusetts, to mother Chris Anne (Boldt), a school teacher, and father Timothy Byers "Tim" Affleck, a social worker. Ben has a younger brother, actor
Casey Affleck (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000729/?ls)
, who was born in 1975. He is of mostly English, Irish, German, and Scottish ancestry. His middle name, Géza, is after a Hungarian family friend who was a Holocaust survivor.
Affleck wanted to be an actor ever since he could remember, and his first acting experience was for a Burger King commercial, when he was on the PBS mini-series,
The Voyage of the Mimi (1984) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0124265/?ls)
. It was also at that age when Ben met his lifelong friend and fellow actor,
Matt Damon (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000354/?ls)
. They played little league together and took drama classes together. Ben's teen years consisted of mainly TV movies and small television appearances including
Hands of a Stranger (1987) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0093141/?ls)
and
The Second Voyage of the Mimi (1988) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0278695/?ls)
. He made his big introduction into feature films in 1993 when he was cast in
Dazed and Confused (1993) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0106677/?ls)
. After that, he did mostly independent films like
Kevin Smith (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0003620/?ls)
's
Mallrats (1995) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0113749/?ls)
and
Chasing Amy (1997) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0118842/?ls)
which were great for Ben's career, receiving renowned appreciation for his works at the Sundance film festival. But the success he was having in independent films didn't last much longer and things got a little shaky for Ben. He was living in an apartment with his brother Casey and friend Matt, getting tired of being turned down for the big roles in films and being given the forgettable supporting ones. Since Matt was having the same trouble, they decided to write their own script, where they could call all the shots. So, after finishing the script for
Good Will Hunting (1997) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0119217/?ls)
, they gave it to their agent,
Patrick Whitesell (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0925877/?ls)
, who showed it to a few Hollywood studios, finally being accepted by Castle Rock. It was great news for the two, but Castle Rock wasn't willing to give Ben and Matt the control over the project they were hoping for. It was friend
Kevin Smith (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0003620/?ls)
who took it to the head of Miramax who bought the script giving Ben and Matt the control they wanted and, in December 5, 1997,
Good Will Hunting (1997) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0119217/?ls)
was released, making the two unknown actors famous. The film was nominated for 9 Academy Awards and won two, including Best Original Screenplay for Ben and Matt. The film marked Ben's breakthrough role, in which he was given for the first time the chance to choose roles instead of having to go through grueling auditions constantly.
Affleck chose such roles in the blockbusters
Armageddon (1998) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0120591/?ls)
,
Shakespeare in Love (1998) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0138097/?ls)
, and
Pearl Harbor (2001) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0213149/?ls)
. In the early years of the 2000s, he also starred in the box office hits
Changing Lanes (2002) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0264472/?ls)
,
The Sum of All Fears (2002) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0164184/?ls)
, and
Daredevil (2003) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0287978/?ls)
, as well as the disappointing comedies
Gigli (2003) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0299930/?ls)
and
Surviving Christmas (2004) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0252028/?ls)
. While the mid 2000s were considered a career downturn for Affleck, he received a Golden Globe nomination for his performance in
Hollywoodland (2006) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0427969/?ls)
. In the several years following, he played supporting roles, including in the films
Smokin' Aces (2006) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0475394/?ls)
,
He's Just Not That Into You (2009) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1001508/?ls)
,
State of Play (2009) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0473705/?ls)
, and
Extract (2009) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1225822/?ls)
. He ventured into directing in 2007, with the thriller
Gone Baby Gone (2007) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0452623/?ls)
, which starred his brother,
Casey Affleck (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000729/?ls)
, and was well received. He then directed, co-wrote, and starred in
The Town (2010) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0840361/?ls)
, which was named to the National Board of Review Top Ten Films of the year. For the political thriller
Argo (2012) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1024648/?ls)
, which he directed and starred in, Affleck won the Golden Globe Award and BAFTA Award for Best Director, and the Academy Award, Golden Globe Award, and BAFTA Award for Best Picture (Affleck's second Oscar win).
In 2014, Affleck headlined the book adaptation thriller
Gone Girl (2014) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2267998/?ls)
. He starred as Bruce Wayne/Batman in the superhero film
Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice (2016) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2975590/?ls)
,
Suicide Squad (2016) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1386697/?ls)
, and
Justice League (2017) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0974015/?ls)
. He reprised the role in
Zack Snyder's Justice League (2021) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt12361974/?ls)
and he will next appear as Batman in
Aquaman and the Lost Kingdom (2023) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt9663764/?ls)
and
The Flash (2023) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0439572/?ls)
.
Recently he has given praise-worthy performances in
The Way Back (2020) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt8544498/?ls)
as a recovering alcoholic,
The Last Duel (2021) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt4244994/?ls)
(notably he also co-wrote the script), and a scene-stealing golden globe nominated performance in
The Tender Bar (2021) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt3108894/?ls)
.
Boston, Massachusetts
Actor/director, broke into showbiz with childhood pal Matt Damon
[No Text] (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000354/?ref_=ls_i_3)
3. Matt Damon (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000354/?ref_=ls_t_3)
Producer
Actor
Writer
Good Will Hunting (1997) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0119217/?ref_=ls_knf_3)
Matthew Paige Damon was born on October 8, 1970, in Boston, Massachusetts, to
Kent Damon (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm1497320/?ls)
, a stockbroker, realtor and tax preparer, and
Nancy Carlsson-Paige (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm1497472/?ls)
, an early childhood education professor at Lesley University. Matt has an older brother, Kyle, a sculptor. His father was of English and Scottish descent, and his mother is of Finnish and Swedish ancestry. The family lived in Newton until his parents divorced in 1973, when Damon and his brother moved with his mother to Cambridge. He grew up in a stable community, and was raised near actor
Ben Affleck (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000255/?ls)
.
Damon attended Cambridge Rindge and Latin School and he performed in a number of theater productions during his time there. He attended Harvard University as an English major. While in Harvard, he kept on skipping classes to pursue acting projects, which included the TNT original film,
Rising Son (1990) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0100497/?ls)
, and prep-school drama,
School Ties (1992) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0105327/?ls)
. It was until his film,
Geronimo: An American Legend (1993) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0107004/?ls)
, was expected to be a big success that he decided to drop out of university completely. Arriving in Hollywood, Matt managed to get his first break with a part in the romantic comedy,
Mystic Pizza (1988) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0095690/?ls)
. However, the film did not do too well and his film career failed to take off. Not letting failure discourage him from acting, he went for another audition, and managed to get a starring role in
School Ties (1992) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0105327/?ls)
. Up next for Matt was a role as a soldier who had problems with drug-addiction in the movie,
Courage Under Fire (1996) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0115956/?ls)
. Matt had, in fact, lost forty pounds for his role which resulted in health problems.
The following year, he garnered accolades for
Good Will Hunting (1997) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0119217/?ls)
, a screenplay he had originally written for an English class at Harvard University.
Good Will Hunting (1997) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0119217/?ls)
was nominated for 9 Academy Awards, one of which, Matt won for Best Original Screenplay along with
Ben Affleck (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000255/?ls)
. In the year 1998, Matt played the title role in
Steven Spielberg (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000229/?ls)
's film,
Saving Private Ryan (1998) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0120815/?ls)
, which was one of the most acclaimed films in that year. Matt had the opportunity of working with
Tom Hanks (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000158/?ls)
and
Vin Diesel (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0004874/?ls)
while filming that movie. That same year, he starred as an earnest law student and reformed poker player in
Rounders (1998) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0128442/?ls)
, starring opposite
Edward Norton (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001570/?ls)
and
John Malkovich (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000518/?ls)
. The next year, Matt rejoined his childhood friend,
Ben Affleck (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000255/?ls)
and fellow comedian,
Chris Rock (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001674/?ls)
, in the comedy
Dogma (1999) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0120655/?ls)
.
Towards the end of 1999, Matt played "Tom Ripley", a working-class young man who tastes the good life and will do anything to live it. Both
Jude Law (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000179/?ls)
and
Gwyneth Paltrow (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000569/?ls)
also starred in the movie.
The Talented Mr. Ripley (1999) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0134119/?ls)
earned mixed reviews from critics, but even so, Matt earned praise for his performance. Matt lent his voice to the animated movie,
Titan A.E. (2000) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0120913/?ls)
in the year 2000, which also earned mixed reviews from the public. He also starred in two other movies,
All the Pretty Horses (2000) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0149624/?ls)
and the golf comedy-drama,
The Legend of Bagger Vance (2000) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0146984/?ls)
, starring alongside
Will Smith (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000226/?ls)
. In the year 2003, he signed on to star in
The Informant! (2009) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1130080/?ls)
by
Steven Soderbergh (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001752/?ls)
and the Farrelly Brothers'
Stuck on You (2003) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0338466/?ls)
. He also starred in
Gerry (2002) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0302674/?ls)
, a film he co-wrote with his friends,
Gus Van Sant (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001814/?ls)
and
Casey Affleck (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000729/?ls)
. One of Matt's most recognizable work to date is his role in the "Bourne" movie franchise. He plays an amnesiac assassin, "Jason Bourne", in
The Bourne Identity (2002) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0258463/?ls)
,
The Bourne Supremacy (2004) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0372183/?ls)
and
The Bourne Ultimatum (2007) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0440963/?ls)
. Another praised role is that as "Linus Caldwell" in the "Ocean's" movie franchise. He had the opportunity to star opposite
George Clooney (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000123/?ls)
,
Brad Pitt (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000093/?ls)
,
Julia Roberts (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000210/?ls)
and
Don Cheadle (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000332/?ls)
in
Ocean's Eleven (2001) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0240772/?ls)
. The successful crime comedy-drama eventually had two other sequels,
Ocean's Twelve (2004) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0349903/?ls)
and
Ocean's Thirteen (2007) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0496806/?ls)
. Among other highly acclaimed movies that Matt has been a part of are
Terry Gilliam (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000416/?ls)
's
The Brothers Grimm (2005) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0355295/?ls)
,
George Clooney (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000123/?ls)
's
Syriana (2005) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0365737/?ls)
,
Martin Scorsese (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000217/?ls)
's
The Departed (2006) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0407887/?ls)
and
Robert De Niro (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000134/?ls)
's
The Good Shepherd (2006) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0343737/?ls)
.
In his personal life, Matt is now happily married to Argentine-born
Luciana Damon (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm3180094/?ls)
, whom he met in Miami, where she was working as a bartender. They married in a private civil ceremony on December 9, 2005, at the Manhattan Marriage Bureau. The couple have four daughters Alexia, Luciana's daughter from a previous relationship, as well as Isabella, Gia and Stella. Matt is a big fan of the Boston Red Sox and he tries to attend their games whenever possible. He has also formed great friendships with his Ocean's co-stars,
George Clooney (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000123/?ls)
and
Brad Pitt (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000093/?ls)
, whom he works on charity projects with. He and actor
Ben Affleck (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000255/?ls)
have remained lifelong friends and collaborators.
Boston, Massachusetts
Movie star and co-writer of
Good Will Hunting
with Ben Affleck

4. Casey Affleck (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000729/?ref_=ls_t_4)
Actor
Director
Writer
Manchester by the Sea (2016) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt4034228/?ref_=ls_knf_4)
Casey Affleck is a renowned American actor, filmmaker, and producer recognized for his captivating performances and commitment to independent cinema. With an Academy Award under his belt and a reputation as a powerful leading man, Casey Affleck has established himself as one of the most compelling and versatile actors in contemporary cinema. Throughout his career, he has consistently delivered performances of exceptional depth and nuance in a wide range of film genres.
Affleck's breakout role came in Andrew Dominik's critically acclaimed character drama, "The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford" (2007). His performance as Robert Ford, a young man consumed by a complex cocktail of admiration and resentment for the notorious outlaw Jesse James (portrayed by Brad Pitt), earned him widespread recognition, including Academy Award, Golden Globe, and Screen Actors Guild Award nominations.
He solidified his critical acclaim with a starring role in his brother Ben Affleck's directorial debut, "Gone, Baby, Gone" (2007). This gripping neo-noir followed two Boston-based private detectives searching for an abducted young girl. Affleck's performance, showcasing both vulnerability and determination, further cemented his reputation as a rising dramatic force.
The following decade saw Affleck continue to diversify his roles, venturing outside the realm of independent drama to blockbuster productions. He was seen in Christopher Nolan's ambitious sci-fi epic "Interstellar" (2014) alongside an ensemble cast including Matthew McConaughey and Anne Hathaway. Affleck also appeared in Scott Cooper's gritty crime thriller, "Out of the Furnace" (2013), where he shared the screen with Christian Bale.
His versatility continued to shine with his performance in the independent film "Ain't Them Bodies Saints" (2013), showcasing a quieter, more brooding side to his acting talents. That same year, Affleck turned his attention to production, establishing The Affleck/Middleton Project with John Powers Middleton as a platform to develop and produce a diverse array of film and television projects.
Affleck's directorial work came to fruition with the release of the mockumentary "I'm Still Here" (2010), which he directed, wrote, and produced, featuring Joaquin Phoenix in a performance art piece that blurred the lines between fiction and reality. This experimental project demonstrated Affleck's willingness to challenge conventional storytelling formats.
In 2016, Affleck returned to the spotlight with his career-defining performance in Kenneth Lonergan's profoundly moving drama, "Manchester by the Sea." His portrayal of Lee Chandler, a grief-stricken man coping with immense loss, earned him the Academy Award for Best Actor. This raw and unforgettable performance cemented Affleck's status as one of the industry's finest dramatic actors.
2016 also saw Affleck star in several other notable films, including the action thriller "Triple 9" (2016) and Disney's historical drama, "The Finest Hours." He further expanded his range with roles in independent films like David Lowery's "A Ghost Story" (2017), a meditative exploration of loss and the passage of time.
Affleck has continued to take on challenging projects that have pushed his boundaries as an actor. Most recently, he starred opposite Elisabeth Moss in the psychological thriller "Light of My Life" (2019), which he also wrote and directed.
His upcoming projects include a pivotal role in Christopher Nolan's highly-anticipated "Oppenheimer" (2023), where he portrays theoretical physicist Robert Oppenheimer himself. Affleck is also slated to star in "Slingshot" (2024), a science fiction thriller set in space.
Casey Affleck's talent for embodying complex, flawed characters with profound authenticity has made him one of the most sought-after actors in the industry. With his captivating performances, dedication to his craft, and his discerning eye for unique storytelling projects, the future remains bright for this remarkable actor.
Boston, Massachusetts
Star of
Gone Baby Gone
, film director, brother of Ben Affleck

5. Donnie Wahlberg (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0005531/?ref_=ls_t_5)
Actor
Producer
Composer
Saw II (2005) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0432348/?ref_=ls_knf_5)
Donald Edmond "Donnie" Wahlberg Jr. was born on August 17, 1969 in Boston, Massachusetts into a family of Swedish (from his paternal grandfather), Irish, and more distant French-Canadian, English, and Scottish, descent. He is the eighth of nine children of Alma Elaine Conroy (née Donnelly), a nurse's aide and clerk & Donald Edward Wahlberg, a delivery driver. His parents eventually divorced and Donnie, finding himself already in trouble, discovered a positive outlet performing in school plays and became involved in varied aspects of theater -- acting, writing, and directing. At 15, he became a member of the teen vocal group originally called NYNUK. Donnie's little brother,
Mark Wahlberg (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000242/?ls)
was originally one of the Boys but balked at the direction the group was taking and backed out.
A founding member of the boy band "New Kids on the Block," the five teens survived a false start with their debut album and proceeded to hit #1 with the single "Please Don't Go Girl" on their second in 1988. They continued to bombard the market with one-after-another "Top Ten" hits including "The Right Stuff" and "I'll Be Loving You Forever." Leaving the young girls panting for more, they became one of the hottest young singing/line-dancing groups to hit the late 80s/early 90s. The Boys went on to sell over 70 million albums worldwide, and provoke the spawning of other five-member harmony groups such as Backstreet Boys and *NSYNC. During its heyday, Donnie played up his resident "bad boy" persona by tallying up several run-ins with the law, including an alleged arson at a Kentucky hotel (charges were dropped). He also delved into "body art" with numerous tattoos and body piercings in an effort to buck their already-cloying image. Amid intergroup dissension and Milli Vanilli-like charges of not contributing all the vocals to their albums, the pop band finally disbanded in 1994 -- partly out of frustration but also having outgrown the group's juvenile moniker.
Unsure of his direction while attracting more trouble in the tabloids, Donnie, who helped write, arrange and produce brother Mark's Funky Bunch group's first two albums a few years earlier, switched gears. He rapped some and modeled some, then transformed himself into an actor, a route taken earlier by his talented bro. While Mark has turned out to become the bigger film star over the years, Donnie has stepped out of his shadows to receive raves and renewed respect for his own tense and compelling character work.
He first showed up in big screen action. Making his debut as a "tough guy" thug in the
Mickey Rourke (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000620/?ls)
urban outing
Bullet (1996) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0115781/?ls)
, filmed in 1994 but not released until two years later. Usually cast as an amoral heavy, Donnie moved up the quality ladder with director
Ron Howard (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000165/?ls)
's thriller
Ransom (1996) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0117438/?ls)
as part of a gang of kidnappers who nab
Mel Gibson (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000154/?ls)
's son, to their eventual regret, of course. His next repellent took the form of a drug dealer in the goth indie horror
Black Circle Boys (1997) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0118730/?ls)
, but the film came and went. After a couple of TV movies, he finally nabbed a starring role in the film
Southie (1998) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0118766/?ls)
playing more or less himself as an Irish-American prodigal son who returns to the mean streets of his native Boston. The movie also featured another brother
Robert Wahlberg (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0906301/?ls)
who also was testing the acting waters.
Ironically, one of Donnie's most powerful roles during this period was also one of his briefest. Seen in the opening sequence, he is nearly unrecognizable (having dropped an alarming amount of weight) portraying a deranged former patient of psychiatrist
Bruce Willis (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000246/?ls)
whose sudden explosion into unfathomable violence sets up the clever twists and turns that turned
M. Night Shyamalan (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0796117/?ls)
's classic psychological thriller
The Sixth Sense (1999) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0167404/?ls)
into a critically-acclaimed box office hit. Donnie's opening bit was mouth dropping and jarring in its horror. He also proved he wasn't a flash in the pan by backing up this performance with a major role as a WWII paratrooper in the critically-hailed ten-part epic
Band of Brothers (2001) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0185906/?ls)
, which won multiple Emmy awards (6).
This TV role directly led to his casting as a gritty L.A. detective in the NBC dramatic series
Boomtown (2002) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0319960/?ls)
, an acclaimed series that didn't survive a second season. Since then Donnie has patented his unrefined intensity into a number of films such as
Triggermen (2002) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0283077/?ls)
,
Dreamcatcher (2003) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0285531/?ls)
,
Saw II (2005) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0432348/?ls)
,
Annapolis (2006) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0417433/?ls)
,
Saw III (2006) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0489270/?ls)
,
Saw IV (2007) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0890870/?ls)
and
Zookeeper (2011) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1222817/?ls)
. He has also clocked in lead roles for such roughhewn TV series as
Runaway (2006) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0805665/?ls)
,
The Kill Point (2007) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0862593/?ls)
,
Return of the Mac (2017) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt6329316/?ls)
and, most notably, as detective Danny Reagan in
Blue Bloods (2010) (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1595859/?ls)
.
Donny has two sons, Xavier and Elijah, by first wife Kim Fey, and is married to actress/producer/writer
Jenny McCarthy-Wahlberg (https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000189/?ls)
. As a former teen heartthrob seemingly headed down a troubled and dangerous path after his initial success, he somehow managed to avoid the traditional pitfalls of drugs and self-destruction, and has since proven himself an actor with "the right stuff." In addition, the "New Kids on the Block" reteamed in 2007 in recording and book tours. The group received a Hollywood Walk of Fame star in 2014.
Boston, Massachusetts
Former 'New Kid On The Block', actor, brother of Mark Wahlberg
